RBF reduced the overnight policy rate to 0.25 % from 0.5 % on March 18 to counter the economic impact of COVID-19
Countercyclical capital buffer down from 0.25% to 0% in accordance with the ECB proposal.
Conduct open market operations in the form of purchase of an aggregate amount of ÔøΩÔøΩ_ 10,000 crores  of Government securities through a multi-security auction

Level 2 policy measures: Enhancing tools for out-of-court debt restructuring and workouts
Details of the measure: Commercial banks have agreed to extend repayment of personal loans by a period of up to 12 months.

Level 2 policy measures: Enhancing tools for out-of-court debt restructuring and workouts
Details of the measure: Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (SMEs) and corporate borrowers  encouraged to contact their lenders on the potential for loan restructuring with banks being expected to harbour the costs of the review.
Review the terms of payments on loans related to the circumstances of the spread of coronavirus infection, and provide a deferral of payments for at least three months per borrower application.

The Bank of Mongolia has exempted data users from the credit report fee until January 1st 2021. Borrowers who are having difficulty repaying their loans due to the Covid-19 pandemic to maintain their credit rating will not be downgraded to the Credit Information Database if they are unable to repay their principal and interest temporarily. But it will not eliminate the obligation to repay the loan, and if there is a real problem with the borrower, the lender can contact the bank to request a deferral of the loan service and amend the loan agreement.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Temporary financial forbearance measures on prudential requirements, loan classifications, and restructuring standards.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: COVID-19 Fund established at the Myanmar Economic Bank with a capital of MMK100 billion (US$71 million) to provide loans to businesses in the apparel, hospitality and tourism sectors and SMEs owned by Myanmar nationals which are suffering the most negative economic consequences, at an interest rate of 1 per cent and a loan period of 1 year (may be adjusted on the severity of the economic loss incurred).
A change in denar reserve requirements for newly approved and restructured loans is expected to promote lending and more favorable credit standards for companies affected by the crisis.
A decision was also made to postpone the application of regulatory requirements related to liquidity to allow banksÔøΩÔøΩto focus onÔøΩÔøΩlending to businesses and households.

Decree adopted allowing banks and savings houses to apply regulatory forbearance for changing loan terms (grace period, maturity, interest rate) with simplified procedures (i.e. no visit to a branch necessary). Banks can initiate loan restructurings without client request which clients can accept/ decline within 10 days. If there is no response, the offer will be considered accepted for individuals and rejected for businesses. So far the banks are offering this option only to individuals and not to businesses. Some banks still require payment of interest during the grace period. Financial companies (issuing quick loans) and leasing companies are to reduce the monthly instalments for individuals by 70% in the next three months, and delay repayment deadlines by at least 90 days, while renegotiating business loans on case-by-case basis. These companies re to issue new loans with 3 months grace period, reduce penalty interest rate from 51% to 31%, and limit all other fees to max 20% of the loan
Precautions should be taken to ensure that banks, exchanges and FLCs can continue their operation
Branches and agents should be equipped with appropriate means of sterilization
SAMA introduces controls for provision of necessary services not available online for  financial institutions

The extraordinary circumstances derived from the current public health emergency situation in Spain caused by the outbreak of COVID-2019 may make it difficult for obliged entities to comply with their obligations of reporting and information to SEPBLAC. Consequently, Sepblac will duly take into account such extraordinary circumstances in order to assess possible delays in compliance.

Establishment of a Money Market Mutual Fund Liquidity Facility, or MMLF. The Federal Reserve Bank  of Boston will make loans available to eligible financial institutions secured by high-quality assets purchased by the financial institution from money market mutual funds

CBU recommended providing a grace period for the repayment of the principal on the loans until October 1, 2020 and to extend the deadlines for payments, based on when the grace period is granted, without change in the classification of loans
Banks to sell part of the sovereign bonds to increase their ablity to participate in the soft credit line to the SMEs to cover their working capital needs
Lower reserve rates for banks participating in the special plan to give credit to SMEs to cover working capital needs
Reduction in reserves required on certain consumer loans for households (Programa Ahora 12)

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Flexibility in the computation and provisioning of NPLs  with an extension of up to 60 days until September 2020.

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: Ban on dividends by banks until 6/30/2020
Establishment of temporary U.S. dollar liquidity arrangements (swap lines)  with the US Fed
Reserve Bank of Australia cuts interest rates to 0.25%
Up to $15 billion will be used to support wholesale funding markets used by smaller lenders, including non-bank lenders.
A three-year funding facility to authorised deposit-taking institutions (ADIs) at a fixed rate of 0.25ÔøΩÔøΩperÔøΩÔøΩcent.  This facility is for at least $90ÔøΩÔøΩbillion.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Both banks and non-bank financial institutions will suspend adverse the classification of loan from January 01, 2020 until June 30, 2020. However, up-gradation of classification is allowed.

The Central Bank has advised the commercial banks to strengthen their Online Banking services and also to enhance customer service through their dedicated hotlines so that customers may obtain essential banking services without visiting their branches. Commercial banks are also instructed to make necessary arrangements for the fluent service of their ATMs, POSs and Agent Banking services during this period and ensure hand sanitizers at all customer touch points to comply with the health guidelines set by Bangladesh Government.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Bangladesh Bank has also increased the limit of the P2P (people to People) transactions of Mobile Financial Services from Tk. 75,000/- to Tk. 200,000/- for purchasing the pharmaceutical and daily used products and instructed to keep these transactions free of charges. The maximum limit for the same case in terms of Debit and Credit Card will be Tk. 15,000/- daily and Tk. 75,000/- on monthly basis.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Cash Out up to Tk. 1,000/- will be exempted from any sort of service charges.
BNB announced increasing the liquidity of the banking system by BGN 7bn by reducing foreign exposures to commercial banks.

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: BNB announced capitalization of the full volume of profit in the banking system in the amount of BGN 1.6bn
BNB announced cancellation of the increase of the countercyclical capital buffer planned for 2020 and 2021 with effect of BGN 0.7bn

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: MTN announced on March 19 that they will be suspending the payment of fees for money transfers for amounts up to 20,000 FCFA. The measure will be limited to 3 transactions per day, per account, and will be valid for a period of 30 days. This may be reviewed based on the development of the health crisis.

Launch of its new liquidity facility, the Standing Term Liquidity Facility (STLF), effective March 30, 2020, the Bank can provide loans to eligible financial institutions in need of temporary liquidity support and where the Bank has no concerns about their financial soundness

Measures to strengthen the liquidity in pesos: 1) extend group of institutions with access to auctions and to the liquidity window of the Central Bank with public debt instruments, by including pension and severance fund managers;
2) To authorize insurance companies to participate in the auctions of repos with both public and private debt instruments;

3) To extend access to funds managed through trusts, stock-brokers and investment management companies to repo auction and to the window with pubic debt instruments (in addition to the repo auctions with private debt instruments);

4) extending the maturities of liquidity operations (REPOS) with private debt instruments to 90 days; The total allotment for liquidity operations (REPOS) with government and private debt instruments increased from $20 trillion (t) to $23.5 t.

Measure to strengthen liquidity in US dollars: US$400 million of swaps in US dollars (FX Swaps) will be auctioned for, in which the Central Bank will sell dollars in cash and will buy them in futures (at 60 days). This measure provides temporary liquidity in US dollars to a large group of institutions including not only traditional intermediaries in the foreign exchange market, but also pension and severance fund managers in both proprietary position and managed funds, with the purpose of alleviating pressures in the foreign exchange market.
Instructions related to the complementary measures to strengthen the management of liquidity and operational risks in the stock market. External Circular Number 11.
LCR - credit institutions might use liquidity buffer below 100%

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: Retention of net income for 2019 (the CNB will decide on a case-by-case basis).  Credit institutions are additionally expected to adjust the payment of variable remunerations (bonuses, severance payments, etc.).
Three-month moratorium on loan repayment, only payment of interest must be fulfilled, to any debtor   in the regulated financial sector. During this period, no late fees can be charged.
During this period, no mortgage garanties can be executed, and financial institutions do not need to submit data to the Credit Bureau.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Lower the requirements for provisioning. Banks may not provision for a years to cover non performing  loans that were performing before 31 March 2020.
Reduction of CB reference interest rates (CB Bonds): from 4% to 17% depending on the maturity.

Reduction of reserve ratios required to 40% for banks in local currency, 28.5% for Saving Banks, adding  11% for each ratio for foreign currency. And 20% of treasurty bonds held by a bank can be consider as mandatory reserve.
Three month waiver of the interbank transaction fee charged by the Central Bank (35 HTG or 0.35 USD)

7-day reverse repo rate, cut 25bp, to 4.5%, Deposit Facility (DF) rates lowered 25 bps to 3,75% and Lending Facility (LF) rates lowered 25 bps to 5,25%.
BI extends the SBN (government bond) repo tenor to 12 months and providing daily auctions to  loosen rupiah liquidity in the banking industry, effective from 20th March 2020.
BI increases the frequency of FX swap auctions for 1, 3, 6 and 12-month tenors from three times  per week to daily auctions in order to ensure adequate liquidity.
6-months moratorium on loan repayments for affected industries (upon customers applications to  banks);
Reduction of the Minimum Reserve Requirement (MRR) up to 5 percent
$150 million FX swap with the Reserve Bank of India

Deferral to 2021 of entry into force of some international standards, such as such as TLAC, Large Exposures and NSFR.

Interest rate cut, 25 bps to 3.75%.
7-day reverse repo rate, cut 100bp, to 1.25%

Relaxation in the maximum penalty that may be imposed for reserve deficiencies

5.5 trillion won worth of guarantees for loans to SMEs and 100 % loan guarantee worth 3 trillion won for small merchants

New BoE Corporate Financing Facility (CCFF) to provide funding for large corporates by purchasing commercial paper.
Bank Rate reduced by 15bp to 0.1%

Operating band will be narrowed to 25 basis points compared to 50 basis points previously, the deposit rate will be set to the current target for the overnight rate

Discount window of the CB and proportional to the loans granted by those financial institutions, specially to SMEs;

The additional resources channeled through the FCIC will be proportional to the increase of each institution's loans with respect to their benchmark portfolio. This expansion factor will be higher for smaller credits.
Injection of RMB 2.8 trillion liquidity via open market operation since Feb 3, though most are withdrawn.
RMB 500 billion via re-lending/re-discount facility to support SMEs financing; interest rate of re-lending facility was lowered to 2.5 percent.
RMB 300 billion in special re-lending program for business impacted by the coronavirus outbreak, at MOF subsidized rate of 1.3 percent.
The NDRC allowed high-quality SMEs to issue corporate bonds for repaying loans and replenishing operating capitals.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)

Gross interest rates on overnight deposits (DON) in 0,01% and the ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩFacilidad Permanente de CrÃ©ditoÔøΩÔøΩ? and the ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩFacilidad Permanente de DepÔøΩ_sito del Mercado Integrado de LiquidezÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ in 2,00% and 0,01% respectively.

The Banking Association asked its members to i) suspend repayment of personal loans, microcredits and SME loans for 60 days
The Banking Association asked its members to ii) restructure loans bilaterally with clients in difficulty.

CBE reduced interest rates by 3% the rates was taken as an exceptional measure, which contributes to supporting economic activity in all sectors. As a result, the CBE's overnight deposit rate fell to 9.25%

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: The Central Bank of Egypt (CBE) instructed banks to automatically enroll most of its customers into internet banking services, based on existing information available at the bank. (Note: previous regulations required a physical signature to enroll for internet banking).The measures are valid for six months. It also raised limits on prepaid cards from EGP 300 to EGP 600 without the need to enter a password CBE also instructed banks to issue free NFC/Contactless pre-paid banking cards for citizens for six months and also instructed banks to issue electronic portfolios for six months. It also requested to enlarge acceptance using QR Code, using request to pay method. The CBE has raised the limit for electronic payments via mobile phones to EGP 30,000 per day and EGP 100,000 per month for individuals, and EGP 40,000 per day and EGP 200,000 per week for corporations. CBE also increased the number of electronic cash units for every bank to EGP 500,000, allowing account transactions from within the same bank or from one bank to another. The new procedures have exempted payment outlets from all fees and commissions on operations that are carried out through banking cards or mobile phone portfolios. For ATM operations, the card issuer will bear all fees on cash withdrawals over the fee cancellation period.
CBE reduced (i) the discount rate by 100 basis points to 5.5 percent,
CBE reduced  (iii) the reserve requirement from 6 to 5 per cent.
CBE reduced  (ii) the liquidity requirements for  commercial banks (from 25 to 20 percent) and development and savings banks (from 23 to 18 percent),
The CBE invoked business continuity plans to allow some employees to work from home.

Level 3 policy measures: Prioritize or review critical supervisory actions
Details of the measure: The CBE announced that it will intensify its existing prudential measures and stress testing technics  to allow it to closely monitor the performance of all banks and respond swiftly to any indications of stress at any point in time.

The CBE strongly encouraged banks to consider restructuring loan repayments and where possible make available loan repayment holidays for businesses and individuals that have been directly or indirectly affected by the COVID-19.

Reduction in Capital Conservation Buffer (CCB) for banks to 1.5% from 3%.

The new policies will come into force tomorrow (20 March) for an initial period of three months. Under new rules transactions and withdrawals below GHS100 ($17.82) will not carry a charge. This is alongside an increase in maximum transaction limits and balance levels for all customers. Until March 31, 2021 the MoF will subsidize 100% of interest on loans for micro and SMEs. This facility will be maintained for another 30 days from the end of the state emergency.

In addition, loans that are due to be repaid within the above period will be considered by the bank for postponing of the repayment period but not exceeding 12 months from the date of repayment.Customers' credit information will be adjusted as prescribed at the request of credit institutions and foreign bank branches.

Allowed early withdrawals from their superannuation system that will be capped at AU $10,000 this financial year, and a further AU $10,000 next financial year, and will be tax-free. Credit guarantees for banks to lend to small and medium-sized enterprises, together with food and commodity companies, for the equivalent of 1.2% of GDP. Most of the announced measures are expected to be financed through allocations from other parts of the Budget.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in capital requirement (definition of capital, car, risk weights)
Details of the measure: Temporarily, the tax effects arising from the overhedge of equity investments held abroad will not be  deducted from equity. The objective is to provide capital relief ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ since the currency depreciation would lead to losses. The measure will provide financial institutions with confidence to maintain and expand their credit provision plans. According to the BCB's projections, the capital relief will amount to BRL 46 bn, in addition to allowing an expansion of approximately BRL 520 bn in credit operations

The BCB will conduct repurchase operations ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ with up to one-year term ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ backed by federal  government securities. The objective is to provide long-term liquidity, which will offsetÔøΩÔøΩthe demand for very short-term liquidity by households and companies. With this measure, the market will be able to price more efficiently the liquidity cost and the money market yield curve. In other words, these longer repos reduce the duration risk originated from the liquidity management.

The financial institutions are charged an end-of-day punitive interest rate to level their liquidity  needs. With the reduction of the spread of these liquidity-leveling operations ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ from +65 bps to +10 bps ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ the financial institutions will be able to access the 'leveling window' at aÔøΩÔøΩlower cost. The measure aims at not penalizing the operational risk originated from the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic crisis on the economy.
The purchase of private securities with a remaining maturity of up to three years
Lowering general reserve requirement from 12% to 9%.
Encouragement to make use of the digital channels.

Level 3 policy measures: Ease credit exposure limits (large exposures, credit limits)
Details of the measure: The Federal Government will increase its risk share in the guarantee banks by 10%. The upper limit of 35% operating capital in the total exposure of the guarantee banks will be increased to 50%. Guarantee banks can now make guarantee decisions up to an amount of EUR 250,000 independently and within 3 days. The large guarantee program (parallel federal-state guarantees), which has so far been limited to companies in structurally weak regions, will be opened up to companies outside these regions. Operating capital financing and investments can now be secured starting from EUR 50m of guarantee requirement and upwards, with a guarantee ratio of up to 80%.

Level 2 policy measures: Enhancing tools for out-of-court debt restructuring and workouts
Details of the measure: Financial Market Stabilization Fund of EUR 500bn is intended to rescue companies from bankruptcy by providing guarantees for their liabilities or by actually injecting capital, which would be equivalent to partial nationalization.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Expansion of existing liquidity support programs from KfW: -  Conditions for the KfW Entrepreneur Loan (for existing enterprises) and ERP Start-up Loan - Universal (for young enterprises under 35 years of age) will be relaxed by increasing risk sharing (indemnity against liability) for operating loans and by opening the instruments also to large enterprises with a turnover of up to EUR 2bn (previously: EUR 500m).  -  Higher risk sharing of up to 80% for operating loans of up to EUR 200m to stimulate the willingness of private banks to grant loans. -  Access for larger companies: The "KfW Loan for Growth" is now accessible for companies up to a turnover limit of EUR 5bn instead of EUR 2bn. Loan available for syndicated financing without limitation to a specific area (previously only innovation and digitisation). Risk assumption/sharing is increased to up to 70% (previously 50%).  -  For companies with a turnover of more than EUR 5bn, support will be provided as before on a case-by-case basis.
Suspension of the duty to file for insolvency. Simplified access to the protective restructuring procedure. All old liabilities would also be initially "frozen".

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Adjustment of hours of service of electronic payment services

Level 2 policy measures: Consumer protection measures and ensuring availability and acceptance of cash
Details of the measure: Adjustment of hours of service of physical payment services
Lowered the CRR by 100 bps to 4.25 percent which will provide additional liquidity of Kshs. 35Billion to commercial banks.
Lowered the CBR by 100 bps to 7.25 percent;

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Flexibility to banks on loan classification and provisioning for loans that were performing as at March 2, 2020 and whose repayment period was extended or restructured due to the pandemic
To disincentivize the use of cash, waiver of charges on mobile money transactions (below Kshs 1,000) and increase of M-PESA limits to Kshs. 150,000/transaction and Kshs. 300,000/day.
Extended the maximum tenor of REPOs fromÔøΩÔøΩ28ÔøΩÔøΩtoÔøΩÔøΩ91 days

The NBKR will provide liquidity assistance in local currency at refinancing rate to all banks (except those under temporary administration or liquidation) to cope with COVID-19 pandemic and ensure stability of the system. Banks will be allowed to apply to the NBKR for liquidity assistance up to 5 times until June 30, 2020.

NBKR has decided to: postpone enactment of several regulations until further notice (information disclosure of banks and fin reporting of NBFIs, regulations on prudential ratios, liquidity and credit risk),

NBKR has decided to: decrease the minimum regulatory threshold for current liquidity ratio (K3.1, liquid assets/current liabilities) from 45% to 30% and remove the other two liquidity ratio requirements (K3.2 (7-day) and K3.3 (overnight/instant)) starting March 30.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in capital requirement (definition of capital, car, risk weights)
Details of the measure: NBKR has decided to: reduce risk-weights of FX corporate and retail loans from current 150% to 100%;

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: NBKR has decided to:  in the event of arrears arising from COVID,ÔøΩÔøΩnot to worsen the classification category due to financial condition of the borrower.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: NBKR has decided to:  require full provisioning of accrued interest on past due loans after being 270 days past due instead of current 90 days past due,

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: The CBL introduced incentives for digital payments: (i) suspension of charges on ACH, RTGS, direct credit;  to customers for transfer of money from their bank accounts to their mobile money accounts; and for merchant payment transactions using mobile money; (ii) adjusted the daily and monthly limits for mobile money transactions for three months; and (iii) mobile money operators and commercial banks have agreed to suspend for one month, all charges for P2P funds transfer via internet or mobile banking services.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: The CBL has suspended for three months the rule on credits (asset classification and provisioning)  to borrowers in the aviation, hospitality, tourism, agricultural and businesses involved in cross-border trading.
The CBL is requiring all banks and MMOs to put in place preventive measures consistent with NPHIL  health protocols.
Financial services have been deemed essential services and providers can remain open for service, as long as  they do not create additional health risks

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: For a month, MTN Nigeria waived fees on Y'ello mobile money platform
Interest rate cut by 225 bps to 11%

To support dinar liquidity in the banking sector, the NBS undertook an additional EUR/RSD swap auction to provide dinar liquidity in the amount of RSD 14.9 billion to the banking sector for a period of three months at an interest rate of 0.85 percent.

The NBS also undertook a repo purchase of dinar government securities with transaction maturity of seven days and three months to the tune of RSD 4.7bn and RSD 20.5bn at 0.75 percent respectively to further increase liquidity.
Monetary Policy Rate (MPR) cut to 4 per cent from 5 per cent

Commercial banks, the Development Bank of Seychelles (DBS) and the Seychelles Credit Union have agreed to consider a moratorium of six months on the repayment of principal and interest on loans to assist businesses in impacted sectors. The six-month moratorium may also apply to individuals that have been adversely impacted.
20 trillion won will be used to buy corporate bonds and commercial paper of companies facing a credit crunch

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: 29.1 trillion won in loans to small- and medium-sized companies

Level 3 policy measures: Ensure minimal functionality in the primary and secondary markets
Details of the measure: FSC announced a 10.7 trillion won facility set up to stabilize stock markets.
FSC to commence a bond buying facility in April that will be funded by 84 institutions, including the Bank of Korea, commercial banks and insurers.
Activating the Contingent Term Repo Facility (CTRF) - a temporary enhancement to its sterling liquidity  insurance facilities
Banks can operate at 2.25 p.p. conservation buffer.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: When classifying assets at risk and forming special reserves, banks are given the right to: (a) set the special reserves (to cover losses on assets exposed to credit risk and conditional liabilities in FX) in Belarusian rubles at the NBRB official rate as of March 1, 2020, (b) classify debt on credit-risk assets and conditional liabilities in FX without interest, fees etc. due for payment over the next 12 months, (c) classify collateral received on credit-risk assets and conditional liabilities in FX as high-quality collateral without interest, fees etc. due for payment over the next 12 months, including accrued and payable in the current month, (d) assess the quality and adequacy of collateral for assets at risk and conditional liabilities in foreign currency, without taking into account the requirements for the frequency of such assessment.

For the next 3 months, commercial banks ordered to: eliminate the minimum monthly payment on the balance of credit card debt; eliminate late fees. Reserve Bank lowered interest rate on credit card consumption to 1% per month.

The Reserve Bank of Fiji (RBF) has established the financial services that are considered essential (ATMs, online and mobile banking, remittances and insurance claims) and approved the following institutions to provide these services during the contingency period: commercial banks, credit institutions, FNPF, insurance companies, and licensed foreign exchange dealers.

IOSCO Statement noting its commitment to ensure that capital markets continue to function in spite of the COVID-19 outbreak to enable all participants to price and transfer risk across all traded asset classes.
Banco de Guatemala lowered policy rate from 2.25% to 2%.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: ALL PSPs e-wallets are expected to be interoperable on March 25th. CBJ instructed all PSPs and threatened if a PSP won't comply, it will not be included in the Platform  CBJ has allowed all PSPs to enable citizens to open wallets online, with simplified KYC and with extended limits (500 JOD) to receive their funds (salaries/subsidies) and also make payments. Couple of banks have launched a new service that enables Jordanians to open a bank account (online and app). CBJ is considering encouraging other banks to follow suit.

On the recommendation of CBK, the Cabinet Secretary for the National Treasury  and Planning has published by Gazette Notice No. 3096 of April 8, 2020, the suspension for a period of six months, the listing of negative credit information for borrowers whose loans were performing previously but have become non-performing from April 1, 2020. Consequently, loans that fall in arrears from April 1 to September 30, 2020, will not lead to the ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩblacklistingÔøΩÔøΩ? of the borrower on the CRBs.
Permission to draw down the capital conservation buffer of 2.5%
Permission to operate below the minimum LCR of 100%

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Permission to reduce the regulatory reserve held against expected losses to 0%
Permission to NSFR to be implemented July 1, 2020 as planned, but lowered to 80%  until September 30, 2021
A six-months' automatic moratorium on loan repayments, principal and interest (excluding credit card balances) for individuals and SMEs
For renewal of motor insurance, consumers should use online platforms.

Banking services considered an essential service and should continue operating with minimum staff, pursue remote access, work from home and on shift basis. All branches must maintain basic health measures like use of sanitizer, mask, disinfectant, thermal scanning and hand gloves, and ensure social distancing and  encourage electronic transactions.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Service fee for all digital transactions, including RTGS, waived by the BFIs.
The BSP has announced a 200 bps reduction of the reserve requirement ratio for banks to 12%, effective 30 March, which would add a BSP-estimated PHP500bn to the system.

Level 3 policy measures: Reduce non-essential regulatory reporting requirements for banks
Details of the measure: The list of the forms of credit institution and NBFI reports that will not be subject to penalties for violations of the reporting procedures between January and June 2020 (the period may be extended if necessary) has been defined. The statistical and other information collected from credit institutions and NBFIs as part of the Bank of Russia Inspection Programme during the first six months of 2020 has been reduced.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Raise the allowed top-up of the monthly ceiling limit for e-wallets up to (20,000) SAR
Refinancing operations offered out to 12m at the twice daily windows.  The interest rate for the 3m operation will be base rate + 30bp.

The SARB will expand its ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩmonetary policy portfolioÔøΩÔøΩ? to include purchasing South Africa Government Bonds (SAGBs). This pumps cash directly into the second market and adds a backstop bid to the market where there hasn't been in recent days. This forces liquidity into a larger and more interconnected market (SAGBs) and a larger set of players including non-banks.
Banks must put in place sanitary measures in branches

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Banks have implemented BCPs to ensure that digital payments channels remain available

Resolution of the Superintendency of Financial Services that provides that deficiencies in guarantee deposits required according to the Compilation of Rules of Payment System during the period 1/3/2020 and 5/31/2020 will not be considered a deficit.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Central Bank mandated that financial institutions shall not charge fees for deposits, withdrawals, balance inquiries and any other movement, regardless of type of account, and whether the accountholder is a client or not.

The central bank eliminated limits for withdrawals at ATMs. It also established that financial entities may not charge fees or commissions for operations (deposits, withdrawals, inquiries, etc.) made through all ATMs authorized and operated by them in the country. This provision will apply until June 30, 2020 inclusive.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Putting on hold the Review of Retail Payments Regulation that was announced on 29 November 2019
Major Brazilian banks (Segment S1) can now repurchase of Financial Letters (LF) up to 20% of their own issuance (up from 5%) [CMN Resolution Nr. 4,788/2020].

Increase support by insurance and guarantee services. Insurance institutions and policy guarantee institutions are encouraged to provide credit enhancement for MSMEs in the upstream and downstream sectors of the industrial chain to help them obtain finance.

Banned for insurance companies to pay dividends as part of efforts to ensure there is enough liquidity in the country's financial system during the coronavirus crisis and following an earthquake that hit Zagreb.

Level 3 policy measures: Reduce non-essential regulatory reporting requirements for banks
Details of the measure: Delay of deadlines for regular Solvency 2 reporting in line with EIOPA Recommendations on supervisory flexibility regarding the deadline of supervisory reporting and public disclosure - Coronavirus/COVID-19. Delay of deadlines for other regular reports (other than Solvency 2) for one month.

The Bank Board of the Czech National Bank lowered the two-week repo rate (2W repo rate) by 75 basis points to 1.00%. At the same time, it lowered the Lombard rate to 2.00% and the discount rate to 0.05%.

Level 2 policy measures: Consumer protection measures and ensuring availability and acceptance of cash
Details of the measure: Adequating operating hours of financial intermediaries

CBE announced that it is reviewing its emergency liquidity assistance for banks which are experiencing  liquidity stress and will lower the cost of borrowing from such a tool and extend repayment from overnight to up to 9 months

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Amole and M-BIRR are providing free transactions on their mobile money services.

Commercial banks in Fiji to offer loan repayment holidays on principal and interest for up to 6 months for businesses and individual customers facing hardship with mortgages and loan repayments due to the COVID-19 pandemic. This is expected to provide a relief of around $400 million.

Commercial banks, Fiji Development Bank and licenced credit institutions can access funds from RBF with an interest rate of 1 % per annum and lend to eligible businesses at a maximum interest rate of 5 %.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: An additional five million dollars will also be added to the Small and Medium Enterprises Credit Guarantee Scheme to cover 50% of the outstanding loans in case of default

Advanced the variable rate term repo auction of ÔøΩÔøΩ_ 25,000 crores from March 30, 2020 to March 26, 2020 and enhanced the amount of the auction scheduled for March 26, 2020, i.e., today to ÔøΩÔøΩ_ 50,000 crores from ÔøΩÔøΩ_ 25,000 crores

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: NPCI has fast tracked the onboarding system on UPI or UPI-QR to make it totally contactless and fully online and Vendors do not have to compromise on self-isolation guidelines to complete these essential tasks
New debt strategy launched on April 14, but scale TBC
Bank of Jamaica reintroduced a longer-term lending facility, whereby Jamaican dollar liquidity will be made available to DTIs for periods of up to six months.

According to the Regulation of the Agency (March 26, 2020 No. 167), the suspension of payments of individuals who have right to apply for a postponed payment, in accordance with this Regulation is not a reason for deterioration of the borrower's credit history and the submission of negative information about the borrower to credit bureaus.
BOL issued a new credit policy for those impacted, asking banks and financial institutions to restructure loans and provide new loans to businesses affected by the outbreak.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Under this policy, banks and financial institutions that implement debt restructuring and new loan provisions will benefit from regulatory forbearance on loan provisioning.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Under this policy, banks and financial institutions that implement debt restructuring and new loan provisions will benefit from regulatory forbearance on loan classification.

Partial or total deferral of principal and / or interest payments for up to 4 months, with respect to the entire amount due. Balances may be frozen without interest charge. Apply for instance to mortgage-backed housing loans, revolving and non-revolving loans directed at individuals

Banks can grant loan payment moratorium or so-called payment holiday for loan payments (includes  principal and interest) for a period ranging from 6 months up to 24 months based on a thorough assessment of economic and financial difficulties experienced by individual borrowers

Bank of Namibia has relaxed the Determination on Liquidity Risk Management (banks required to ensure  that their cash inflows match the cash outflows expected within 0-7 days) so that expected outflows may exceed the inflows, but not more than the excess liquidity above their regulatory limit
Capital conservation buffer rate reduced to 0 percent for atleast 24 months to support banking  institutions to supply credit to the economy

Postponed the effective date of implementation of the 25 percent single borrower limit and concentration risk limit to allow banking institutions a wider scope to lend to vulnerable sectors of the economy
Capital Conservation Buffer (CCB) reduced from 2.5% to 1.5% (applicable until further notice)

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in capital requirement (definition of capital, car, risk weights)
Details of the measure: Increase in the regulatory limit for classification of exposures under 'regulatory retail' portfolio for capital adequacy purposes  from PKR 125 million per single counterparty to PKR 180 million

Level 3 policy measures: Ease other macroprudential measures (eg, dti, ltv)
Details of the measure: One year increase on Debt Burden Ratio for consumer loans (from 50% to 60%). BPRD Circular Letter No. 14 of 2020
Payment holiday on loan principal repayments (for all loans, applicable for one year, interest still to be paid)

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Regulatory criteria for restucturing/rescheduling loans relaxed till March 2021.  No impact on credit rating for this.
Banks are permited to lend against shares as collateral

Level 3 policy measures: Ease other macroprudential measures (eg, dti, ltv)
Details of the measure: Margin call requirement of 30% vis-ÔøΩÔøΩ-vis banks' financing against listed shares reduced to 10%.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Temporary Bridging Loan Programme expanded to cover all sectors and maximum supported loan raised from S$1m to $5m
Forex futures trading limited to be raised by 25%: Up from 40% to 50% for local banks and from 200% to 250% of foreign bank branches in Korea

Level 3 policy measures: Ease other macroprudential measures (eg, dti, ltv)
Details of the measure: The levy on financial institutions' non-deposit FX liabilities to be temporarily lifted for three months from April to June, as well as installment payment plans to be expanded for payments due this year
FX liquidity coverage ratio (LCR) of 70%, down from 80%, until May

BOK to supply an unlimited amount of liquidity at set interest rates based on market demand by buying bonds (91-day) in repo auctions once every week to ensure financial market stability and to support timely implementation of the government's Financial Support Package.

Loan restructuring recommendation was widened to include also individuals, and not only the principal amount, but also accrued interest. Banks were also recommended not to apply penalties for late payment of overdue loans and not to foreclose collateral on such loans.
Statutory reserves from 5% to 4.5% to allow banks to increase lending to private sector.
Issuance of Open Market Operations (OMO) Corporate Bills to mop up liquidity from the market.

Reintroduction of multi-currency regime to allow local transactions to be paid for in US$. Fixed exchange rate of US$1: ZWL$25 to provide a cushion to ever increasing prices of goods and services. Ban market system where market players were exchanging forex using an interbank rate. Currently the rate at the parallel market is US$1: ZWL$40. On 23 June 2020, the FX Auction gave rise to the initial market-determined exchange rate of ZW$57.36 to the US$.
Reduce lending rate from 35% to 25% to allow banks to  reduce their interest rate to borrowers.
Banks have been persuaded not to increase cost for money transfer. Mobile money transfer operators have been engaged to reduce costs of money transfers.
Engagement with financial market infrastructures on pandemic plans.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Provision of Working Capital at a 5 percent interest for wholesale distributors authorized by the Ministry of Economic Affairs for a period of 3 months, extendable by 3 months to enable them to procure adequate stocks and ensure uninterrupted supply of essential items at reasonable price.
All banks and financial institutions have been issued a directive to restructure loans, especially to ease the burden of debtors  facing major revenue declines
7-day reverse repo rate, cut 50bp, to 0.25%

CMHC is reinitiating the Insured Mortgage Purchase Program with $50 billion of authority to purchase securitized mortgages and is expanding its conventional securitization programs (including expending eligibility, although details are not yet announced)
Review of large and medium size financial institutions' business continuity plans and discussions with FIs management

Creation of the  Commercial Paper Purchase Program (CPPP), which will conduct primary and secondary  market purchases of CP, including asset-backed CP, issued by Canadian firms, municipalities and provincial agencies with an outstanding CP program
7-day reverse repo rate, cut 50bp, to 3.75%
Mortgage financing companies, factoring and leasing companies mandated to give a six-month grace period to any client who asks.
NBE to avail 15 Billion Birr liquidity facility to private banks which is aimed at providing debt relief  to clients and additional loans

Banks to avail foreign currency for importers primarily importing goods and input materials for the prevention of Covid-19 (the fx request of these importers will get priority over other fx requests).
BCBS extends by one year on the date of implementation of BIII reviewed rules to compute capital ratio requirements, leverage ratio and disclosure requirements
IAIS Executive Committee takes steps to address impact of COVID-19  on the insurance sector
IFRS Guidance on how the pandemic affects accounting for ECL, which highlighted that IFRS9 does not provide a mechanistic approach.
Evaluation on how German banks would uphold their business continuity management.
Up to 12 months principal deferments  by many lenders
75 basis points cut in repo.The reverse repo rate cut by 90 basis points to 4 percent.
A three month moratorium is announced on payment of installments of loans outstanding on March 1, 2020.

CBI has instructed banks to reschedule loan repayments which are due in March, April and May by 3 months (without any additional service charge or interest payments). The directive covers loans to a designated list of businesses especially SMEs (including hotels, restaurants and transportation sector) and all individuals with interest-free loans (normally provided to vulnerable households).

Support to SMEs:  (i) additional financing line of 300 TND; (ii) payment by the State of the difference between the interest rate on investment loans and the TMM, for up to 3 points, (iii) Investment fund of 500 MTND (with a first closing at 100 MTND) to be seeded by CDC; to finance strategic companies, (iv)  ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩback-upÔøΩÔøΩ? Fund of 100 MTND, to be seeded by CDC, to re-acquire the interests of investment funds in companies active in strategic fields and which are in difficulty Guarantee mechanism (Fund of 500 MTD) for the benefit of the tourism sector to guarantee new credits of operations and management which will be granted by the banking sector before December 31, 2020 on a duration of 7 years including two years of grace. Also covers transportation and cultural sectors.

Second-round economic stimulus package (PRIHATIN). An additional RM55 billion is in the form of guarantees, The PRIHATIN economic stimulus package is designed with the aim of addressing three broad objectives (i) protecting citizens, (ii) supporting businesses, especially small and medium sized enterprises (SMEs), and (iii) strengthening the economy.
BS remains open during the State of Emergency period to facilitate the needs of the banks to ensure that there is enough currency available to meet the demand of the general public
Regular FX swap auctions at fixed swap points announced and volumes to not need to match, allowing the NBS to provide additional liquidity at favorable rates (0.85% for dinars, 0% for EUR).

Details of the measure: Banco de EspaÃ±a applies the ECB recommendation on dividend distribution to the credit institutions under its supervision.

Former Savings Banks (Cajas - now members of CECA) are waiving the fees for the withdrawal of money in their ATM network.
Moratorium on mortgage repayments as well as on utility bills for families whose incomes have been hit by the crisis, which will also be applicable to SMEs and self-employed in difficulty.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Limiting access to cash, inducing the CBT to push for increased reliance on credit card usage through a free distribution to all clients, with the ultimate aim of increasing online payments.

Companies and individuals who are debtors of financial institutions will have an additional 90 days to update the information required by these institutions whenever the expiration of said information occurs during the months of March to July 2020. Details of the measure: Directing new credit to the health services sector, as well as for SMEs and startups.
Requiring Banks to reallocate social responsibility funds to support the health services sector, and to efforts contributing to limiting the spread of the pandemic.

Payments and money transfers services have been deemed essential and may remain open.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Relaxing limit of foreign currency outward remittance for Bangladeshi nationals unable to travel back through credit cards and exchange houses.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Loan (only short term) request from Tourism and Transportation sectors (those borrowers who are regular in repayments as of Q2FY2020) and from traders of Medical items is to be processed within 5 business days.

No penalty imposed for not complying with the regulatory and supervisory ratios for Q3FY2020 (mid-April)

In case of dispute between a client and a financial institution, the BCC will be the arbitrator. The mechanism was initially planned to be in place from April 2020 to August 2020, but was eventually extended to December 31, 2020.

Level 3 policy measures: Relief measures on customer identification (e.g. simplified cdd even in case of non-face-to-face relationships)
Details of the measure: Any requirement for the presentation of valid identification card (ID) shall be relaxed, including for electronic or online customer onboarding and transactions, subject to the following conditions: (a) The amount of transactions shall not exceed P50,000.00 per day;  (b) The customer is either a permanent or temporary resident or who conducts business in the area which has been declared to be under ECQ/CQ by the competent authority;  (c) The customer shall submit certification, either in hard copy or electronic form, which need not be notarized, that he/she has no valid ID; and  (d) The customer's account activities shall be subject to ongoing monitoring by the BSFI to identify potential abuse of the relaxed requirement and any suspicious transactions shall be reported to the Anti-Money Laundering Council within the prescribed period.
MAS adopted a 0% per annum rate of appreciation of the policy band and reduced the mid-point to the prevailing level of the S$NEER. There will be no change to the width of the policy band.

The Bank of Albania decided to relax its monetary policy by: reducing the policy rate from 1.0% to 0.5%.

Agricultural companies can apply for a guarantee (up to EUR 50m), a working capital loan (up to EUR 100m) or land capital loan (up to EUR 50m).

Refinancing operations (similar to ECB's TLTRO program) to increase lending to non-financial sector and support non-financial corporations' liquidity.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Corporate financing (PLN 73.2bn in total, including PLN 4.9bn in spending and PLN 68.3bn in liquidity measures). To support non-financial corporations, government plans to increase funding available to the Polish Development Fund (PFR), Export Credit Insurance Corporation (KUKE), Subsidy Fund operated by the Polish Development Bank (BGK) ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ institutions which provide guarantees, loans, trade insurances, equity and subsidies. -  Extending the BGK's de minimis guarantee program for SME to increase the level of guarantees for loans granted by the banking sector from 60% to 80%. -  The Security and Growth Program operated by the PFR is expected to create possibility for companies to obtain financing in the form of equity or through bond issuance funded by PFR Investments. -  BGK is set to subsidize interest repayments for the enterprise sector through the Subsidy Fund. -  KUKE is set to increase the size of commercial turnover insurances of domestic and cross-border trade. Range of other measures is expected to be introduced to protect business environment in Poland: -  Industrial Development Agency (ARP) is set to support refinancing of leasing agreements of distressed companies in transportation sector. -  Labor Fund is expected to provide up to 500,000 loans of PLN 5000 to micro enterprises for a period of 6 months. -  Social Security payments are to be postponed or paid in installments without any additional charges/penalties. -  Deadlines for carrying out and completing public procurement are to be extended without any penalties. -  Working capital credits for non-financial companies to be automatically prolonged based on ratings calculated using financial information from the end of 2019 (KNF to introduce appropriate regulation). -  Second chance policy ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ support for SMEs undergoing reorganization.
