Financial cooperatives requested by the supervisor to activate business continuity plans

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Credit facilities for companies for productive credit to the agricultural sectors, construction, services, tourism, manufacturing industry, home acquisition, trade, electricity, gas, water, health services, transport, storage and communications.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Dynamic transactions electronic money, early payment to SMEs, purchases of the Minimum State of 25% of Goods and Services, simplification of procedures for my MYPE account, chains for direct marketing.

Level 3 policy measures: Prioritize or review critical supervisory actions
Details of the measure: BaFin and Deutsche Bundesbank postponed the stress test for less-significant institutions planned for 2021 to 2022.
Banco de Guatemala lowered policy rate by 50 bp to 2.25 percent
Junta Monetaria has temporarily eased (180-day period) credit risk management regulations to enable loan restructuring, loan payments moratorium, and the use of generic provisions.

BCH suspended issuance of one-day BCH bills, resulting in liquidity increase of L10,600 mn (1.6 percent of GDP)ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩthis adds to the projected increase in liquidity of about L7,500 mn (1.2 percent of GDP) in 2020 resulting from the previously announced elimination of obligatory investments in the central bank.
Banco Central de Honduras has reduced policy rate to 4.5% BCH has reduced interest rate on permanent facilitites to 5.5% (TPM +1%)

The government issued a decree mandating all supervised financial institutions to provide temporary debt service relief to companies and individuals whose incomes have been affected by the crisis. Debt service of affected sectors will be suspended until end-June, without penalties or impact on credit classification.  The government announced a 3-month moratorium on service of bank loans financed by the second tier development bank Banhprovi (covering about 5 percent of total bank credit to the private sector), as well as additional financing for Banhprovi's housing program for the middle class (L200 mn, about $8 mn).
The rate for foreign currency deposit window was cut by 60 bps.
Central Bank of Nicaragua (CBN) reduced its repo reference rate, and the 1-day and 7-day repo window rate by 75 bps
Banking Superintendence allowed the use of accumulated dynamic provisioning (about US$1.3 bn) to absorb impact of credit losses.
Banking Superintendence allowed voluntary loan restructuring: adjust existing loan conditions, grant grace periods, reduce interest rates, and eliminate some fees.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: K600 million credit line to support businesses and individuals
Total release of the reserve requirements for local and foreign currencies releasing the equivalent to USD 740 million.
Establishment of a liquidity window for FIs for up to 12 months equivalent to USD 760 million
Interest rate cut 100 bps to 2.25%.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Line of credit from BNF (Development Bank) for approx USD 15 million - Art 18 of the Ley NÔøΩ 6524/2020  (ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩDeclara Estado de Emergencia en todo el territorio de la RepÃºblica del Paraguay ante la pandemia declarada por la OrganizaciÔøΩ_n Mundial de la Salud del COVID-19 o Coronavirus y se establecen medidas administrativas, fiscales y financierasÔøΩÔøΩ?) allows this fund to also include respurces p[rovided by IFIs. Line of credit from AFD (Development Bank) to support MSMEs for approx USD 60 million with a 2-year grace period

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Relaxing NPL classificaiton and facilitating loan refinancing and restructuring
The Securities and Exchange Commission issued a notice to Finance and Lending Companies to implement a minimum of a 30-day grace period for the payment of all loans

The Government approved the rules for the application of provisions on facilities for loans granted by  credit institutions and non-bank financial institutions, by setting out the conditions under which creditors approve applications, the deferral period and the extension period for deferred loans, and in the case of mortgage loans, the way in which interest is postponed and guaranteed

ANDE will increase the fund used to provide collaterals, allowing financial institutions to give credits for up to US$ 2500m (they did not mention what the assumed leverage is). In addition, the institution will implement a new subsidized line of working capital credit for small and medium-size companies affected by the situation, and it will postpone all repayments of older credits for one month
The excess deposit reserve rate is reduced from 0.72% to 0.35%

To ensure that adequate foreign reserves can be maintained, RBF has tightened the exchange control policy requirements, with changes including reduction in delegated limits and suspension of certain facilities aiming to protect Fiji's BOP
Preserving capital should be the insurers' priority, and insurers should stop paying dividends until October 1.

The BCBS issues guidance on expected credit loss (ECL) accounting to ensure that banks reflect the risk-reducing effect of the exceptional measures when calculating their capital requirements. It also sets out the amended transitional arrangements for the regulatory capital treatment of ECL accounting, which will provide jurisdictions with greater flexibility in how to phase in the impact of ECL on regulatory capital.
Second Targeted Long Term Repo Operation (TLTRO), with tenor of 3 years and amount of INR 250 billion on April 03, 2020.
On April 3, 2020, the NBM further decreased the required reserve ratio for deposits in local currency from  38.5% to 34%.

Parliament approved a law that guarantees the possibility for affected citizens and SMEs to receive deferrals of loan payments for up to six months. Banks are allowed not to classify such loans as restructured for loss provisioning purposes until September 30, 2020.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Banks are allowed not to classify such loans as restructured for loss provisioning purposes until September 30, 2020.
Loan Deferrals will not impact credit history

The Monetary Board of the Central Bank of Sri Lanka, on 03 April 2020, decided to reduce the Standing Deposit Facility Rate (SDFR) and the Standing Lending Facility Rate (SLFR)  of  the  Central  Bank  by 25 basis  points  to  6.00 per  cent  and 7.00 per  cent, respectively, effective from the  close  of  business  on  03  April 2020.

BOT will halve the rate of contribution from financial institutions to the Financial Institutions Developmenf Fund (FIDF) from 0.46% of deposit base to 0.23% per annum for two years to ease the loan interest burden on businesses and households.
Per new Presidnetial Decree, the CBU will introduce a special mechanism for providing liquidity to  commercial banks with a term of up to 3 years in the amount of up to 2 trillion soums.
Per new Presidnetial Decree, the volume of loans to be restructured going forward will be 7 trln for  corporates and 4.7 trln for individuals.

A targerted medium-term refinancing facility has been established with an initial amt. of K10 billion to provide  medium term liquidity. The amt. will be reviewed as conditions warrant. It is a 3-5 year facility that will be available to eligible financial service providers to enable them to restructure or refinancing qualifying facilities or on-lend to eligible clients
Scaled up open market operations to provide short-term liquidity support to commercial banks on more  flexible terms than those obtaining before the COVID-19 outbreak

Level 3 policy measures: Ensure minimal functionality in the primary and secondary markets
Details of the measure: Revised rules governing the operations of the Interbank foreign exchange market to support its smooth functioning, strengthen market discipline and provide a mechanism for addressing heightened volatility in the exchange rate in stress periods.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Revised loan classification and provisioning rules through issuance of new directives as the replacement  to statutory instrument no. 142 of 1996, which in the process of being revoked

Extended the transitional arrangement provided for FSPs from 3-year transitional period (2018-2022) to  amortise the 'Day 1 impact of the IFRS 9' for capital adequacy purposes, for a further 2 year period (up to 31st Dec 2022)
Allowed eligible NBFIs to henceforth partially use capital instruments that would not ordinarily quality  as common equity Tier  1 and Tier 2 capital, for purposes of computing regulatory capital
Urging commercial banks to remove transfer fees on the bank a/c to e-wallet transactions from an initial  period of 3 months and to reduce the merchant discount rate (MDR)

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Implement business continuity protocols that will ensure that systemically important payment systems and  FMIs remain available

As per interim directive of the central bank, from April 5 to April 9, the branches of commercial banks will remain open for transaction from 10.00AM ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ 1.00 PM. During this period, customers will have both withdrawal and deposit facilities through Cash/Cheque, issuance of DD or Pay-order, BEFTN, Treasury Chalan and other regular payment services. The clearing instruments need to be placed before 11.30 AM and 12.00 PM and Return Cut-Off Time will be 12.30 pm and 1.30 pm respectively for High Value and Regular Value instruments.

IRDAI granted additional grace period of 30 days for life insurance policies whose premiums fall due in March and April 2020 and also allowed life insurers to offer settlement options in respect of unit linked policies maturing up to 31st May 2020 to protect the interests of policyholders.

The Securities and Exchange Commission of Pakistan (SECP) on Wednesday allowed all lending. Non-Bank Finance Companies (NBFCs) including Non-Bank Microfinance Companies (NBMFCs) to defer repayment of principal loans by their borrowers for one year

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Opened working capital lines to micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) through the Bank for Investment and Foreign Trade (BICE). The total allocation was ARS 1 billion, and loans have a fixed annual rate of 19% for companies with a guarantee from the Reciprocal Guarantee Societies (SGR), and a term of up to 12 months.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Offered loans at a fix rate of 12% and non-refundable contributions to companies, small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), cooperatives, and research and development instituions that contribute to the COVID-19 health emergency. Supported by the National Productive Development Fund (FONDEP), the total amount of finance assistance was worth ARS 2.25 billion: ARS 2 billion in fixed-rate loans wtih varying maturities, and ARS 250 million in non-reimbursable contributions.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: BDT300 billion package for working capital finance in which government will pay 4.5 % and borrower will pay 4.5% interest rate. BDT 200 billion package for SME finance in which government will pay 5% and borrower will pay 4% interest rate. BDT 50 billion for Pre-shipment refinance scheme at 7% interest rate.
Postponed the roll-out of its new life insurance regulations by six months.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: The Bank of Palestine Group has launched a campaign whereby every time customers use the mobile banking application "Banke" one ILS is donated by the bank towards the government's efforts to combat the pandemic. To encourage customers to use the App a daily prize is given to customers to stay home and use the app and avoid going out.
Liquidity facility of $179m to purchase government bonds held by companies (MSMEs and large companies in the productive sector).

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Bangladesh Bank requested all mobile financial service (MFS) providers to support workers with no-fee account opening through April 20 to support the implementation of stimulus package measures (particularly payment of salaries to formal sector workers).

Increased the maximum amount of Time Deposits with Special Guarantee (DPGE) for each person against the same financial institution associated with the FGC, or against all associated institutions of the same financial conglomerate, to R $ 40 million from R $ 20 million

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: Temporarily prohibited the distribution of results and the increase in the remuneration of managers of financial institutions and other institutions authorized to operate by the Central Bank

Brazil re-introduced the DPGE (initially used in the aftermath of the Global Financial Crisis) which are special deposits guaranteed up to BRL 40MM (USD 16MM). Such deposits pay specific contributions to the deposit insurance fund (0.03% per month, or 0.02% if the bank offers guarantees to the deposit insurer)), should be in the minimum amount of BRL 1MM and have a term between 12 and 24 months. A single institution cannot issue more than BRL 1Bn in DPGE.
Recapitalization of the National Guarantee Fund for guarantees of different sectors of the economy with implicit focus on micro, small and medium-sized enterprises.

ICCR Report on the treatment of credit data in credit information systems in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic aimed at safeguarding the integrity of credit reporting systems and protecting borrowers during the crisis.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Introduced a Quick Loan Program (Kfw-Schnellkredit) for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The program was run by the government-owned promotional bank KfW. Loans are available to SMEs with over 10 employees, active on the market since at least January 1, 2019. Eligible businesses can obtain loans at a maximum of EUR 800,000 for firms with over 50 employees, and EUR 500,000 for firms with up to 50 employees.
Online submission of IDs is possible for state promotional grants, amongst other measures.
As from April 6, revised auction calendar. More frequent auctions of 3 and 5Y fixed rate instruments.
Bank of Israel cuts interest rate to 0.1%
NBK decreased the policy rate by 250bps from 12 percent to 9.5 percent.
Allow a grace period for loan instalment payments starting from 16 March 2020 until 30 April 2020, and depending on the developments of the situation this period may be extended.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: CBK, through its Credit Registry measures, has undertaken all appropriate legal measures to prevent credit ratings and to not classify them as non-performing loans in the Credit Registry.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: CBK, through its Credit Registry measures, has undertaken all appropriate legal measures to not require additional provisions.
During this period, no deterioration measure of the credit rating will be applied to the borrower.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: The Government will be abolishing the 2% interest rate for the RM500mil Micro Credit Scheme under Bank Simpanan Nasional. The Micro Credit Scheme for micro-SMEs is also extended to loan under TEKUN Nasional with a maximum borrowing of RM10,000 per SME at 0% interest. Applicants can only choose from one of these schemes - either under Bank Simpanan Nasional or TEKUN Nasional.

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: NBM (1) recommended the banks to refrain from distributing dividends to shareholders and other forms   of capital distribution, at least until 30 September 2020

NBM  (2) approved measures to relax the requirements for capital buffers: (a) the banks are allowed  to use temporarily (the date to be communicated) the capital conservation buffer previously established, (b) the preserved capital can be used to absorb eventual worsening of the loan portfolio quality and support the financing of the business environment and of the population.

NBM: Banks were encouraged to apply appropriate policies for recognition and coverage of  non-performing exposures and carry out sound capital and liquidity planning, alongside robust risk management.

Increase limits (transaction wise, daily, monthly) for non-face-to-face translations (mobile money, internet banking). Promoting digital channels (online document submission). Fee-free online transactions within country for 4 months. Telephone/email requests for e/online transactions to be promoted for expanding the e-transactions. All the things to be handled by managing the risks.
Time extension for supervisory reporting
Guaranteed the possibility deferral payments on loans for up to six months for citizens/SMEs in difficult economic situations related to the coronavirus pandemic.

Level 3 policy measures: Lower risks weights for credit with public guarantees
Details of the measure: Government's risk-share raised to 90% for EFS Trade Loan, SME Working Capital Loan and Temporary Bridging Loan programme

The new Bill was presented to the Parliament on 6 April and contains the following insolvency related measures: -  A contracting party would be barred from taking legal actions (which include court and insolvency proceedings) against a non-performing party.  The types of contract covered would include a lease and a supply contract. -  The threshold for individual bankruptcy would increase from SG$15,000 to SG$60,000 whereas for winding up of companies would increase from SG$10,000 to SG$100,000. -  The cap to qualify for Debt Repayment Scheme will be raised from $100,000 to $250,000. -  The response time for statutory demand will be lengthened from 21 days to 6 months. Directors would be relieved from insolvent trading obligations but would still remain liable criminally for fraudulent trading .

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: Capital conservation must take priority over any distribution of dividends on ordinary shares and the payment of cash bonuses to executive officers and material risk takers
South African Reserve Bank lowered Pillar 2A capital buffer to zero. They also provided minimum capital conservation buffer banks should maintain.
South African Reserve Bank lowered the liquidity coverage ratio to 80% from 100% for the duration of the crisis.
South African Reserve Bank announced it has provided guidance to the banking industry on how IFRS 9  could be implemented during this period of volatility and stress.
FSC said it will work to help ease regulatory burdens stemming from liquidity coverage ratio and loan-to-deposit ratio requirements.

Financial Institutions (FIs) are urged to take precautionary measures against cyber criminals and hackers looking to take advantage of the current situation prevailing within the country. The corona virus (COVID-19) outbreak has prompted individuals and institutions to rely heavily on remote banking services offered by Financial Institutions that are engaging a limited staff to carry out banking and other related operations. - 	Due to the prevailing curfew situation and implementation of BCP within the FIU/CBSL all onsite/follow-up supervision has been suspended until further notice
Bank of Uganda (BoU) has in the April 2020 Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) meeting reduced the Central Bank Rate (CBR) by 1 percentage point to 8 percent.
Provide liquidity to commercial banks for a longer period through issuance of reverse REPOs of up to 60 days at the CBR, with opportunity to roll over.

Purchase Treasury Bonds held by Microfinance Deposit taking Institutions (MDIs) and Credit Institutions (CIs) in order to ease their liquidity distress whenever it arises. MDIs and CIs that do not hold Treasury bills or bonds in their asset holdings will be provided with liquidity secured by their holdings of unencumbered Fixed Deposits or Placements with other SFIs

Grant exceptional permission to SFIs to restructure loans of corporate and individual customers including a moratorium on loan repayment for borrowers that have been affected by the pandemic, on a case by case basis at the discretion of the SFIs for up to 12 months, effective April 1st, 2020.

Beginning in the second quarter 2020 and until the end of the year, a banking organization that has a leverage ratio of 8 percent or greater and meets certain other criteria may elect to use the community bank leverage ratio framework. Community banking organizations will have until January 1, 2022, before the community bank leverage ratio requirement is re-established at greater than 9 percent

Established the Paycheck Protection Program Liquidity Facility (PPPLF) that will extend credit to eligible financial institutions that originate PPP loans, taking the loans as collateral at face value

The CBU has eased minimum reserve requirements, by allowing 35% (instead of previous 25%)  of the amount of minimum required reserves to be used flexibly during the month, starting April 1. This proportion may further be increased in future, however reserve requirement ratios have not been changed.

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: Reached out to Authorized Deposit-taking institutions (ADIs) to outline expectations regarding limit discretionary capital distributions and dividends in the months ahead, to ensure that they instead use buffers and maintain capacity to continue to lend

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Export Development Fund enhanced to USD5 billion from USD 3 billion. CB will charge 1% to banks and banks will charge 2%. Workers in export industries can open mobile financial service account or bank account without any charge to receive benefits of stimulus fund.
Lowered the CTR threshold from Nu. 500,000 to Nu. 250,000.00.
Reporting Entities to submit daily CTR
Temporary suspension of credit ratings - The actual status information shall only be reported for NBE's regulatory purpose (information only). For the Bureau purpose exemption is exerted.
AMF clarified accounting standards for calculation of expected credit losses in light of recent  announcements from ESMA, EBA, and IASB.

The Central Bank of Honduras (BCH) on Tuesday announced the implementation of monetary policy measures that would free the financial system some $465.5 million, seeking to mitigate the impact on the economy of the coronavirus outbreak. BCH President announced a reduction in the banking's mandatory national currency investments from 3% to 0%, which would release about $263 million, and the suspension of the securities auction in the second quarter of the year, which would free up $202 million to the financial system.
In addition, there was a decrease in the interest rate of the BCH credit to the financial system at a day from 5.5% to 5% and from 2 to 14 days from 6.25% to 5.50%
HKMA issued a letter on AML/CFT measures during COVID19.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: CB opened fixed-rate (maximum annual interest of 2.5%) funds to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) under the Growth Credit Program Hair (FGS Hair). The total size of GFS Hair was set at HUF 1.5 trillion. Minimum loan sizes are HUF 1 million, and ma

CB announced government securities purchase program in the secondary market to restore the stable liquidity of the market. CB also relaunches its mortgage bond program to improve the long-term supply of funding to the banking sector.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: CB launched the Funding for Growth Scheme Go! on 20 April 2020, raising the current allocation amount by HUF 1,000 billion. Including HUF 500 billion undrawn under the FGSÔøΩÔøΩfix, the MNB will make available up to HUF 1,500 billion of cheap and stable source of lending to the SME sector under the FGS Go! The new Scheme is identical to the earlier phases of the FGS in terms of its key parameters and the method of implementation. MNB will continue to provide refinancing loans to credit institutions at a zero interest rate, and interest to be paid by SMEs will continue to be maximum 2.5 percent.

Revised framework for CB corporate bond purchase program. Total amount remains unchanged, HUF 450 billion. Single issuer limit increased from HUF 20 billion to 50 billion. Eligible maturities increased from 10 years to 20 years.

CBJ announced a challenge fund to encourage licensed mPSPs and merchants in Jordan to accept digital payments through the JoMoPay switch. This challenge fund will help mPSPs to increase merchant acceptance of mobile payments. CBJ is inviting mPSPs (minimum 2 mPSPs) to apply for this fund targeted to acquire merchants in order to be able to present and accept payments digitally, furthermore, the fund will offer merchants financial incentives to accept mobile money payments.
Relaxation of CDD document requirements.
The BSP announced that the minimum liquidity ratio (MLR) for stand-alone thrift banks, rural banks and cooperative banks was reduced from 20% to 16%.

Government to carry 3 months of loan repayments for all small businesses under its Government Guarantee Schemes administered by the Samoa Business Hub;  Government to provide interest relief for all loans with the Development Bank for 2months.

To support banks' lending activities, MAS will adjust the Net Stable Funding Ratio requirement. The amount of stable funding that banks must maintain for loans to individuals and businesses that are maturing in less than six months will be halved from 50% to 25%. The relief will apply until 30 September 2021, and may be extended if necessary.
Allow FIs to take into account the government's fiscal assistance and banks' relief  measures in setting more realistic accounting loan loss allowances.

Level 3 policy measures: Prioritize or review critical supervisory actions
Details of the measure: Defer FIs' implementation of the final set of Basel III reforms, margin requirements  for non-centrally cleared derivatives, and other new regulations and policies, to ease FIs' operational burden;

Level 3 policy measures: Reduce non-essential regulatory reporting requirements for banks
Details of the measure: Provide FIs more latitude on submission timelines for regulatory reports and defer non-urgent industry projects.

Level 3 policy measures: Prioritize or review critical supervisory actions
Details of the measure: Suspend regular onsite inspections and supervisory visits till further notice.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in capital requirement (definition of capital, car, risk weights)
Details of the measure: South African Reserve Bank is temporarily amending Directive 7 of 2015 for loans restructured as a  result of the  impact of COVID-19 to not attract a higher capital charge for the duration of the crisis.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Signed a business agreement with NH Nonghyup Bank to strengthen cooperation in supporting SMEs, providing 2 trillion won by the end of the year through small business secondary loans, small business policy funds, special loans for local businesses, and special financial support for small tourism businesses

Commercial banks and specialised financial institutions will also give SMEs with a credit line not more than 100 million baht each a six-month debt moratorium on both principalÔøΩÔøΩand interest. To be eligible, these SME loans should not fall under non-performing loans by the recipient companies as of December 31, 2019.

500 billion baht (US$15 billion) in funding for commercial banks to lend to SMEs. Each SME can borrow up to 500 million baht (US$15 million) at an annual interest rate of 2%. For the first six months, however, the interest rate will be at 0%, which will be absorbed by the government.

Issued a revised statement clarifying the interaction between the interagency statement issued on March 22, 2020, and the temporary relief provided by Section 4013 of the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act, which was signed into law on March 27, 2020
SEC said that financial institutions that take advantage of the CARES Act provision that allows the deferral of implementation of two GAAP standards will not be in violation of GAAP.
New credit guarantee line (Siga Emergencia) expands coverage ratios up to 80 percent for firms that have been affected by COVID-19 but who do not have sufficient guarantees to support credit needs.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Bank of Albania, along with commercial banks, have decided to waive fees for interbank electronic credit transfers for end users. Further, Bank of Albania, as the operator of the RTGS and ACH, have decided to waive transaction fees for member commercial banks for clearing/settlement via the ACH and RTGS.

EUR 100M 2-year bond issuance in the domestic market to cover hard currency cash need of the government. Additional local currency (ALL) government securities auctions in new tenors (3-month and 6-month) announced for Q2 2020.

Level 3 policy measures: Prioritize or review critical supervisory actions
Details of the measure: Temporarily suspending issuing new banking licences for at least six months in response to the economic uncertainty created by COVID-19.
Susep joined a central bank-developed blockchain platform for the instant exchange of information of regulated companies with the monetary authority and market regulator CVM.

The EC announced that it has approved a Bulgarian BGN 500m (EUR 255m) public guarantee scheme to  support SMEs in the context of the coronavirus outbreak. The scheme was approved under the temporary State aid rules.

The Rural Development Foundation approved the terms of financial measures (EUR 200m) for rural  entrepreneurs and businesses who face difficulties related to the coronavirus. Loan guarantees were available to both SMEs and large enterprises.

Level 3 policy measures: Reduce non-essential regulatory reporting requirements for banks
Details of the measure: BCBS will not collect Basel III monitoring data for the end June 2020 reporting date to increase operational capacity for banks.
IOSCO has reprioritized its work program to focus on the direct effects of COVID-19 on market-based finance.

In respect of term loans, insurers are permitted to grant a moratorium of   months towards payment of instalments falling due between 1st March, 2020 and 31st May, 2020. The repayment schedule for such loans and also the residual tenor, will be shifted across the board by three months subsequent to the moratorium period.
BI reached a repurchase agreement (repo) worth US$60 billion with the U.S. Fed to boost dollar liquidity supply following a fall in Indonesia's foreign exchange reserves in March
The FSA and the BOJ have agreed to develop measures to temporarily exclude central bank deposits  from the leverage ratio exposure measure
CNBV will grant temporary regulatory flexibility until March 31, 2021 so that banks can use their capital buffers.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: CNBV said it will delay the implementation of IFRS9 to January 1, 2022.
CNBV announced a delay in the implementation of regulatory standards including Business Indicator Method and TLAC requirements.

Allowing institutions to register as liquid assets those that have been eligible in such capacity until February 28 for compliance with Liquidity Coverage Ratio (CCL) for a period of six months and may be extended for a maximum period up to six additional months
The BSP announced Reclassification of Debt Securities Measured at Fair Value to the Amortized Cost Category
Cuts on benchmark rate to 0.5 percent.
Instructions to file STRs (paper-based submissions).

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: MAS announced a S$125 million support package to sustain and strengthen capabilities in the financial services and FinTech sectors amid the current economic slump. The support package will help to position financial institutions and FinTech firms for stronger growth when the threat of COVID-19 recedes and economic activity normalises.

Allowing vulnerable debtors whose income levels have fallen due to COVID 19 that have difficulties servicing household debts and are facing a risk of debt overdue may use a 6 to 12-month deferment of principal payment

Allowing multiple debt holders whose income levels have fallen due to COVID 19, that have difficulties servicing debts and are facing a risk of debt overdue may use debt adjustment programs offered by the Credit Counseling & Recovery Service (CCRS). The CCRS debt adjustment programs offer up to one year of deferment of principal payment for at risk debtors including short term debtors of less than three months) as well as debt reduction for long term debtors. The support will be provided by about 5 ,800 financial institutions and loan companies in agreement with the CCRS until the end of this year. It may be extended thereafter if it becomes necessary.

Level 3 policy measures: Use of recovery and resolution tools
Details of the measure: Established KRW2 trillion facility at the Korea Asset Management Corporation , which will be used to purchase long term personal debts to help alleviate long term debt burdens of delinquent debtors and protect them from the possibility of being exposed to excessive debt collection attempts

Improved rules and procedures on exemption for misconduct in financial services including applications of exemptions such as disaster and innovation, no intent or gross negligence rule, improving fairness in procedures, encouraging internal measures by financial companies, creating cooperation between regulators and banks, and more use of on-site measures, no-action letters and consulting services for minor wrongdoing or breach of rules

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: For start-ups and venture companies, 2.2 trillion won (US$1.8 billion) will be given through low-rate loans.

36 trillion won (29.5 billion U.S. dollars) will be offered for trade finance, including 30 trillion won (24.6 billion U.S. dollars) to extend the maturity of export insurance and guarantee, 5.5 trillion won (4.5 billion U.S. dollars) for fresh trade finance and 1 trillion won (820 million U.S. dollars) for emergency liquidity.
Transfer of money through digital channels (mobile payments) for vulnerable households.
Lenders may give a moratorium of up to 3 months from April 2020 on loan instalments, and on interest accrued.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Propose adjustments on loan provisioning to enable institutions and clients to adhere to the changed situation due to COVID -19
Lenders may accrue interest on outstanding loans during moratorium period. Calculated accrued interest for the moratorium  period should not exceed interest rate agreed in the original agreement.
Providing temporary, conditional exemptive relief for business development companies (BDCs) to enable them to make additional investments in small and medium-sized businesses

Level 3 policy measures: Ensure public risk disclosures by banks
Details of the measure: SEC issued a statement on the importance of robust disclosures and reporting during COVID-19.

Level 3 policy measures: Prioritize or review critical supervisory actions
Details of the measure: Suspension of on-site examinations Until June 2020.  On-site spot checks will be done as needed

Level 3 policy measures: Lower risks weights for credit with public guarantees
Details of the measure: Modified capital rules to neutralize the regulatory capital effects of participating in the Federal Reserve's PPP facility because there is no credit or market risk in association with PPP loans pledged to the facility

Level 3 policy measures: Lower risks weights for credit with public guarantees
Details of the measure: FRB, FDIC, and OCC announced an interim final rule to encourage lending through the Small Business  Administration's Paycheck Protection Program (PPP), clarifying that a zero percent risk weight applies to loans covered by the PPP for capital purposes.

The BNB affirmed a draft order of postponing and settling loan repayments to banks and their subsidiaries, proposed by the Association of Banks in Bulgaria. The affirmed document acts as a private moratorium in accordance with the EBA's Guidelines on Legislative and Non-legislative Moratoria on Loan Repayments Applied in the Light of the COVID-19 Crisis (EBA/GL/2020/02). Commercial banks who have accepted the established order of postponing loan repayments, will make public the ways in which they will ease the burden on their obligors. The private moratorium allows for rescheduling of the capital and interest payments of loans without any changes to the key parameters of the loan agreement, such as interest rates. Loan repayments may be postponed for up to six months during the period ending on December 31, 2020. Subject to postponement are loans that as at March 1, 2020 were serviced regularly or overdue by no more than 90 days. Three standardized mechanisms are envisaged: postponement of the capital and interest payments of loans by up to six months; postponement of the capital payments by up to six months; freedom for obligors with revolving loans to use a fixed loan limit completely or partially at a time of their choosing. A given mechanism is to be chosen through mutual agreement between the banks and their clients

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Allowing small business (SME) owners to apply for support from the Canada Emergency Business Account through their banks and credit unions, offering eligible small business and non-profit organizations can get interest-free loans of up to $40,000. If the loan is repaid by December 31, 2022, 25% of it will be forgiven, up to $10,000. This is part of the Business Credit Availability Program (BCAP).
The government is announcing the expansion of the  system of public support for credit insurance , which  will allow companies that have taken out such cover to continue to be covered .
BFM introduced an extraordinary refinancing scheme for banks to support MSMEs

BFM announced that banks can deduct the amount of restructured credits since March 2020 from the mandatory reserves.

State Bank of Pakistan (SBP) has introduced a temporary refinance scheme for payment of wages  and salaries to the workers and employees of the business    concerns. This Scheme is expected to ease cash flow constraints of the employers and thereby avoid layoffs

Reduced the Overnight Reverse Repurchase (RRP) Volume Offering beginning 8 April 2020 and will scale  down its daily overnight RRP volume offering as necessary depending on liquidity conditions to encourage counterparties to lend in the interbank market or re-channel their funds into other assets such as GS or loans

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Bank of Russia approved additional measures including allowing credit institutions to use assessments made as of 1 January 2020 for balance sheet assets and for loan loss provisioning on loans classified under Quality Category I and II.

It has been decided not to penalise credit history compilation sources if they miss deadlines for submitting information to credit history bureaus by 7 consecutive days or less (for as long as the high-alert mode is in place), or if they miss deadlines for reporting loan repayment holidays by no more than one month after the applicable federal law comes into force (for technical preparation purposes).

Broadened the range of securities eligible for open market operation transactions to include debentures  issued by three specialized banks (the Korea Development Bank, the Industrial Bank of Korea, and the Export-Import Bank of Korea) and MBSs issued by the Korea Housing Finance Corporation from April 14, 2020 to March 31, 2021
Broadened a eligible collateral for repo transactions to include bonds issued by the Korea Deposit Insurance Corporation

The Central Bank of Trinidad and Tobago (ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩCentral BankÔøΩÔøΩ?), the Trinidad and Tobago Securities and Exchange Commission (ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩTTSECÔøΩÔøΩ?) and the Financial Intelligence Unit of Trinidad and Tobago (ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩFIUÔøΩÔøΩ?) issued a Joint Regulatory Guidance on complying with AML/CFT verification requirements in light of COVID19 measures. They encourage the use of responsible electronic and digital customer on-boarding measures, while ensuring that risk-based controls are in place to mitigate ML/TF/PF risk. The Authorities recognize that reporting entities may need to temporarily amend their AML compliance programmes to implement alternative processes to verify customers' identity.

Moved up the opening date of the Term Funding Scheme for Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (TFSME). It was re-scheduled to open on April 15, 2020. TFSME allowed eligible banks and buidling societies to access four-year funding at rates close to the Bank Rate.

Specific guarantees for export insurance and credit insurance could reach EUR 12 billion.
Decided to allow repurchased Letras Financeiras (LFs) to be deducted from reserve requirements on time deposits

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Interest waived to loans (classified as performing as of 29 February 2020) and based on loan outstanding as of 10th April 2020; The cost of the interest waiver shared equally between the Government and the Financial Service Providers (FSP); No penal interest/late fee  charged during the deferment period.

Extension of gestation period for projects under construction for a period of three months (in addition to the maximum gestation period specified in the Prudential Regulations 2017); The waiver of interest accrued on loans under gestation shall be provided for three months (April to June 2020), which shall be based on the loan outstanding as of 10th April 2020; and the cost of the interest waiver will be shared equally between the Government and the FSPs.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Tourism related company/business can make available short term loans at concessional interest rate of 5% to meet operational expenses, in particular, to assist with payroll expenses to help retain employees; The total tenure of the loan shall be up to four years including the gestation period of three months; Interest rate shall be 5% to eligible borrowers and 4 % for intermediaries; and Security/Collateral: LTV-100% of collateral value.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Loans to Cottage & Small Industries (CSI):  The National CSI Development Bank shall provide the following loans for 3 months (from April to June 2020) to help the CSIs - (i) Microloans i.e. loans up to Nu.500,000 at an interest rate of 2 percent per annum to promote RNR/agriculture and rural activities; and (ii) Working Capital loan to CSIs at an interest rate of 4 percent per annum.

Decrease of one percentage point of the reserve requirement on the receivables whose current required  reserve percentage is 4.5% (CDT of less than 18 months), from 4.5% to 3.5%.

The event of restructuring of a credit facility arising from the direct or indirect impact of COVID-19 pandemic should not be treated as an adverse change in the credit risk profile of the borrower nor shall it be reported to a credit reference bureau.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: The event of restructuring of a credit facility arising from the direct or indirect impact of COVID-19 pandemic should not be treated as an adverse change in the credit risk profile of the borrower nor shall it be reported to a credit reference bureau.
Banks are instructed to provide special health insurnace for their emplyees working during COVID-19 lockdown for taking risks and grant facilities to the family in case of fatality.

Providing immediate, temporary relief to sponsors of federally regulated, defined benefit pension plans in the form of a moratorium, through the remainder of 2020, on solvency payment requirements for defined benefit plans

Introducing a Corporate Bond Purchase Program (CBPP) that will purchase eligible corporate bonds  in the secondary market and will be capped at $10 billion and will be restricted to senior secured and unsecured bonds originated by Canadian incorporated companies with a remaining maturity of up to 5 years and a minimum credit rating of BBB or equivalent. The program will remain active for a period of 12 months

Temporarily increasing the amount of treasury bills it acquires at auctions to up to 40 per cent. Introducing a Provincial Bond Purchase Program (PBPP) that will purchase eligible securities in the secondary market. Eligible securities are made up of Canadian-dollar denominated bonds issued by all provinces and fully-guaranteed provincial agencies with remaining terms-to-maturity up to ten years. The program size will be capped at $50 billion. The program will remain active for a period of 12 months

Chile's Central Bank agreed to increase the maximum investment limits on alternative assets for four of the country's five public pension funds as it seeks to contain the impact of the coronavirus health crisis on the economy.

Lowered the Required Reserve Ratio (RRR) by 0.5 percentage points for rural credit cooperatives, rural  commercial banks, rural  cooperative banks, village banks, as well as city commercial banks operating solely within provincial-level administrative regions, which is one of the two targeted reductions of 0.5 percentage points each
Lowered medium-term lending facility (MLF) by to 2.95%
Banks are temporarily requested to buy government bonds for an amount equal to a fraction of  their deposits.
The CBE announced a further cut to the discount rate of 100 basis points.
Extended the short-sale ban taken on March 17, 2020 through May 18, 2020. Terms and conditions of the ban remain the same.
FSB Report on international cooperation and coordination to address the financial stability implications of COVID-19 and policy measures taken.
Conduct another TLTRO operation for ÔøΩÔøΩ_ 25,000 crores on April 17, 2020
JFSA proposed to defer the implementation of the final two phases of the margin requirements  for non-centrally cleared derivatives.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Lowering/waiving the fees on instant payments using the CBR Fast Payment System

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Lowered the fees paid by online merchants for the acceptance of cards to encourage the use  of online purchases of essential goods and services;

Extended the ban on net short positions by one month. The ban applies to positions taken on Spanish  trading venues (Stock Exchanges, the Alternative Stock Market, and MAB). The ban takes effect from April 18, 2020, and will remain in force through May 18, 2020.

On April 15, CBSL also announces regulatory softening for the licensed financial companies (LFC) and leasing companies, namely (I) reduction of the liquid asset requirement for time deposits, savings deposits, and borrowings;

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Expanded the range of businesses that can receive government funding under the 5-7-9% Loan Program. The total size of the program is estimated at UAH 35 billion. The program now includes entrepreneurs who have a maximum annual income of UAH 100 million. The Ministry increased the maximum loan amount from UAH 1.5 million to UAH 3 million. The Minsitry expanded the scenarios for which it would extend loans to enrepreneurs.
The state permitted delay in repayments of whole loans provided for anti-crisi measures for up to nine months.
The CBU decreased the refinancing rate from 16% to 15%.

Level 3 policy measures: Prioritize or review critical supervisory actions
Details of the measure: Announced new commencement dates for six prudential and reporting standards that have been finalised  but are yet to fully come into effect
Extended the maximum period between contracting and settling the export exchange contract to 1,500 days

Adjusted the regulation of the Special Temporary Liquidity Line backed by Guaranteed Financial Bills  (LTEL-LFG), the maximum limit on loans taken by cooperative banks will become 100% of the Adjusted Shareholders' Equity calculated based on the Combined Balance Sheets of the Cooperative Systems. This seeks to give the same treatment to cooperative banks as that accorded to prudential banking conglomerates
Expanded its its liquidity operations (repo, final purchases and temporary liquidity support) to includ Solidarity Titles

Further strengthened the the National Guarantee Fund -FNG SA to MSMEs creating a Payroll Payment Guarantee for a value of $ 12 billion pesos and will have 90% coverage and will support disbursements made by financial entities to finance the value of monthly payrolls, for a total of $ 2,000 million pesos per company. The term may be up to 36 months and with a minimum grace period of 6 months. As well as creating a Guarantee for Working Capital for a value of $ 3 billion pesos. The amount to be guaranteed for this line will be up to $ 2.4 billion pesos per company, with 80% coverage, a term of up to 36 months and a minimum grace period of 4 months

The Monetary Board eliminated the collection of fees, commissions and charges, in any form or means, for inactivity in savings accounts, current accounts and of any other nature in the entities of financial intermediation.
Specifying delayed payment schedule following the 6 month deferment of payments announced on March 16

Worked with credit insurers to set up a protective shield worth EUR 30 billion, which will secure supplier  loans from German companies to credit insurers. The shield will guarantee compensation payments from credit insurers. Individual participants will offer 65% of premium income to the federal government in 2020, bear losses of up to EUR 500 million themselves, and assume default risks that go beyond the federal guarantee.

Level 3 policy measures: Ensure minimal functionality in the primary and secondary markets
Details of the measure: Amended trading hours for various RBI regulated markets announced on April 3 will continue to be  effective till the close of business on Thursday April 30, 2020
Bank of Mozambique reduced the policy rate in 150 bps to 11.25%.
Interest rate cut by 200 bps to 9%

Cut the interest rate on the BSP's overnight reverse repurchase (RRP) facility by 50 basis points (bps) to  2.75 percent, interest rates on the overnight lending and deposit facilities were reduced to 3.25 percent and 2.25 percent
Allowing loans granted to MSMEs to be counted as part of banks' compliance with reserve requirements (Circular No. 1083 dated 22 April 2020, as amended by Circular No. 1087 dated 27 May 2020).

The Bank of Russia recommends that credit institutions, for the period until 1 July 2020, enable citizens to conduct bank card operations after the expiration of their validity period, taking into account risk management systems used by credit institutions and bank card terms and conditions.

Raise with immediate effect the leverage limit for S-REITs from 45% to 50%, to provide S-REITs greater  flexibility to manage their capital structure amid the challenging environment created by the COVID-19 pandemic

Deferred to 1 January 2022 the implementation of a new minimum interest coverage ratio (ICR) requirement  proposed to require S-REITs to have a minimum ICR of 2.5 times before they are allowed to increase their leverage to beyond the prevailing 45% limit (up to 50%)

Required S-REITs to disclose their leverage ratios and interest coverage ratio (ICR) in annual reports  and interim financial results to provide investors with timely information about the financial position of S-REITs and the impact of higher leverage on their risk profiles
Permitting insurers that are experiencing conditions of financial unsoundness, SCR ratios below 100%  due only to the impact of COVID-19, to continue operations without exercising regulatory action

Asks insurers to consider whether it is necessary to temporarily suspend all discretionary dividend  distributions, including share buybacks and cash bonus payments to senior management in light of the likely increase in claims across different lines of business, including but not limited to business interruption, consumer credit, credit life, life risk and funeral policies

In the case where insurers make concessions that would increase the outstanding premiums caused by  the COVID-19 pandemic, it will not be included in the default risk SCR calculation, where such outstanding premiums would have attracted capital requirements in the ordinary course

Exemption of certain short-term insurers and independent intermediaries from regulation 5.2 of the  Regulations under the Short-term Insurance Act 53 of 1998. This exemption is also granted in an attempt to support broker sustainability; the insurer can still pay commission and the broker can accept the commission on those policies where the policyholders have opted for a premium relief and the premium has not been received by the insurer

Exemption for certain long-term insurers from regulations 3.5, 3.17 and 4.2(1) of the Regulations under  the Long-term Insurance Act 52 of 1998, including deferral of commission clawbacks by insurers in an attempt to support broker sustainability as well as accessibility for investors to their investments (for those investors taking up the premium holiday and then paying back the premiums, where a likelihood exists for them to breach the 20% rule and extend the restriction period)

Granting over-exposed institutional investors, including linked and non-linked insurance companies, a  dispensation where they will not be required to realign their foreign asset holdings to be in line with the respective foreign portfolio investment limits, for a specific period and subject to certain conditions

Decided to adopt revised rules and regulations for the examination and sanctions on financial institutions  particularly regarding rules on exemption from sanctions and requests for regulatory interpretation and no-action letter
With effect from 16 April 2020, the Bank Rate has been effectively reduced by 500 basis points from 15.00%  to 10.00% to automatically adjust in line with the SLFR, with a margin of +300 basis points

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in capital requirement (definition of capital, car, risk weights)
Details of the measure: A 1-year postponement of the capital adequacy and minimum capital compliance deadline.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Expanded the Coronavirus Large Business Interruption Loans Scheme (CLBILS) to cover all viable firms.  The program now covers businesses with turnovers higher than GBP 500 million per year. Firms with turnover higher than GBS 45 million can apply for up to GBP 25 of loans, and firms with turnover higher than GBS 250 million can borrow a maximum of GBP 50 million. The government will guarantee 80% of each loan. Accredited lenders will be listed on the British Business Bank website.

Level 3 policy measures: Ensure public risk disclosures by banks
Details of the measure: Released a new reporting standard to collect data from financial institutions taking part in the  Federal Government's Coronavirus SME Guarantee Scheme

Following up and supporting measures already adopted by creditors in general to renegotiation of credit,  credit bureaus to extend the collection process, usually 10 days from the communication to the debtor, for 45 days. As a result, debtors and creditors will have an extended period to carry out the renegotiation.

Following up and supporting measures already adopted by creditors in general to renegotiation of credit,  credit bureaus to extend the collection process, usually 10 days from the communication to the debtor, for 45 days. As a result, debtors and creditors will have an extended period to carry out the renegotiation.
OSFI has released a COVID-19-related explanatory memo on Basel III and bank capital, buffer utilization, and related dividend  restrictions

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Central Bank raised contactless payments limits without PIN from CRC 15,000 to CRC 30,000

Launched a Pre-approved Principal Payment Holiday Scheme for corporate customers that have an annual sales turnover of HK$800 million or less and that have no outstanding loan payments overdue for more than 30 days. Principal payments of loans (including revolving facilities) will generally be deferred by 6 months, whereas trade facilities, given their short-term nature, will be deferred by 3 months

Temporarily allowed credit instututions to violate the capital buffer (TFP) limit. The Bank estimates that  this move will ease about HUF 700 billion for instituions and may further increase the lending potnetial of domestic credit institutions by up to HUF 5 trillion.
The RBI will inject 500 billion rupees ($6.5 billion) into the corporate bond market in a new round of targeted  long-term repo operations.
It cut the reverse repurchase rate 25 bps to 3.75%.
Increased Ways and Means Advances (WMA) limit for all States/UTs by 60% over and above the level  as on March 31, 2020 till September 30, 2020

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: Decided that all banks shall not make any further dividend payouts from the profits pertaining to the  financial year ended March 31, 2020 until further instructions

LCR requirement for Scheduled Commercial Banks is being brought down from 100 per cent to 80 per  cent with immediate effect. The requirement shall be gradually restored back in two phases ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ 90 per cent by October 1, 2020 and 100 per cent by April 1, 2021

Lenders are required to implement a resolution plan in respect of entities in default within 180 days  from the end of Review Period of 30 days. For accounts which were within the Review Period as on March 1, 2020, the period from March 1, 2020 to May 31, 2020 shall be excluded from the calculation of the 30-day timeline for the Review Period, the residual Review Period shall resume from June 1, 2020, upon expiry of which the lenders shall have the usual 180 days for resolution. In respect of accounts where the Review Period was over, but the 180-day resolution period had not expired as on March 1, 2020, the timeline for resolution shall get extended by 90 days from the date on which the 180-day period was originally set to expire.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: For the lending institutions that were permitted to grant a moratorium of three months on payment of all  term loan instalments falling due between March 1, 2020 and May 31, 2020 ('moratorium period'). Accounts classified as standard on February 29, 2020, even if overdue, the moratorium period, wherever granted, shall be excluded by the lending institutions from the number of days past-due for the purpose of asset classification under the IRAC norms. Similarly in respect of working capital facilities sanctioned in the form of cash credit/overdraft (ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩCC/ODÔøΩÔøΩ?), the Regulatory Package permitted the recovery of interest applied during the period from March 1, 2020 up to May 31, 2020 to be deferred ('deferment period'). Such deferment period, wherever granted in respect of all facilities classified as standard, including SMA, as on February 29, 2020, shall be excluded for the determination of out of order status.

Banks which grant moratorium or deferments must maintain higher provision of 10 per cent on all such  accounts under the standstill, spread over two quarters, i.e., March, 2020 and June, 2020. These provisions can be adjusted later on against the provisioning requirements for actual slippages in such accounts

Provided special refinance facilities for a total amount of ÔøΩÔøΩ_50,000 crore to National Bank for Agriculture  and Rural Development (NABARD), Small Industries Development Bank of India (SIDBI) and National Housing Bank (NHB) to enable them to meet sectoral credit needs. This will comprise ÔøΩÔøΩ_25,000 crore to NABARD for refinancing regional rural banks (RRBs), cooperative banks and micro finance institutions (MFIs); ÔøΩÔøΩ_15,000 crore to SIDBI for on-lending/refinancing; and ÔøΩÔøΩ_ 10,000 crore to NHB for supporting housing finance companies (HFCs).

Ordered that factoring companies access credit lines and guarantees that the CRECER  Fund provides in order to facilitate access to working capital for micro, small and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs).

Offered credit instituions the opportunity to apply for risk premiums while restructuring loan debt from  March 1 to September 30, 2020, and allowed credit instituions to apply previous (lower) premia when calculating risk ratios.

Level 3 policy measures: Ease other macroprudential measures (eg, dti, ltv)
Details of the measure: Exapnded the scope of support programs for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The Bank  attempted this by: (1.) revising the calculation of debt limits, and (2.) relaxing the in-person requirement for SMEs to obtain loans related to supporting/maintaining employment. The second rule change applies April 6 through July 1, 2020.

Allowed banks temporarily (during the quarantine period) to open accounts remotely with simplified  KYC rules, provided these accounts are opened by individuals to make or receive socially important payments  (social transfers, alimonies, insurance reimbursement, mortgage payments etc.) or by SMEs to receive grants/loans to preserve employment and ensure salary payments to employees.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in capital requirement (definition of capital, car, risk weights)
Details of the measure: To improve the affordability of mortgage loans, the Bank of Russia plans to accelerate the implementation of Basel III standard in Russia with regard to retail lending. The provisions on the assessment of mortgage loan risks will be implemented by mid-2020. Risk ratios for standard mortgage loans with the LTV below 100% and eligible levels of the debt-to-income indicator will be set in the 20-50% range (currently, risk ratios are in the 35-100% range). This will help cut mortgage interest rates.

Level 3 policy measures: Reduce non-essential regulatory reporting requirements for banks
Details of the measure: Relaxation of deadlines for the submission of statutory returns.

Maximum limit for the ratio of the Open Market Operations (OMO) portfolio nominal size to the CBRT  analytical balance sheet total assets, set at 5% for 2020 in the Monetary and Exchange Rate Policy for 2020 text, has been revised to 10%

Revised the facility offered to Primary Dealer (PD) banks to sell Government Domestic Debt Securities  (GDDS) to the CBRT, including the limits offered to PD banks for outright sales of GDDS to the CBRT will be applied independent of the repo transaction limits and that PD banks will be offered a GDDS selling limit that is equal to the repo transaction limits, related purchases will also be carried out within the total maximum limit of 10% set for the OMO portfolio, GDDS to be purchased and the amount of purchases will be determined by the CBRT, and purchases will be conducted via the quantity auction method

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Proposed measures to support consumers facing payment difficulties due to coronavirus.  The range of temporary measures cover motor finance and high-cost credit agreements, which include: high-cost short-term credit (including payday loans), buy-now pay-later (BNPL), rent-to-own (RTO) and pawnbroking.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Announced a rule change to bolster the effectiveness of the Small Business Administration's (SBA)  Paycheck Protection Program (PPP). The change will temporarily modify the Board's rules so that certain bank directors and shareholders can apply for PPP loans for their small businesses.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Increased the interest rate reduction support for the credit package of VND 100,000 billion. from 1% to  2.5% / year to help customers affected by Covid-19 epidemic to overcome difficulties, stabilize production and business, ensure social security

HKMC Insurance Limited (HKMCI), a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Hong Kong Mortgage Corporation Limited, announces that, the Special 100% Loan Guarantee under the SME Financing Guarantee Scheme (SFGS) will start receiving applications from 20 April 2020 (Monday).  Enterprises may apply for an optional principal moratorium for the first 6 months, so as to alleviate instant burden on repayment. (Subject to approval of funding by the Finance Committee of the Legislative Council, the maximum loan amount per enterprise will be increased to HK$4 million, and the principal moratorium arrangement will be extended to the first 12 months.)

HKMC Insurance Limited (HKMCI), a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Hong Kong Mortgage Corporation Limited, announces that, the Special 100% Loan Guarantee under the SME Financing Guarantee Scheme (SFGS) will start receiving applications from 20 April 2020 (Monday).   The Special 100% Loan Guarantee is applicable to all sectors.  The loans will be fully guaranteed by the Government.  Eligible enterprises should have been operating for at least three months as at end-December 2019, and have suffered at least a 30% decline in sales turnover in any month since February 2020 compared with the monthly average of any quarter in 2019.  An interest rate of the Prime Rate minus 2.5% per annum (i.e. current interest rate at 2.75%) will be charged.  All guarantee fee will be waived.  The maximum amount of the loan per enterprise is the total amount of employee wages and rents for six months1, or HK$2 million, whichever is lower.

CB authorized deposit insurance scheme of Sri Lanka (operated by the CBSL) to issue loans to the non-bank financial institutions  - licensed financial companies (LFCs) with acceptable collaterals under the Liquidity Support Scheme
Banks allowed to delay repayment of loans under the earlier CBSL and MOF programs till end December 2020
CBSL softens prudential requirements to banks, D-SIBs and non-D-SIBs can draw-down their Capital Conservation Buffers by 100 bps and 50 bps respectively;

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Requirement to classify credit facilities as 'non-performing' when the aggregate amount of all outstanding non-performing loans granted to such borrower exceeds 30% of total credit facilities is lifted
Banks are allowed to recover loans in LKR as a last resort, where recovery of loans in FX currency is unlikely
Banks allowed to provide 60 days debt repayment deferral for the payments due in March 2020 by borrowers who are not entitled to any other concession.

The AML/CTF Rules support flexible KYC processes and procedures. Other ways that you can verify your customers' identity  and fulfil your KYC requirements include: - 	using alternative proof of identity processes  - 	using electronic copies (scans or photographs) of reliable and independent documentation, in accordance with your AML/CTF program, to verify the identity of individual customers  - 	relying on disclosure certificates to verify certain types of information about customers who are not individuals, where measures put in place by industry as part of their response to the COVID-19 pandemic mean that such information is not otherwise reasonably available from other sources  - 	After customers have provided copies of identification documents, you could consider additional verification through: - 	using a video call, such as Skype, Zoom or FaceTime to compare the physical identity of a customer with scanned or photographed copies of identification documents - 	requiring a customer to provide a clear, front-view 'selfie' of themselves that can be compared with the scanned or photographed copies of identification documents - 	telephoning the customer to ask questions about their identification, their reason for requesting a designated service or other questions that would assist in ascertaining whether the customer is who they claim to be.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: A revolving refinance scheme of BDT 30 billion for three years period is announced for low income professionals, farmers, marginal/small business owners which banks will distribute through Micro Finance Institutions. BB will give banks at one percent rate, banks will lend to MFI at 3.5 percent rate and MFI can lend at maximum 9 percent interest rate.

BCB postponed the full implementation of the framework aiming at preventing the practice of crimes of money laundering or concealment of assets, rights, and values; as well as the financing of terrorism (AML/CTF) within the National Financial System (SFN).  The mandatory adoption of internal policies, procedures and controls to prevent AML/CFT by supervised entities was postponed from July 1st to October 1st 2020 [BCB Circular No. 4,005/2020].

The release deadline for the ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩPillar 3 ReportÔøΩÔøΩ? was extended from 60 to 90 days after the following reporting dates: March 31st 2020 and June 30th 2020 [BCB Circular Nr. 4.003/2020]. The Pillar 3 Report ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ mandatorily disclosed by regulated financial institutions ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ aims to promote market discipline by providing meaningful regulatory information to investors and other interested parties on a consistent and comparable basis. The norm makes clear that financial institutions categorized in regulatory Segment 2 (S2) and Segment 3 (S3) must disclose their derivative exposures.
Lower the 1-year loan prime rate (LPR) to 3.85% from 4.05% and 5-year LPR to 4.65% from 4.75%
Adjusted the margin between points of purchase and sale to meet the requirement of mandatory quotation of Market Makers, from 80 to 50 basis points until April 30 of the current year

Maintained the 0% cost rate for Temporary Securities Transfer Operations that it carries out with all Market Makers in  the first market window (3:30 pm to 4:00 pm) until April 30 of the current year inclusive. The maximum amount to carry out these operations remains at $ 2 billion. The maximum quota to carry out active and / or passive Simultaneous Operations by the General Directorate of Public Credit and National Treasury is reduced from $ 3.5 billion to $ 2.0 billion
Instructed banks to consider payment moritoria to manage stress related to loan repayment, and allowed them to issue moritoria on payments until June 30, 2020.

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: Suspension in distribution of dividends for 2019 and 2020
SEBI has issued a series of measures regarding easing compliance to listing and reporting requirements due to Covid-19

Level 3 policy measures: Ensure minimal functionality in the primary and secondary markets
Details of the measure: The measures (orderly trading and settlement, effective risk management, price discovery and maintenance of market integrity) implemented since March 23, 2020 will continue to be in force till May 28, 2020.

The limit for Ways and Means Advances (WMA) for the remaining part of first half of the financial year 2020-21 (April 2020 to September 2020) for the government of India will be revised to ÔøΩÔøΩ_ 2,00,000 crore
An extension of 30 days is granted with respect to the ordinary deadlines.

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: The financial regulator recommended commercial banks and insurance companies not to distribute the accumulated net profit for dividend payments in the current year and not to carry out share buybacks.

Level 3 policy measures: Promoting digital channels in line with aml/cft requirements (via e-kyc, digital signature, and online document
Details of the measure: Promoting digital channels (via e-KYC, digital signature collection, and online document submission).

The Ministry of Finance introduced in early April the program ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩDamane OxygeneÔøΩÔøΩ? which provides credit guarantees through the CCG (Caisse Centrale de Garantie) for all new loans extended by banks for working capital purposes to MSMEs (loan amount below the equivalent of $ 250K, there are also limits on the maximum turnover of eligible SMEs).

Reduction of the base rate of insurance premiums from 0.15 to 0.1% effective 3Q2020, and also on the reduction of the additional and higher additional rates of insurance premiums from  50 to 25% and from 500 to 300%  of the base rate, respectively.

It has been decided to waive enforcement measures for the review of credit ratings by credit rating agencies within a period of no later than ten business days from the expiry of the timeframes provided for in Paragraph 9 of Article 12 of Federal Law No. 222-FZ, dated 13 July 201531.

Launched the MAS SGD Facility for ESG Loans in partnership with Enterprise Singapore (ESG), to lend Singapore Dollars (SGD) at an interest rate of 0.1% per annum to eligible financial institutions, to support their lending to SMEs under the Enhanced Enter

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in capital requirement (definition of capital, car, risk weights)
Details of the measure: FSC released details on capital adequacy easing including allowing banks to assign a 100 percent risk weight to contributions to the stock market stabilization fundand easing standards for calculating firms'net capital ratio temporarily for newly issued business loans.
Increased maximum leverage ratio for credit card companies from the current six times to eight times the total assets minus on lending loans over equity capital

Level 3 policy measures: Ease credit exposure limits (large exposures, credit limits)
Details of the measure: FSC temporarily lifted the credit extension cap for subsidiaries of the same holding company to 30%.

Exempted banks from sanctions for violating the Loan-to-Deposit (LTD) ratio requirement within a 5 percentage point range until the end of June 2021 as well as savings banks and mutual finance companies within a 10 percentage point range
Will not impose penalties on Korea Development Bank (KDB) for violating the net stable funding ratio rule within a 10 percentage point range until the end of June 2021

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: FSC permitted all financial institutions to apply the existing asset quality standards
FSC permitted all financial institutions that there is no need to  raise additional capital reserves (provisioning)
FSC permitted all financial institutions to consider accrued interest as interest revenue for accounting purposes
FSC permitted all financial institutions to reclassify commercial loans to closed business from substandard (non performing) to risky assets (performing) category

Level 3 policy measures: Reduce non-essential regulatory reporting requirements for banks
Details of the measure: FSC confirmed that there will be no penalties or administrative sanctions for failing to meet disclosure or business report deadlines.
Allowing insurance companies participating in the bond market stabilization fund and/or stock market stabilization fund to raise short term cash through repos.

Considering the prevailing situation in the country due to the COVID ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ 19 virus outbreak, the Central Bank of Sri Lanka has decided to allow opening of Wallets or Wallets facilitation accounts fulfilling the Know-Your-Customer (KYC) requirements digitally. However, all Licensed Commercial Banks (LCBs), Licensed Specialized Banks (LSBs) and Finance Companies (FCs) are instructed to follow a secure identification method to identify the customer before permitting access to digital Wallets/Wallets facilitation accounts. In addition, fund receipts to these Wallets or Wallets facilitation accounts shall only be made by way of online fund transfers from any account with any LCB, LSB or FC and over-the counter deposits shall not be accepted without proper KYC. This facility is granted till 30 April 2020 and all LCBs LSBs or FCs which facilitated accounts based on digital KYC are required to physically verify the identification details before 20 May 2020.
