AMLO, as key AML/CFT Regulator, is issuing specific guidance on implementing AML/CFT measures in this COVID-19 Pandemic for reporting entities (REs), in line with FATF statement dated 1 April 2020 as follows. As we understand that REs are facing challenges in providing their services to customers, face-to-face, AMLO encourage the use of technology and digital ID for KYC and CDD process. This could help ensuring that the physical distancing policy by the government is strictly followed.  Also, we are emphasizing that REs should follow RBA and apply simplified measures where low risk customers/services or products could be identified. Especially, in the area that could support any government measures in response to COVID-19.
Letter to retails investors regarding several measures.

Issue two exemptive orders in order to move Consolidated Audit Trail (CAT) implementation forward: (1) establishing a phased CAT reporting timeline for broker-dealers, and (2) permitting introducing brokers that meet certain requirements to follow the sma
ECB and Bulgarian National Bank set up swap line to provide euro liquidity.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: The government is ready to provide BGN 4.5bn in public resources through eight packages of measures to help  businesses cope with the COVID-19 crisis, using the services of the Bulgarian Development Bank (BDB) and 12 other commercial banks. Six financial instruments for nearly BGN 4.5bn in support of SMEs, self-employed workers and employees placed on unpaid leave were presented at an extraordinary briefing by MoF. These are loans granted by commercial banks to companies and citizens affected by the crisis, which, although low-interest and even interest-free, will have to repay. The Cabinet has provided guarantees through the BDB and the EIF that will reduce interest rates and allow for graceful repayment periods.
Revised Term Repo terms and conditions to include term repos up to 24 months

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: To ease the potential effects of moritoria on bank capital positions, the FSA also permitted banks to not re-classify them as restructured or overdue.
FSA also issued flexibile guidelines regarding the maintenance of capital buffers and liquidity coverage.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: AirtelTigo Ghana is now enrolling customers via a WhatsApp chat

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Decided to continue the availability of 2% Interest Subvention (IS) and 3% Prompt Repayment Incentive (PRI) to farmers for the extended period of repayment up to 31.05.2020 or date of repayment, whichever is earlier, for short term crop loans upto ÔøΩÔøΩ_3 lakh

The NBK introduced limits on cash out from bank accounts during a month: 20 mln tenge for small businesses, 120 mln tenge for medium businesses and 150 mln tenge for large businesses. This requirement will enter into force from June 1, and will not apply to individuals, sole entrepreneurs, microenterprises and several legal entities involved in retail trade.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: M-Pesa Kenya is offering a WhatsApp chat option for reversals (#chatWithZuri)

Level 3 policy measures: Ensure minimal functionality in the primary and secondary markets
Details of the measure: Incorporated into its foreign exchange intervention tools, the possibility to conduct hedge transactions settled by differences in US dollars. This will be done in order to operate during the hours when Mexican markets are closed.

Will implement swaps of government securities, in which it will receive long-term securities (10 years and longer) and will deliver other with maturities of up to 3 years. The amount of the program will be for up to MXN $100 billion and will be in force until September 30, 2020

Decided to temporarily open a financing facility for commercial banks which will be guaranteed by credits to corporates that issue public debt, so that this financing can be channeled to micro, small- and medium-size enterprises (SMEs) in Mexico. The amount of the program will be for up to MXN $100 billion and will be in force until September 30, 2020

Decided to open a financing facility for commercial and development banks to allow them to channel resources to micro, small-, and medium-size enterprises (SMEs) and individuals affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. The program will be for up to MXN $250 billion and will be in force until September 30, 2020

Decided to implement a corporate securities repurchase facility (FRTC) through credit institutions in order to provide liquidity to short-term corporate securities and long-term corporate debt that, as a result of the conditions of uncertainty and volatility, have observed lower liquidity and impaired trading conditions in the secondary market. The program will be for up to MXN $100 billion and will be in force until September 30, 2020

Decided to implement a debt securities temporary swap facility to provide liquidity for trading instruments which, as a result of uncertainty and volatility, have observed lower liquidity and impaired trading conditions in the secondary market. Under this facility eligible institutions may deliver debt securities in exchange for government securities. The program will be for up to MXN $100 billion and will be in force until September 30, 2020

Decided to open a facility to repurchase government securities at longer terms than those of regular open market operations. The program will be for up to MXN $100 billion and will be in force until September 30, 2020
Extending the counterparts eligible for the Ordinary Additional Liquidity Facility (FLAO) to include development banks and will be in force until September 30, 2020

Extending the securities eligible for the Ordinary Additional Liquidity Facility (FLAO), foreign exchange hedging program operations, and USD credit operations and will be in force until September 30, 2020
Increasing liquidity during trading hours to facilitate the optimal functioning of financial markets and payment systems and will be in force until September 30, 2020
Lowered the target for the overnight interbank interest rate by 50 basis points to 6%
Mandatory compilation of biometric data for users of financial services has been postponed due to Covid-19

Introduced a R200 billion loan guarantee scheme that will assist enterprises with operational costs, such as salaries, rent and the payment of suppliers. In the initial phase, companies with a turnover of less than R300 million a year will be eligible.

Issued guidance to accountable institutions (AIs) to continue to act in good faith towards fulfilling their  obligations to the greatest extent possible, and to make prudent decisions regarding the management of money laundering, terrorist financing, and proliferation financing risks (ML/TF/PF risks)
Provides spaza shop owners with access to working capital investment and revolving credit facility that is backed by the Khula Credit Guarantee scheme of SEFA, in partnership with Nedbank

The SEFA-Debt Restructuring Facility is geared towards SMMEs which are already funded by the Small Enterprise Funding Agency (SEFA) and are negatively affected by the COVID-19 outbreak. SEFA will grant a payment holiday for up to six months.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: The SMME Relief Finance Facility will provide soft-loan funding for existing businesses which are  distressed due to the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. The aid will be available for six months from 1 April 2020, although businesses may apply for a longer period of assistance if additional assistance is required.

Level 3 policy measures: Ease credit exposure limits (large exposures, credit limits)
Details of the measure: Postponed the official introduction of large exposures framework of limiting large exposures at 25% of Tier 1 capital until after 2021
Extended the EUR 100 billion guarantee line to also cover company notes and to reinforce the mutual guarantee societies of Autonomous Communities.

NBU recommended to introduce measures to enable the remote and smooth work  of the insurance companies that exempt insurance companies from the sanctions and fines in certain cases and prolong the deadline for submission of the 2019 financial statements

Announced the alignment of Fannie Mae's and Freddie Mac's policies regarding servicer obligations to advance scheduled monthly principal and interest payments  for single-family mortgage loans, once a servicer has advanced four months of missed payments on a loan, it will have no further obligation to advance scheduled payments. Mortgage loans that are delinquent for more than four months, historically were purchased out of MBS pools by the Enterprises. Today's action clarifies that mortgage loans with COVID-19 payment forbearance shall be treated like a natural disaster event and will remain in the MBS pool. This change reduces the potential liquidity demands on the Enterprises resulting from loans in COVID-19 forbearance and delinquent loans.

All liability insurance companies must hand over information on policies issued to SSN in digital format through the Electronic Document Management (GDE) system. This whole process allows for the tracking of policies from start to finish as well as improved notification when changes are introduced.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in capital requirement (definition of capital, car, risk weights)
Details of the measure: The NBRB approved changes in the banks prudential requirements for the period up to December 31, 2020,  which allow banks:  when calculating the ratio of regulatory capital adequacy to apply the degree of credit risk in relation to debt on loans and securities of systemically important borrowers in the amount of 100% while in case of debt guaranteed with Government's guarantees - 20% on foreign currency debt and 0% on debt in Belarusian rubles;
Apply the value of the capital buffer of 2 p.p. (from 25 March 2020 this number has been reduced from 2.5 p.p. to  2.25 p.p.)

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in capital requirement (definition of capital, car, risk weights)
Details of the measure: To not deduct from the tier I capital the amount of intangible assets (excluding accrued depreciation) on computer  programs, databases or their copies purchased in 2020 under licensing (copyright) contracts or other basis provided for by the legislation, as well as the amount of increase in the depreciated value of intangible assets in 2020 (excluding the accrued depreciation) under computer programs, databases or copies resulting from the modernization of such assets; g rate.

Apply the value of the liquidity coverage standard of 80% (previously 100%). In case of a decrease in the liquidity level  of banks, the NBRB stands ready to extend the refinancing periods and provide banks with loans for a period of three to six months at the refinancing rate.

CDIC relaxed banks' reporting obligations and testing for data system requirements, enhanced its public awareness activities and deferred the payment of premiums (originally due on July 15) until December 15, 2020.
Increased the weight of inclusive financial assessment for assessing performance of financial institutions.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Rreduce the provision coverage (by 20 percentage points) of small and medium banks

Increasing the daily maximum limit for withdrawals and cash deposits in bank branches and ATMs set  on March 29 to cash deposits for individuals to become 50 thousand Egyptian pounds from branches and 20 thousand Egyptian pounds of ATMs.

Announced the introduction of a temporary US Dollar Liquidity Facility (the Facility) to make available US dollar liquidity assistance for licensed banks through funds obtained through the Federal Reserves' FIMA Repo Facility. It's intention is to maintain the facility until September 30 2020

Level 3 policy measures: Prioritize or review critical supervisory actions
Details of the measure: HKMA decided to postpone the 2020 Supervisor-Driven Stress Test until 2021.

DMO (AKK) announced revised Annual Borrowing Plan. Reduced retail sale. Increased FX bond issuance (from EUR 1 billion to 4 billion), of which 2 billion done on 04/23. HUF 1,632 billion (~USD 5 billion) additional issuance of domestic wholesale instruments,  buildingon the 3Y and 5Y bonds.

POJK Number 14 / POJK.05 / 2020 Concerning Countercyclical Policies on the Spread of Coronavirus Disease 2019 for Nonbank Financial Services Institutions - clarify the provision of financing restructuring for debtors affected by COVID-19
POJK Number 15 / POJK.04 / 2020 Concerning Plans and Conducting General Meeting of Shareholders of Public Companies
POJK Number 16 / POJK.04 / 2020 Concerning the Conducting of a General Meeting of Shareholders of an Electronic Public Company
POJK Number 17 / POJK.04 / 2020 Concerning Material Transactions and Changes in Business Activities
Reducing the additional 1 percent capital requirement in respect of housing loans

Level 3 policy measures: Ease other macroprudential measures (eg, dti, ltv)
Details of the measure: Providing leniency in the restrictions on housing loans for workers placed on unpaid leave, including allowing the restriction on the payment-to-income (PTI) ratÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩio to be 70 percent under certain condition

Level 3 policy measures: Reduce non-essential regulatory reporting requirements for banks
Details of the measure: Extended recent European Banking Authority and European Central Bank decisions on "harmonized reports"  to less significant banks and security investment firms; these firms may submit supervisory reports between April 30, 2020 and May 31, 2020. Liquidity coverage requirements and funding plans are excluded from the deadline extension, and they may be submitted within two months of the original deadline.

BDL extends period of credit facilities for one month to include June 2020. It also imposed additional eligibility criteria to benefit from these facilities by excluding entities that were exempted from the lockdown decision or those whose financial performance did not deteriorate due to the current crisis.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Interest payments to banks on behalf of affected businesses

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Encouraged the use of e-payments amid the Luzon-wide, enhanced community quarantine (ECQ) to minimize face-to-face  transactions and prevent the spread of COVID-19

Excluded small sized regional banks from the list of domestic systemically important banks (D-SIBs) and exempted them from the 1 percentage point additional capital buffer rule dictated by the early adoption of Basel III credit risk framework

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in capital requirement (definition of capital, car, risk weights)
Details of the measure: Lowered credit risk weights for SME loans and loss given default rates for business loans through the early adoption of Basel III credit risk framework

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Raised the cap on the face value of non-personalized prepaid cards from KRW500,000 to KRW3 million until September 30, 2020
Established a special purpose vehicle of (KRW20 trillion) to purchase corporate bonds, commercial paper and short-term debts, including junk rated bonds

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Expanding the KRW12 0 trillion in emergency financing support for small merchants to KRW16.4 trillion through reserve funds.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Establishing a KRW 40 trillion+ new stabilization fund to support key industries, which will be operated by the Korea Development Bank
Reduce the policy rate (one-week repo auction rate) from 9.75 percent to 8.75 percent

Level 3 policy measures: Reduce non-essential regulatory reporting requirements for banks
Details of the measure: FCA introduced some temporary measures for firms submitting regulatory returns. We have extended the submission deadlines for the regulatory returns listed below. The extension applies for submissions that are due up to and including 30 June 2020.

Increased the proportion of gilts held in the Asset Purchase Facility (APR) that are made available to the Debt Management Office (DMO) to use in its market operations and for the DMO's Standing and Special Repo Facilities.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Announced a final rule that makes technical changes in the interim final rule that the agencies announced on March 27, 2020, allowing certain banks to delay the estimated impact of Current Expected Credit Losses on regulatory capital

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in capital requirement (definition of capital, car, risk weights)
Details of the measure: Reduction of the total capital adequacy ratio for systemically important banks from 12% to 11% until January 1, 2021;

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in capital requirement (definition of capital, car, risk weights)
Details of the measure: Reduction of the total capital adequacy ratio for other banks from 10% to 9% until January 1, 2021;
Reduction of the counter-cyclical capital buffer (CCyB) from 0.5% to 0% until January 1, 2021;

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in capital requirement (definition of capital, car, risk weights)
Details of the measure: Exclude market and operational risks when calculating the capital adequacy ratio until January 1, 2021

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in capital requirement (definition of capital, car, risk weights)
Details of the measure: Reduction of the risk ratio on mortgage loans issued by banks at their own expense before April 1, 2020 from 100%  to 50%.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in capital requirement (definition of capital, car, risk weights)
Details of the measure: Reducing the risk level of loans to manufacturers of medical supplies and equipment from 100% to 20%.
Extension of the deadline for public disclosure of annual audited financial report by investment companies and the stock exchange until September 30, 2020.
Prolongation of the disclosure of annual and semi-annual reports to the public by issuers whose securities have been publicly offered and traded on a regulated market for a period of 1 (one) month.
Postponement of the inspection of the activities of licensed persons (investment company, stock exchange) in the securities market until September 30, 2020.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Moratorium on reclassification of restructured mortgage loans due to quality deterioration until September 30, 2020.

Level 3 policy measures: Prioritize or review critical supervisory actions
Details of the measure: Postponement of inspections in credit institutions (comprehensive and thematic) until September 30, 2020, except  in cases where urgent response is required.

Restructuring of mortgage loans issued at the expense of the Mortgage and Credit Guarantee Fund until March 1, 2020 on the basis of the Fund's consent (by amending the relevant normative documents of the Fund for this purpose) until September 30, 2020.
Postponement of corrective measures by the Central Bank until January 1, 2021 in case of violation of capital requirements  of investment companies.

Receivables of insurers directly affected by the special quarantine regime that are arising after March 1, 2020 and exceeding 90 days, to be taken into account in the calculation of insurance reserves and the insurer's own funds until January 1, 2021.

Transfer of settlement regime of deals with government bonds, notes of the Central Bank and mortgage bonds on secondary market from ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩT + 1ÔøΩÔøΩ? mode to ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩT + 0ÔøΩÔøΩ? mode until September 30, 2020
Cancellation of listing tariffs on corporate bonds listed on the Baku Stock Exchange from April 1, 2020 to January 1, 2021
Cancellation of tariffs and fees paid to the National Depository Center over securities deals and repo transactions concluded in the secondary market until September 30, 2020

Minimization of the range of documents required by the Baku Stock Exchange when placing securities on the stock exchange by public offering by January 1, 2021 (only an extract from the state register of securities and an issue prospectus are required)

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Reduction by 50 % of the service fees changed to banks in interbank payment systems until September 30, 2020. Reduction of bank acquirer tariffs by 50% until September 30, 2020 in order to reduce the costs incurred by business for card-based payments. .

Negative information on borrowers with satisfactory quality credits as of 01.03.2020 and delaying credit obligations due to the pandemic should be submitted to the credit bureau with a special note by 30.09.2020; borrowers' credit history will not be worsened

Level 3 policy measures: Lower risks weights for credit with public guarantees
Details of the measure: Amended the prudential requirements applicable to financial institutions under the Emergency Employment Support Program in which the portion paid by the Union in credit operations contracted under the Emergency Employment Support Program (PESE) will not be counted as an exposure of the participating financial institution, for the purposes of calculating the capital requirement through a standardized approach (RWACPAD) and Leverage Ratio (RA)

Decided to allow financial institutions to capture Time Deposits with Special Guarantee (DPGE) from institutions associated with the Credit Guarantee Fund (FGC). Funding will be guaranteed by the FGC up to a maximum amount of R $ 400 million of the total credits of each holding institution against the institution or conglomerate issuing DPGE
FINTRAC message to all reporting entities in light of COVID-19 .

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Some RD $ 7,800 million have been channeled from legal reserve release as loans for households, highlighting the financing for Commerce and MSMEs (RD $ 3,950 million), Export ( RD $ 1,130 million) and Manufacturing (RD $ 1,870 million).

Level 3 policy measures: Promoting digital channels in line with aml/cft requirements (via e-kyc, digital signature, and online document
Details of the measure: UAFE has disseminated through its social networks on twitter (@UAFE_EC) and facebook (@UafeEc) and has sent massive emails to the reporting entities in Ecuador, regarding an explanatory brochure - prepared by the UAFE, taking into account the statement issued by GAFILAT - on the phenomena that SOs must consider as risks from this pandemic.
Decided to conduct simultaneous purchase and sale of government securities under Open Market Operations (OMO) for ÔøΩÔøΩ_ 10,000 crores each on April 27, 2020

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: For MNOs, remove fees on operations carried out within the same network. Reduce fees across networks from a minimum of K120 to K20

Issued a circular to all banks, finance and finance leasing companies to defer all types of instalments of loans  of Omani low-pay manpower. The deferment will last three months from the date of postponement.The decision will begin to take effect from the salaries of May 2020 until further notice

Eased the asset cover requirement of banks with expanded/foreign currency deposit units (E/FCDUs) to provide the covered institutions with greater flexibility to manage their foreign currency exposures.Under the new rules, banks shall be allowed to offset any deficiency in the asset cover incurred on one or more days of the week with the excess cover that they may hold on other days of the same week and the immediately succeeding week.
Advises insurers not to apply sanctions to insurants for time of restrictive measures. Lawmakers have restricted the conclusion of life insurance agreements in electronic form.

Pensioners are enabled to continue receiving pensions using their bank cards. The measures provided for by Article 74 of Federal Law No. 86-FZ, dated 10 July 2002, 'On the Central Bank of the Russian Federation (Bank of Russia)' will not be applied in the case of depositing pensions to bank accounts that provide for the conduct of operations with the use of those bank payment cards which are not the national payment instruments.

Directed all banks to postpone the payment of three months installments for all financing products without any additional cost or fees for the Saudi workers covered in support according to the unemployment insurance (Sand) system, starting from the month
Lowered the discount rate from a level of 10% to 8% in an effort to provide the economy with incentives to support businesses and the public during difficult times.

Announced temporary actions aimed at increasing the availability of intraday credit extended by Federal Reserve Banks  on both a collateralized and uncollateralized basis, including suspending uncollateralized intraday credit limits (net debit caps) and waiving overdraft fees for institutions that are eligible for the primary credit program; and permitting a streamlined procedure for secondary credit institutions to request collateralized intraday credit (max caps). Relatedly, the Board is suspending two collections of information that are used to calculate net debit caps. These actions will remain in effect until September 30, 2020
Announced that it is working to expand access to its Paycheck Protection Program Liquidity Facility (PPPLF)  for additional SBA-qualified lenders as soon as possible
Announced that Federal Home Loan Banks (FHLBanks) can accept Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) loans  as collateral when making loans, called advances, to their members

The Central Bank of Bolivia (BCB) injected 3.5 billion Bolivianos (more than $500 million) by purchasing bonds from the pension funds, which, in turn, are expected to deposit the money at banks, increasing the banking system liquidity by about 50 percent.
Amended the Standing Term Liquidity Facility (STLF) to include term of up to ninety (90) days
The economic stimulus package includes temporary suspension of second pillar pension scheme payments

Liquidity provision to banks and microfinance institutions through emergency swap facility. USD 400 million aggregate. USD 200 million for commercial banks; 200 millions for microfinance institutions.
Government announced GEL 300 credit guarantee scheme to improve SME access to finance

Allowing banks and financial institutions taking part in providing mortgage loans for the Housing Authority Subsidised  Sale Flats Scheme (SSFS) to offer a mortgage principal moratorium plan to the scheme's mortgagors for a maximum 12-month period and the mortgage loan repayment period may be extended correspondingly by a maximum of 12 months

In view of the emerging market conditions, and to conserve capital with the insurance companies in the interests of the policyholders and of the economy at large,IRDAI (insurance regulator) ÔøΩÔøΩhas urged insurers to take a conscious call to refrain from dividend pay-outs from profits pertaining to the financial year ending 31st March 2020, till further instructions. This position shall be reassessed by the Authority based on financial results of insurers for the quarter ending 30th September, 2020.

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: FHC designates and DTIs will suspend the distribution of profits by way of declaring dividends in any manner (cash or stock) for the 2020 financial year, until further notice.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Transaction and balance limits have been raised

CBM granted a three-year extension for banks to comply with four directives to better align the sector with international standards released in 2017. Banks now have until August 31, 2023 to comply with: Notification No. (16/2017) Capital Adequacy Regulation, Notification No. (17/2017) Asset Classification and Provisioning Regulations, Notification No. (18/2017) Large Exposures Regulation, and Notification No. (19/2017) Liquidity Ration Requirement Regulation.

Loan repayments (principle, interest, instalment) to MFIs due in mid-April 2020, which was extended by one quarter, i.e. up to mid-July 2020, however, has now been further extended to mid-January 2021.

Borrowers (regular in dues as of mid-December 2019), whose loan repayment capacity has been impaired due to COVID-19, can seek to reschedule or restructure loans, for once for a period of one year; However, at least 25% of the interest accrued and payable on the date of rescheduling or restructuring has to be recovered and the remaining interest may be capitalized.
In case of projects under construction phase, grace period is extended by a maximum of one year.

Level 3 policy measures: Caps on interest rates or fees
Details of the measure: Banks are mandated to reduce lending rates by 200 bps for the fourth quarter (mid-April to mid-July 2020) subject to (a) exclusion list, (b) not compulsory to go  below base rate, (c ) 300 bps to retail clients of MFIs and 200 bps if it's a wholesale loan from an MFI, and (d) the reduced rate is applicable until end of fourth quarter only.
Availability of NPR 10 billion as Refinance Facility at normal refinance rate to the MFIs for a duration one year, which can be on-lent at a spread of 4 percent.
MFIs operating beyond their geographical (provincial) jurisdiction are given up to mid-July 2020 for selling, closing or trans-locating branches.
MFIs not able to comply with capital fund requirement due to COVID-19 will not face actions related to compliance until mid-July 2021.
MFIs that conduct transactions in a group under normal times must make provision for minimal presence of members and/or use alternative medium.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Decided to lower the interest rate on loans meant for for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) from  a level of 4% to 3.50% per year. The loans were offered to credit institutions, which then extended them to SMEs so that they could maintain employment. The interest rate decrease will apply on April 27, 2020 to both new and already existing loans extended by the Bank under this program--with an aggregate limit of RUB 500 billion.
Reduced the key rate by 50 basis points to a level of 5.50% per annum.

Level 2 policy measures: Enhancing tools for out-of-court debt restructuring and workouts
Details of the measure: To support individual mortgage borrowers, CBR recommended to all credit institutions postpone foreclosure and eviction procedures until September 30, 2020.
To support individual mortgage borrowers, CBR recommended to all credit institutions postpone foreclosure and eviction procedures until September 30, 2020.

Launched the secured financing program, by guaranteeing a rate of (95%) of the value of the financing granted according to the mechanisms approved within the Kafala program, with the aim of providing additional support and enhancing the creditworthiness of the micro-enterprises Small and medium and overcome the challenges of financing these enterprises, which reduces the impact of the decrease in cash flows, and makes it easier for them to serve their customers, and to pay the salaries and dues of their employees.
Extended the 3-month and 1-month term Contingent Term Repo Facility (CTRF) thorugh May 2020, with the final  operation on May 29, 2020.

Implemented a 3-month payment freeze on automobile debt, buy-now pay-later (BNPL), rent-to-own (RTO), and pawnbroking agreements. The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) also froze high-cost, short-term credit--including payday loans-- for one month and refrained from charging additional interest. The FCA first proposed these measures in mid-April, and they will become active on April 27.
The MoF cancelled the last 4 auctions (3/31, 4/7, 4/14, 4/21) because of the low demand  and announced they will offer only short-term bonds (up to 252 days) in UAH and US$ on 4/28

Granted no-action relief with respect to a registrant listing new principals or an applicant for AP registration until July 23, 2020, or until the National Futures Association (NFA) notifies the public that it has resumed processing fingerprints, whichever is earlier, as long as the registrant fulfills a number of requirements

Announced an interim final rule to amend Regulation D (Reserve Requirements of Depository Institutions) to delete the six-per-month limit on convenient transfers from the "savings deposit" definition.

Reduction in reserve requirements. New credit extended in local currency will be deducted from the minimum mandatory reserve requirements with ceiling according to different categories organized by maturity (30; 30-90; 91-180; 181-367).

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: MFIs should promote digital platforms among their customers

Level 3 policy measures: Ensure public risk disclosures by banks
Details of the measure: Required banking institutions to take appropriate steps to ensure that borrowers/customers are provided with clear information on the process and changes to the terms of their agreements, as well as convenient means to conclude these agreements in view of the Movement Control Order. This is in association with the 6-month moratorium on loan/financing payments announced on 25 March 2020.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Treasury amends regulation of CBILS scheme to support small businesses.

Level 3 policy measures: Reduce non-essential regulatory reporting requirements for banks
Details of the measure: The requirement for the banks to submit Audited Annual financail statement to BB is deferred untill June 2020.
Reduction of CRR by 200 basis point to 7 percent.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Extended from four to six months the transitional treatment applicable to the provisions required for the reprogramming of commercial credit quotas in banks and supervised cooperatives.
NBG maintains a flexible exchange rate with interventions limited to smoothing larger adjustments. Since March 13, NBG intervened on four occassions for a total amount of USD120 mln.

A special liquidity window of USD 6.6 billion for banks to lend to mutual funds or purchase/repo from mutual funds. The Special Liquidity Facility for Mutual funds (SLF MF) will be valid betweem April 27 and May 11 and funds under this window will be exempted from regulatory limits and will can be considered for prioirity sector lending targets. On April 30, the regulatory benefits were extended to all bank lending to mutual funds, not only lending under the SLF MF. ÔøΩÔøΩ ÔøΩÔøΩ

Approved credit card companies attaching to the SME loan fund to increase the credit supply and financing options of small and medium businesses seeking to obtain a state guarantee loan. The terms of the loan through the credit card companies are the same as those currently in the date.

The Bank of Jamaica has taken additional actions to ensure uninterrupted system wide liquidity, such as the recent removal of limits on the amounts that deposit taking institutions can borrow overnight without being charged a penalty rate and a broadening of the range of acceptable repo collateral.

Implemented yield curve control that applies a negative interest rate of minus 0.1 percent to the Policy-Rate Balances in current accounts held by financial institutions at the Bank and purchase a necessary amount of JGBs without setting an upper limit so that 10-year JGB yields will remain at around zero percent.

Decided to actively purchase ETFs and J-REITs for the time being so that their amounts outstanding will increase at annual paces with the upper limit of about 12 trillion yen and about 180 billion yen.
Conducting further active purchases of both JGBs and T-Bills for the time being, with a view to maintaining stability in the bond market and stabilizing the entire yield curve at a low level.

Strengthened the Special Funds-Supplying Operations to Facilitate Financing in Response to the Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) by expanding the range of collateral in calculating the maximum amount of the loans, increasing the number of eligible counterparties, and applying a positive interest rate to current account balances at the Bank.

Increased the maximum amount of additional purchases of CP and corporate bonds and conduct purchases with the upper limit of the amount outstanding of about 20 trillion yen in total. Maximum amounts of additional purchases of CP and corporate bonds will be increased from 1 trillion yen to 7.5 trillion yen for each asset. Other than the additional purchases, the existing amounts outstanding of CP and corporate bonds will be maintained at about 2 trillion yen and about 3 trillion yen, respectively. The additional purchases will continue until the end of September 2020. In addition, it raised the maximum amounts outstanding of a single issuer's CP and corporate bonds to be purchased, and the maximum remaining maturity of corporate bonds to be purchased will be extended to 5 years.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Temporarily changed the Special Accounting Criteria applicable to the Fund for Operation and Bank Financing of Housing (FOVI), to the Mining Development Trust (FIFOMI) , as well as the Institutional Trusts in Relation to Agriculture (FIRA), regarding commercial, consumer and hlusing loans that they have with clients whose source of payment is affected by this contingency. This allows the lending institutions to not classify restructured or rescheduled loans as non-performing, when they meet certain criteria.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Size of COVID-19 Fund to be increased from K100 billion to K200 billion- K500 billion before the end of the year.

Government will guarantee 50% of any new working capital loans made by banks to Myanmar enterprises generating a turnover of up to MMK1 billion that are not beneficiaries of other government spending schemes, and conditional upon maintenance or rehire of staff as employed on February 1, 2020. Government guarantees will also be extended to firms in high-growth sectors which have been negatively impacted by COVID-19.
Banks allowed to restructure and reschedule existing loans extended to MSMEs that regularly pay interest and principal on a timely basis for a longer period (not more than 3 years)

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: MMK 100 billion trade finance fund to be established by end of year

Level 3 policy measures: Use of recovery and resolution tools
Details of the measure: Establish an Asset Management Company through which potential NPLs held by banks could be set aside for 5~7 years allowing banks some breathing space and contribute towards credit growth

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Promote the use of mobile platforms such as mobile payment services like KBZ Pay, CB Pay, Wave Money, M Pitesan and OK Dollar.
After the third interest rate cut since COVID-19, bank deposit rates in Myanmar will be reduced to a minimum of 5pc and lending rates will not exceed 10pc for collateralised loans, starting May 1.
Suspension of check clearing in Nigeria, restrictions are lifted on April 28.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: The State Bank of Pakistan has enhanced financing limit for a single hospital/medical centre  from Rs. 200million to Rs. 500 million under the Refinancing Facility for Combatting COVID19.
Introduced a new procedure for maintaining the register of mutual investment funds.

Allowing the deferment of principal payment will be available for vulnerable debtors who are unable to service debts due to diminished income caused by the COVID 19 pandemic. It will be offered by all financial institutions from April 29 until the end of this year.

Level 3 policy measures: Reduce non-essential regulatory reporting requirements for banks
Details of the measure: Extended reporting deadline for companies that have already been granted exemptions from sanctions regarding their inability to meet the quarterly and semi annual report ing deadline due to COVID 19 related issues, the deadline has been extended until May 15.

Ordered a new extension, until May 10, 2020, of the suspension of the summary exchange and financial proceedings instructed under the terms of the Foreign Exchange Penal Regime Laws No. 19,359 and of Entities Financial No. 21,526.

Ordered today that the Common Investment Funds (FCI) in pesos must invest at least 75 percent of their assets in financial instruments and negotiable securities issued in the Argentine Republic exclusively in national currency.
Offered the possibility of canceling credit card balances that expire until April 30 in 9 fixed installments with a three-month grace period.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Zero rate credit and twelve installments with six months for  monotributistas [taxpayers underÔøΩÔøΩtheÔøΩÔøΩsimplified tax regime] and self-employed.

Elimination of punitive interest on credit installments (personal, pledge, mortgage etc) unpaid until June 30 and the possibility of requesting entities to defer payment of installments that expire between April 1 and 30 June 2020 until the month following the originally scheduled end of the contract.

Level 3 policy measures: Reduce non-essential regulatory reporting requirements for banks
Details of the measure: Extended the deadline for the delivery of the Market Risk Statement (DRM) and Operational Limits Statement (DLO) and Internal Capital Adequacy Assessment (Icaap) documents.
Change the rule for returned checks so they will be available to the customer at the branch where they were deposited, and no longer at the relationship agency until September 30, 2020.
NBH to launch government securities and mortgage bonds purchase program from May 4.
The authorities are  encouraging the banking sector to reschedule loans and mortgages, in addition to the mortgage rate cuts already announced by the National Housing Trust.

Level 3 policy measures: Ease other macroprudential measures (eg, dti, ltv)
Details of the measure: International borrowings in foreign currency by Nepalese banks with tenure of one year or more may be considered as deposit mobilzation in the computation of Loan to Deposit Ratio, enabling more headroom for lending.

Level 3 policy measures: Ease other macroprudential measures (eg, dti, ltv)
Details of the measure: Loan against fixed deposit as collateral may be advanced for 100 percent of the value of fixed deposit if the duration of the time deposit is of two years or more and the remaining period is atleast one year.

Refinance facility shall be made available to financial instittions at 2 percent up to NPR 1.5 million against collateral of security of pass loans extended to SMEs as project loans, subject to on-lending rate not exceeding 5 percent.
Credit information of borrowers must be reported to CIB within 7 days of credit approval and within 90 days of credit facilities being overdue.

Level 3 policy measures: Caps on interest rates or fees
Details of the measure: Banks are mandated to reduce lending rates by 200 bps for the fourth quarter (mid-April to mid-July 2020) subject to (a) exclusion list, (b) not compulsory to go  below base rate, (c ) 300 bps to retail clients of MFIs and 200 bps if it's a wholesale loan from an MFI, and (d) the reduced rate is applicable until end of fourth quarter only.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Additional working capital facility to the extent of 10 percent of total existing credit limit can be extended to designated sectors (hotels, restaurants, travel trade, SMEs, exporters, health, poultry, entertainment) for one year and without additional equity contrbution.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: The Monetary Board approved the suspension of charging of filing, processing, and licensing/registration fees relative  to application to provide electronic payment and financial services (EPFS) as an additional relief to BSFIs affected by the Corona Virus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) situation.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Transaction fees charged for fund transfer instructions made with PhilPaSS from 01 April 2020 until the end of the ECQ  over Metro Manila on 30 April 2020, shall be waived

The Fed expanded the scope and duration of the Municipal Liquidity Facility, a $500 billion emergency lending program  for state and local governments enduring the economic fallout from the coronavirus pandemic

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Required credit institutions and foreign bank branches to provide free payment service for beneficiaries through direct payment to accounts and free money transfer via Social Policy Bank deposit accounts at credit institutions when transferring money to employers for paying workers' in national currency.

Granting Non-Refundable Contributions (ANRs) for a maximum amount of $ 1,800,000, and $ 6,000,000 for high impact or associative projects. Up to 100% of the project will be covered and surety bond will be required. It will make available a total amount of 70 million pesos to support projects and has the support of the IDB and is part of teh Program to Support the National Productive System.

The Bank of China and Credit Agricole executed the first cross-currency swap between the US dollar and China's  renminbi based on SOFR. The one-year, $10 million swap was confirmed on the China Foreign Exchange Trade System platform.

Offering a line of credit for working capital or liquidity to companies with domiciliary public utilities for aqueduct, sewage and / or toilet, electric power and fuel gas so that they can guarantee the provision of the service and defer, to 36 months, the payment of teh consumption of its users of strata 1 and 2 during the Covid-19 emergency.
National Bank of Georgia reduced monetary policy rate (refinancing rate) by 50 basis points from 9% to 8.5%.

Level 3 policy measures: Reduce non-essential regulatory reporting requirements for banks
Details of the measure: In order to mitigate the difficulties for banks in timely submission of various regulatory returns, in view of disruptions on account of COVID-19 pandemic, RBI has extended the timelines for their submission by 30 days

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: The government will help pay a portion of the interest for loans of up to 10 billion rupiah ($655,308) taken out by MSMEs, provided by banks, the state pawnshop chain Pegadaian or other financing companies. A total of 271 trillion rupiah ($17.76 billion) of loans may benefit from the programme. Lenders may have to restructure loans and delay principal payments by up to six months for debtors to get subsidised
Lenders may have to restructure loans and delay principal payments by up to six months for debtors to get subsidised

Adjustment in the implementation of existing regulations due to COVID19 - Revised implementation of licensing process, report submission, correspondence and meeting with BI, administrative sanction to non-national resource exporter, BI cash liquidity services, price/fee adjustment of interbank payment system (SKNBI), credit card services.
The increase in the guaranteed portfolio claims cap for MSMEs from 10% to 20% for one year (April 2020- March 2021).
CB rate cut to 7%.

Resumed provision of foreign exchange to all commercial banks for onward sales to parents wishing to pay schools fees and SMEs wishing to make essential imports needed to revamp economic activities across the country. In particular, the CBN is resuming the provision of over US$ 100 million per week for both categories.

Level 3 policy measures: Prioritize or review critical supervisory actions
Details of the measure: Delay the entry into effect higher minimum capital (two-steps tiered approach) by one year to April 2021 (first step) and to April 2022 (second and final step) for microfinance banks.

Required that people who access "Zero Rate Credits" agreed under Article 9 of Decree No. 332/2020 (and amendments) may not, until fully canceled, sell securities with settlement in foreign currency or transfer them to other depository entities.
Extended until June 30 including the suspension of the application of fines and the closing and disabling of bank accounts due to the rejection of checks due to lack of funds.

Requiring that companies that access credit lines with subsidized rates and those that carry out purchase-sale operations of securities with settlement in foreign currency will have to request the prior consent of the Central Bank to access the Single Market and Free of Exchange for the acquisition of foreign exchange.
Extends to its affiliates the grace period for the payment of installments of credits in force during the month of June.
The MPC reduced the Bank of Botswana's reference rate by 50 basis points to 4.25 percent.
The MPC reduced the primary reserve requirement to 2.5% (from 5%) effective May 13th
The MPC introduced a new annual downward rate of crawl to shield the Pula exchange rate.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Launched the "Chile Fund for Commitment to All 2020" earlier than planned to finance projects during the crisis period. The initiative was created to fund innovative projects committed to overcoming povery and other social vulnerabilities. Though the original launch date for the first of three lines of credit was June 2020, the first credit line will become available to corporations and foundations on April 30, 2020. The first line of credit will allocate CLP 800 million, and individual projects may receive up to CLP 20 million.

Approved Circular No. 2,252, with provisions for banking entities regarding the Covid-19 credits of the Guarantee Fund for Small and Medium Entrepreneurs (FOGAPE). The Circular addresses the following matters: exceptional measures for the treatment of loan installment provisions in the commercial portfolio; the classification of the debtors and the calculation of the default; the establishment of procedures to control the eligibility conditions of the debtors; the destination of the financing and; sending the periodic information to the CMF.
Reduced its intervention interest rate by 50 basis points, to a level of 3.25%. The rate cut was a unanimous decisoin by the Bank's Board of Directors.
Made the operation of the "Transitionial Liquidity Support" more flexible.
Renewed financially compliant forward contracts that were set to expire before May 30, 2020.
Expanded the list of counterparties for open market operations. The list now includes the National Development Finance (a development bank) and securities companies.
Continued carrying out foreign exchange swaps in an amount of USD 400 million.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Launched a line of credit called the "Territorial Commitment" on April 29, 2020. The credit line will extend up to COP 500 billion to departments, municipalities, and decentralized entities belonging to Colombia's territories. The funds were to be used for working capital. The credit lines have three-year terms, a one-year grace period, and an interest equal to the 1-month Reference Bank Indicator (short-term interest rate) + 1.85% MV. The credit will flow from Findeter to commercial banks to territorial entities. Commericial banks may offer loans at an interest up to 2% higher than Findeter's final rate.
Announced guarantees for companies operating in the accommodation and catering sector, travel agencies and tour operators and microfinance guarantees for micro and small enterprises .

Level 3 policy measures: Ensure minimal functionality in the primary and secondary markets
Details of the measure: Decided that the amended trading hours i.e., from 10.00 am to 2.00 pm for RBI-regulated markets that were effective till the close of business on Thursday April 30, 20202 that were announced on April 16, 2020 shall be extended till further notice.

Decided that the regulatory benefits announced under the SLF-MF scheme will be extended to all banks, irrespective of whether they avail funding from the Reserve Bank or deploy their own resources under the above-mentioned scheme.

Adopted temporary (timeframe not specified) rules for classification and provisioning of already provided loans: application of worst classification criteria within a bank is waived, loans are to be classified separately

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Revised and relaxed the norms for classification of loans as NPL

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Adopted temporary (timeframe not specified) rules for classification and provisioning of already provided loans: portion of loan in local currency guaranteed by the Fund can be classified as ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩnormalÔøΩÔøΩ? (i.e. 0% provision), if the Fund holds a deposit in the same bank

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Adopted temporary (timeframe not specified) rules for classification and provisioning of already provided loans: classification and provisioning requirements of certain type of loans (meeting set criteria) are weakened (e.g. loans which previously would fall under ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩsubstandardÔøΩÔøΩ? category are now allowed to be classified one notch better, same for doubtful and loss categories)

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Adopted temporary (timeframe not specified) rules for classification and provisioning of already provided loans: loans restructured twice since March 1, 2020 due to COVID outbreak are allowed to keep the same classification.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Adopted temporary (timeframe not specified) rules for classification and provisioning of already provided loans: the term after which foreclosed movable or immovable collateral will be 100% provisioned if not sold, is extended from respectively 1 and 3 years to 2 and 4 years, and the banks are given the right to give the property for rent to increase their operational income.

Rules for credit administration are temporarily (timeframe not specified) weakened: certain documentation requirements are waived for lending purposes,and frequency (at least once per year) of mandatory monitoring (with on-site visit) for loans not exceeding 1 mln KGS is waived.

Level 3 policy measures: Ease other macroprudential measures (eg, dti, ltv)
Details of the measure: Rules for lending are temporarily weakned: the DSTI ratio (loan payments to average monthly income) for consumer loans in local currency is increased from 50% to 60% for borrowers with high income (> ~2800$) and lowered to 40% for borrowers with low income (< ~700$).

Level 3 policy measures: Reduce non-essential regulatory reporting requirements for banks
Details of the measure: The deadline for the submission of audited financial statements by banks and OFIs was extended by three months to no later than July 31, 2020 to help deal the effects of lock-downs on the access to supporting financial services.
The BCRP has implemented liquidity easing operations such as security and currency repos in March and so far in April. The BCRP has several additional liquidity injection instruments.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Individuals are allowed to send transfers through the Faster Payments System without fees

Level 3 policy measures: Reduce non-essential regulatory reporting requirements for banks
Details of the measure: The deadline for the parent organisation of a bank holding company to submit the 2019 annual consolidated financial statements of the bank holding company is extended to 210 calendar days after the end of the reporting year of such financial statements, and the deadlines for submitting the interim consolidated financial statements for the reporting periods of 2020 are extended to 180 calendar days after the end of the reporting periods of respective interim statements. The said financial statements are to be submitted to the Bank of Russia within three business days after their disclosure. The deadlines for the submission to the Bank of Russia of the information on the risks of a bank holding company, its members and its investments in investment funds' units as of 1 January 2020 and 1 July 2020 are extended to 180 calendar days after respective reporting dates.

Allowing individuals who are not able to meet the relevant minimum average daily or monthly balances for their retail bank accounts or have set up GIRO arrangements for automated deductions of payments (e.g. for insurance premium and electricity/phone bill payments) from their retail bank accounts to apply for waiving fall-below service fees and failed GIRO deduction charges for retail bank accounts up to 31 Dec 2020.
Allowing individuals to refinance investment property loans, without being subject to the total debt servicing ratio and mortgage servicing ratio up to 31 Dec 2020.

Allowing individuals to defer payments for commercial and industrial property loans up to 31 Dec 2020, mortgage equity withdrawal loans up to 31 Dec 2020, renovation and student loans up to 31 Dec 2020, and motor vehicle loans and hire-purchase agreements (subject to assessment) as well as extend loan tenure for debt consolidation plans (DCPs) for up to 5 years.
Defer Insurance Premium payment, flexible premium installment plans

Became the controlling shareholder of Interbank Card Center (BKM) which operates pursuant to the license obtained from the CBRT and is considered as a system operator with systemic importance for the payment systems in Turkey due to the operations it conducts.

Added a provision that authorized the CBRT to be a shareholder of any systemically important system operators established and to be established to ensure uninterrupted operation of the payment and securities settlement systems.

Expanded scope and eligibility for the Main Street Lending Program. The Board of Governors created a third loan option (with increased risk sharing by lenders for borrowers with greater leverage), lowered the minimum loan size for certain loans to USD 500,000, and expanded the pool of businesses eligible to borrow.

Expanded access to the Paycheck Protection Program Liquidity Facility (PPPLF) to additional lenders including all PPP lenders approved by the SBA, including non-depository institution lenders, and expanded the collateral that can be pledged to whole PPP loans that have been purchased as collateral to the PPPLF
Central Bank lowered to 8% the higher band of the policy rate corridor from 9% and kept the lower band at 6.75% with policy rate kept at 7.25%
Provided a letter that outlines expectation to all deposit-taking institutions (DTIs) on the use of Pillar II capital buffers for DTIs using the Standardized Approach to credit risk.

Level 3 policy measures: Reduce non-essential regulatory reporting requirements for banks
Details of the measure: Providing public companies with temporary blanket relief from certain filing and delivery requirements, which are generally tied to the sending of materials for annual general meetings (AGMs). With this conditional temporary relief, the CSA is giving public companies until December 31, 2020 to file their executive compensation disclosure. The CSA is also providing companies with temporary relief from the requirements to send, or send upon request, copies of their annual or interim financial statements and management's discussion and analysis (MD&A) to investors within certain time periods.
Refinancing rate reduced from 12.75% to 11.75%

Finalized a rule to extend by 18 months the initial compliance dates for the single-counterparty credit rule to enhance financial stability by limiting the exposure that a large domestic or foreign bank can have to another counterparty.

Issued an emergency regulation that will require New York State-regulated health insurers to waive out-of-pocket costs, including cost-sharing, deductibles, copayments and coinsurance, for in-network mental health services for New York's frontline essential workers during COVID-19.
Federal bank regulatory agencies modify liquidity coverage ratio for banks  participating in Money Market Mutual Fund Liquidity Facility and Paycheck Protection Program Liquidity Facility.

Banks were instructed to transfer interests/profits on loans to a blocked account for the period April 01-May 31 and banks must not collect any interest payment from borrowers during this period until further instruction.
Reduction in minimum investment amounts for tax exemptions for real estate investment projects
Closed all offices with just few essential staff remaining at locations

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Increased the Lending Fund for Small and Medium Businesses (SMEs) by an additional NIS 6 billion to NIS 14 billion.

Universal and commercial banks (U/KBs), and their subsidiary banks and quasibanks (QBs), are required to maintain regulatory capital and liquidity buffers under the Basel III risk-based capital adequacy and liquidity framework. In this connection, a covered bank/QB which has built up its capital conservation buffer and Liquidity Coverage Ratio (LCR) buffer is allowed to utilize the same during this state of health emergency.

Universal and commercial banks (U/KBs), and their subsidiary banks and quasibanks (QBs), are required to maintain regulatory capital and liquidity buffers under the Basel III risk-based capital adequacy and liquidity framework. In this connection, a covered bank/QB which has built up its capital conservation buffer and Liquidity Coverage Ratio (LCR) buffer is allowed to utilize the same during this state of health emergency.
PRA said in a statement that exposures under the Bounce Back Loan scheme are eligible for credit risk mitigation.

Details of the measure: PRA gave banks permission to exclude loans under the Bounce Back Loan scheme from the leverage ratio total exposure measure.
Provision of Government Guarantees of up-to ZWL$ 2.5 billion for bank loans accessed by indistry for working capital purposes.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Credit facility for teh Gold sector to teh tune of ZWL$ 1 billion targeting both small scale and large scale miners.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: ZWL$ 500 million has been earmarked for teh MSMEs sector to assist SMEs to quickly resuscitate their businesses and recover from teh effects of COVID-19.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: The performing arts sector has been allocated an amount of ZWL 20 million to assist them in Covid recovery efforts.
A total of ZWL$ 500 million in Gov. Guarantees has been put in place for tourism sector players to access working capital loans from banks.

Level 3 policy measures: Caps on interest rates or fees
Details of the measure: Productive sector lending interest rates have been lowered to not more than 20% and loans must be restructures to allow businesses to recover.
Productive sector lending interest rates have been lowered to not more than 20% and loans must be restructures to allow businesses to recover.
Reduction of statutory reserve requirements on banks will be implemented in order to release at least ZWL$ 2 billion of liquidity in order to increase the capacity of banks to lend.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Extended 24% credits to finance the payment of wages to SMEs that are in financial difficulties as a result of the health crisis caused by the Covid-19 pandemic to also be available to pay salaries in April. -paid in May- and May -paid in June.

Recommendations: acceptance of claims for damages from policyholders by e-mail and in e-form (including video and photo images of events); granting a deferral until 30 September 2020 when paying insurance premiums to insurers directly affected by the special quarantine regime under voluntary insurance contracts; taking the necessary management and technological measures to fully adapt insurers' business processes to the new operating conditions in connection with the pandemic; ensuring the conclusion of voluntary insurance contracts in e-form (taking into account the requirements of the Civil Code of Azerbaijan, the Law on Insurance Activity and legal acts related to information protection); explanation by insurers on their Internet pages of the relevant procedure related to the regulation of information and losses related to the work regime during the special quarantine period; ensuring the reception of insurers through video calls, as well as the continuous operation of the hotline in order to protect the rights of insurers; deferred payment of dividends based on the results of 2019 until 30 September 2020 and non-payment of interim dividends in 2020 in order to maintain and strengthen the capital positions of insurers.

Congress approved the project that capitalizes FOGAPE (Small Business Guarantee Fund) for US $ 3,000 million, which will allow new loans of up to 24,000 million dollars to be granted to companies that need liquidity to face the economic effects derived from the expansion of the Coronavirus (Covid-19) in Chile and the world.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Instructed businesses that the 6 month postponement on payments for certain types of credit announced on March 16 should not be counted towards the number of days needed to pass for the asset to be written down as nonperforming
Allowing financial institutions to delay the publication of quarterly financial statements.

Latvian Finance Association has announced that Latvian banks can join a moratorium and allow customers to delay mortgage payments up to 12 months, consumer loans up to 6 months and businesses can delay up to 6 months.ÔøΩÔøΩ
BNM cut its overnight policy rate by 50 basis points to 2.00%

Flexibility to use Malaysian Government Securities (MGS) and Malaysian Government Investment Issues (MGII) by banking institutions to fully meet the Statutory Reserve Requirement compliance effective 16 May 2020. This flexibility is available until 31 May 2021.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: US$8.5 million worth of subsidies for copra and cocoa export products
Loan holidays for copra and cocoa export products

Extended several loan origination flexibilities currently offered by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac (The Enterprises) designed to help borrowers during the COVID-19 national emergency. Those flexibilities are extended until at least June 30th and include alternative appraisals on purchase and rate term refinance loans, alternative methods for verifying employment before loan closing, flexibility for borrowers to provide documentation (rather than requiring an inspection) to allow renovation disbursements (draws), and expanding the use of power of attorney and remote online notarizations to assist with loan closings.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: All sole proprietorships will be able to access an interest-free loan of 12,000 pesos this month and 12,000 pesos next month.
Reduced the fee to 50% of the fee rate for banks and non-bank credit institutions, when applying for establishment and operation licenses from May 5, 2020 to the end of December 31, 2020

In ÔøΩÔøΩview ÔøΩÔøΩof the ÔøΩÔøΩimpact ÔøΩÔøΩof ÔøΩÔøΩthe COVID-19 pandemic and ÔøΩÔøΩthe ÔøΩÔøΩlockdown ÔøΩÔøΩmeasures undertaken by ÔøΩÔøΩCentral ÔøΩÔøΩand ÔøΩÔøΩState ÔøΩÔøΩGovernments, based ÔøΩÔøΩon ÔøΩÔøΩrepresentations, SEBI has decided to grant the following onetime relaxations from strict enforcement of certain ÔøΩÔøΩregulations ÔøΩÔøΩof ÔøΩÔøΩSEBI ÔøΩÔøΩ(Issue ÔøΩÔøΩof ÔøΩÔøΩCapital ÔøΩÔøΩand ÔøΩÔøΩDisclosure ÔøΩÔøΩRequirements) Regulations, ÔøΩÔøΩ2018 ÔøΩÔøΩ(ICDR ÔøΩÔøΩRegulations) till July 31, 2020.

Introduced temporary measures to allow with immediate effect until 30 September 2020, listed  issuers and parties involved in rights issues and take-over or merger transactions the option to electronically disseminate Offer Documents through publication on SGXNET and their corporate websites. There is thus no need to dispatch hardcopy Offer Documents as required under the Securities and Futures Act, the Singapore Code on Take-overs and Mergers, and the SGX Listing Rules.

Revised and updated time frame to certain dates stipulated in the prior Joint Communication 2 of 2020 issued on 21 April 2020, which outlined expectations regarding accountable institutions (AIs) due diligence and compliance surrounding financing of illicit or unlawful activity.

Announced a one-year postponement of the implementation of margin requirements for non-centrally cleared OTC derivative transactions to help ease compliance burdens on financial institutions amid the COVID 19 crisis.

Banco de EspaÃ±a said they will applythe flexibility available in the regulations on minimum requirements for own funds and eligible liabilities (MREL) to the setting of transition periods and the intermediate MREL targets.

The Monetary Board of the Central Bank of Sri Lanka, at a special meetingheld on 06  May  2020,reviewed  the  currentmonetary  policy  stanceand decidedto  reduce  the Standing Deposit Facility Rate (SDFR) and the Standing Lending Facility Rate (SLFR) of the Central Bank by 50 basis points to 5.50 per cent and 6.50 per cent, respectively, effective from the close of business on 06 May 2020.
Developed the Conformed Invoice as a credit instrument to discount in financial entities or the capital market

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Established a credit line for MSMEs, PyME Plus line, that do not have bank credit so that they will be able to manage a loan with the subsidized rate of 24%, based on a provision of the Central Bank of the Argentine Republic that will be operational next week. The Central Bank authorized a special line for $ 22,000 million with minimum requirements so that they can take their first credit and for the MSMEs that obtain the FOGAR guarantee, the banks cannot deny it.

The relevant Act is the Coronavirus Economic Response Package Omnibus Act 2020 (Act No.22): -  practitioners are still required to lodge statutory returns, including annual administration returns and annual trustee returns; -  trustees are expected to communicate with debtors who are required to contribute from their income but who are not maintaining payments of income contributions, to ascertain whether re-assessment of income, hardship relief or leniency in the renegotiation of payment schedules is appropriate. What constitutes being affected by COVID-19 can include, but is not limited to, a bankrupt having their income reduced or ceased, having to stay home from work because the bankrupt or a dependant has COVID-19, where the bankrupt is presently overseas they may not be able to return to their employment in Australia etc; -  when considering renegotiating payment schedules, the trustee must also be conscious that some smaller creditors may be relying on dividends from bankrupt estates to keep their businesses operating or to pay household bills; -  proposals can be put to creditors without a meeting being convened under the Bankruptcy Act 1966. Trustees should only convene meetings if absolutely necessary. If meetings must be held, they must be held electronically and in accordance with the provisions of the Insolvency Practice Rules. The place of the meeting would be the technology used to facilitate the meeting (eg. by teleconference, or by video conferencing); -  economic support payments  are not claimable by the bankruptcy trustee as income or as an asset, regardless of whether the bankrupt receives the payments before or after the date of bankruptcy; and -  COVID-19 supplement payments  are claimable by the trustee if the bankrupt receives them before the date of bankruptcy and it remains in the bankrupt's bank account when he becomes bankrupt. During bankruptcy these payments are included in the after-tax income amount. If the after-tax income exceeds a set amount, the bankrupt may have to make compulsory payments. -  Enacting the Coronavirus Economic Response Package Omnibus Ordinance 2020  on 25.3.2020  (Schedule 12 ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ applying for 6 months): -  increase in the threshold for issuing a statutory demand to a company from $2,000 to $20,000; and an increase in the time period for responding to such demand from 21 days to 6 months;  -  increase in the threshold for initiating bankruptcy proceedings from $5,000 to $20,000; an increase in the time period for responding to such notice from 21 days to 6 months; and extending the period of protection a debtor receives after making a declaration of intention to present a debtor's petition from 21 days to 6 months; and -  relief for directors from any personal liability for trading while insolvent but egregious cases of dishonesty and fraud will still be subject to criminal penalties. -  Evictions will be put on hold for 6 months by the states and territories. Landlords and renters are encouraged to talk about short term agreements.

Schedule 12 contains the relevant amendments for insolvency, and  Part 1 specifically for personal bankruptcy.ÔøΩÔøΩ From a corporate perspective, Part 3 of that Schedule sets out the provisions for temporary relief for insolvent trading.
Brazil's central bank cut the Selic rate by a more than expected 75 bps to 3%.

BNDES will allocate R$ 4 billion (approx. USD 700 million) through its holding company BNDES Par to fund managers focused on small business financing. It will invest in up to 10 private credit funds, which will be selected in the coming weeks. Commonly funded by institutional investors, these funds seek to provide an alternative to bank loans for companies that are too small to finance by issuing debt or offering shares.

The Canada Emergency Response Benefit (CERB) and temporary additional  amounts provided under the Canada Child Benefit (CCB) pursuant to the COVID-19 Emergency Response Act are not subject to the operation of any law relating to bankruptcy or insolvency.ÔøΩÔøΩ Debtors are entitled to keep CERB payments and CCB payments received pursuant to the COVID-19 Emergency Response Act, and these payments should not be included as property or income.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Small hotels will get subsidies from the state for 80 per cent of bank interest payments for six months.
