Details of the measure: The remaining TRY 40 billion limit of Turkish lira rediscount credits will continue to be extented through Turk Eximbank with an allocation of TRY 20 billion, as well as through state-owned banks and other banks, with allocations of TRY 10 billion each.
Amended regulations regarding credit card instalment payment times from 12 months to 18 months
Required Russian brokers to maintain a short term liquidity ratio of 70% as of October 2021, to be incrased to 100% by 2023
Set up a  ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ4.5 billion EURO repo/ liquidity line with ECB

Level 2 policy measures: Consumer protection measures and ensuring availability and acceptance of cash
Details of the measure: The NBR will provide sufficient cash for ATMs and branches

Level 3 policy measures: Use of recovery and resolution tools
Details of the measure: BSP will gradually re-offer other tenors in its term deposit facility (TDF). Similarly, the daily offer volumes in the reverse repurchase (RRP) facility will be increased at a measured pace. These operational adjustments will begin on 10 June 2020 with the re-opening of the 14-day TDF and P200-billion auction offering in the RRP facility

Level 3 policy measures: Reduce non-essential regulatory reporting requirements for banks
Details of the measure: Suspended submission of required reports to the Financial Supervisor Sector that fall due within the months of March to June 2020 until further notice, except for the submission of the Financial Reporting Package for Banks (FRP), the Consolidated Foreign Exchange (FX) Position Report, event driven report requirements and reserve requirement-related reports

Issued a revision of the ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩComprehensive Supervision Guidelines for SMEs and Regional Financial InstitutionsÔøΩÔøΩ? regarding the way of thinking regarding approval when the amount exceeds the credit limit, etc

Level 3 policy measures: Reduce non-essential regulatory reporting requirements for banks
Details of the measure: CNV extended the deadline for the presentation of the Interim and Annual Financial Statements (EECC) with a closing date of April 30, 2020 of all entities subject to the agency's control.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: SBA, in consultation with Treasury, will promptly issue rules and guidance, a modified borrower application form  for PPP

Expanded its Main Street Lending Program to allow more small and medium-sized businesses to be able to receive support. The Board lowered the minimum loan amount, raised the maximum loan limit, adjusted the principal repayment schedule to begin after two years, and extended the term to five years, providing borrowers with greater flexibility in repaying the loans.

CFTC extended through September 30, 2020, certain elements of the no-action relief issued in response to the COVID-19 pandemic that was set to expire on June 30, 2020. Initial measures were introduced till end June 2020 and subsequently extended till end Sep 2020

Hong Kong Export Credit Insurance Corporation announced the launch of a 100% Credit Limit Top-Up Scheme. It will increase the buyers' credit limits of its policyholders by 100%, subject to a cap of $100 million

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Approved the expansion and modification of the small and medium-sized enterprise (SME) Financing Line for export and investment projects under the Fund for the Internationalized Business (FIEM). The changes include the expansion of the total amount available under the credit line from a level of EUR 50 million to a level of EUR 150 million. Individual credit lines now have a maximum of EUR 10 million, and the associated amortization period is now more flexible.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Permitted farms to apply for advanced payments to receive 70% of the value of the company's securities portfolio. The measure was meant to provide immediately liquidity to farms taking into account the emergency of COVID-19.

Adopted further measures to extend the Additional Credit Claims (ACC) scheme. The Bank of Italy introduced the possibility of granting guarantees to both consumer and mortgage loans offered to households. These measures will enter into force on June 17, 2020.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Panama will expand access to productive financing for micro, small and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) in light of the COVID-19 crisis with a loan of $150 millionfrom a multilateral agency.

Level 3 policy measures: Use of recovery and resolution tools
Details of the measure: When conducting monetary operations for the purchase of securities on a temporary or outright basis, the National Bank will be able to accept domestic government bonds with the longest maturity (15 and 30 years), as well as Eurobonds issued by the state on international financial markets, which are owned by domestic commercial banks.ÔøΩÔøΩ

a) Interest-free loans with 30% grant component for micro and small enterprises through the Development Bank (EUR 30 mn EU grant financing and EUR 1 mn national co-financing). b) Government guarantee scheme through the Development Bank announced, with two products: - 50% guarantee of SME loans through commercial banks (EUR 10 million initial capital, for guaranteeing  over EUR 65 million of new loans) c) Customs guarantee through RBSM for securing the customs debt (EUR 3 million state guarantee would guarantee EUR 25 million) Agriculture credit line through MBPR (EUR 5 mn)
The NBS included corporate bonds in the securities it can purchase on the secondary market and will also allow them as collateral for ST liquidity loans and for repo transactions.

Additional liquidity supprt for MSMEs through the Development Fund announced on 5/29 to support tourism, hospitality, and transport sectors with favorable terms (1% interest, up to 3 years maturity and 2 years grace period).
The government implemented simplified procedures for issuing corporate bonds.
Deemed it prudent to temporarily suspend the issuance of all new insurance licences for a period of six months, other than in exceptional circumstances as may be determined by the PA.
Reference: https://www.resbank.co.za/Lists/News and Publications/Attachments/9990/Communication 1 of 2020 - Suspension of the issuance of certain new insurance.pdf

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: The central bank suspended the fee it charges to financial institutions for the provision of services related to payment systems

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Promoting interoperability between e-money issuers and financial institutions.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Waived fees for mobile money and electronic transactions lower than CDF 2,500,000

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Increase of limits for mobile money for up to USD 2,500

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Keep enough cash at ATMs and disinfect bank notes.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Government announced LKR 100 billion additional refinancing facility through the Central Bank and the PFIs to support SMEs working capital requirements. This is implemented under the Central Banks refinancing loan scheme titled ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩSaubagya COVID-19 Renaissance Facility.ÔøΩÔøΩ? A concessionary interest rate of 4% is applicable and max. amount to be lent as two months working capital (LKR 25 million per applicant targeting the SMEs).

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: The MoF launched a HUF 140bn preferential loan program for SMEs at 0% interest. 50% of the programme's budget may be used for investment purposes and 50% for financing liquidity and operations. The maximum loan amount can be HUF 150 million in the case of investment loans and HUF 300 million in the case of working capital and liquidity financing. The zero percent loan will be available nationwide from June 12 through the Hungarian Development Bank (MFB).
Postponement of loan maturities, up to 3 months, renewable once
Reduction in compulsory capital reserves for banks from 15% to 10% for an 18-month period

The Finance Ministry will guarantee EGP 3 billon in funding provided by the Central Bank of Egypt (CBE) to state banks for soft loans to tourism companies and hotels. The ministry will guarantee the loans for three years, including a one-year grace period. The loans, which are subsidized by the CBE, carry a 5% interest rate and are meant to help tourism companies cover wages, commitments to suppliers, and maintenance expenses amid a covid-induced slump. Beneficiaries are allowed to use up to 15% of the loan to cover basic operations costs.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: The Central Bank of Egypt (CBE) allowed contractors to apply for help under the its EGP 100 billion stimulus initiative for select industries to help them survive the fallout from COVID-19. Companies need to have turnover of at least EGP 50 million per year to qualify.

The CBE said it will finance banks' purchase and distribution of 100k new POS machines this year as part of a wider plan to expand the use of e-payment services. The CBE will give incentives to banks that promote POS payments with a bonus equivalent to 0.5% of the value of the total transactions processed via their POS for three months.
The CBE will guarantee 80% of each loan banks make under the CBE's EGP 100 billion stimulus program for industry.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Egypt's Micro, Small and Medium Enterprise Development Agency (MSMEDA) launched an initiative to provide small businesses, including industrial and labor-intensive projects, with one-year loans up to EGP 1 million. The initiative aims at funding the costs of operation and production to ensure the continuity of small projects.

Level 3 policy measures: Ensure minimal functionality in the primary and secondary markets
Details of the measure: The Financial Regulatory Authority (FRA) is cutting service fees for securities traded on the EGX to 0.005% on transactions to a maximum of EGP 250 to spur trading volumes. The fee was originally set at 0.00625%. Fees for bonds, debt instruments, and sukuk will fall to 0.0025% of the total transaction value.

CBE initiative for defaulting clients (legal persons) (i.e. companies) in all sectors. This initiative will apply to companies having doubtful and bad debts (credit score of 9 , 10) with an outstanding debt balance of less than L.E 10 million (excluding marginal interests) but regardless of whether or not legal proceedings have been initiated or not. If, client repays a proportion of the debt balance in cash or in-kind (subject to bank's approval of in-kind payment) according to its cash flows, the following is done: -	(i) Removing [client's name] from list of blocked clients  -	(ii) Dropping of all cases and counter cases before courts   -	(iii) Releasing all collaterals related to that debt.

Level 3 policy measures: Ensure minimal functionality in the primary and secondary markets
Details of the measure: The President announced that the CBE will allocate LE 20 billion to support the stock exchange.

Level 3 policy measures: Ensure public risk disclosures by banks
Details of the measure: The CBE instructed financial institutions to apply the International Financial Regulation Standards (IFRS9) given the current crisis. Banks are allowed to issue quarterly summarized financial statements in accordance with the Egyptian Accounting Standard No. (30) as amended for the year 2015 (ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩPeriodic Financial Statements), provided that banks prepare full annual financial statements at the end of December 2020 if they prepare their annual financial statements at end of December each year.  For banks preparing their financial statements by end of June each year, they must prepare their annual financial statements by end of June 2021.  For the period of deferral of outstanding credit payments from clients for a period of 6 months issued under the circular dated March 15th, 2020 and subsequent circulars, this period must not, without prejudice to bank's responsibility for assessing its credit portfolio to maintain its quality and the ability of its clients to pay, be factored into the calculation of suspension of payment and must not be considered as one of the indictors reflecting material increase of credit risk.

CBE Initiative for defaulting clients (natural persons) (i.e. individuals).  This initiative will be valid until September 30th, 2020 for defaulting clients (individuals) with debts to all banks totaling less than L.E 1,000,000 (not counting marginal interests) excluding credit cards. Under this initiative, the following is done: (i) Dropping of all the court cases between bank's and client's once terms of repayment are agreed upon.  (ii) Client's name is removed from blocked client lists and guarantees and collaterals related to such debts are released when client pays 50% of net debt balance (not counting marginal interests) during the period until March 31st, 2021 (iii) Clients who have already made such payment before September 30th, 2019 will be eligible for the same terms of the initiative.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: The central bank in partnership with Visa established a campaign to promote payments done through the Visa app. For every 10 transactions every customer will get a refund of AZN 25
No PIN on transactions below HRK 250 for contactless payments

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Fees for transactions on JamClear RTGS have been waived.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: The Croatian National Bank issued a recommendation to credit institutions to issue debit cards to the most vulnerable consumers

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Waive fees on ATM transactions
BNM agree to a full waiver of the fees charged to banks for extracting Central Credit Reference Information System (CCRIS) reports between June 1, 2020, and Dec 31, 2021.
Central Bank of Solomon Islands (CBSI) has made changes to the Cash Reserves Requirement (CRR) - Effective Monday 15th June 2020, the CRR has been eased from 7.5% to 5%.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Extended through July 31, 2020, several loan origination flexibilities currently offered by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac (the Enterprises) designed to help borrowers during the COVID-19 national emergency, including alternative appraisals on purchase and rate term refinance loans, alternative methods for verifying employment before loan closing, expanding the use of power of attorney and remote online notarizations to assist with loan closings, and authority to purchase mortgages in forbearance.

Level 3 policy measures: Reduce non-essential regulatory reporting requirements for banks
Details of the measure: On June 5, 2020, the Bank of Russia decided to establish the procedure and timing for the preparation and submission of reports submitted by non-credit financial organizations for the year 2020. The new procedures are consistent with the regulatory framework that introduced regulatory exemptions due to the spread of the coronavirus.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Signed the'Win-Win Special Warranty' agreement of KRW 420 billion with the automobile industry. Supporting up to 3 billion won in working capital and up to 10 billion won in facility funds

As of June 10, the liquidity injection operations carried out by BCRP amount to S/ 44.3 billion, of which S/ 20.6 billion was Government-backed repo operations. In addition, BCRP has approved repo operations that promote credit rescheduling, thereby injecting liquidity and promoting a more quickly passthrough of the reductions in the reference interest rate to the interest rates of the new credits granted by the financial system enterprises.

Signed the implementing decree that makes the Italian Credit Export Agency's (SACE) guarantee operational to cover 80% of the EUR 100 million loan signed by Ovs, an Italian clothing company, with a pool of Italian banks led by Unicredit. The guarantee is part of the Italian guarantee operations conducted by SACE as part of the government's response to the COVID-19 crisis.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Created the PyMEs Plus program to support microbusinesses and SMEs by providing new lines of credit to eligible applicants. The maximum amounts that can be requested are ARS 250,000 for microenterprises and ARS 500,000 for small businesses.
Lowered the discount rate from a level of 8% to 6%.

Extended regulatory deadlines related to prudential requirements established in the General Regulations of the COOPAC (Resolution SBS N ÔøΩ 480-2019 and its amendments) and the Regulation of Autonomous Assets of Credit Insurance of the COOPAC (Resolution SBS N ÔøΩ 1308-2019).

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Announced an increase in the anti-crisis loan program by RUB 100 billion, bringing to total level of funds available for guarantees to RUB 350 billion. Through the state development corporation Vnesheconombank (VEB), the Russian government guarantees loans to businesses up to 85%. The loan rates may not exceed 2% per annum, and are aimed at supporting employment. If the debtor retains at least 90% of employees by the end of a specified period, the loan and interest are fully written off. Otherwise, the borrower had to repay the loan in stages.

Announced updates to the Secondary Market Corporate Credit Facility (SMCCF), which will begin buying a broad and diversified portfolio of corporate bonds to support market liquidity and the availability of credit for large employers.

Level 3 policy measures: Prioritize or review critical supervisory actions
Details of the measure: FED announced a reduced focus on exam activity in light of the coronavirus response. The resumption of examination activities for all banks is announced on June 15.

Will provide construction sector enterprises with a facility to borrow from LCBs, using guarantees issued by the government equivalent to the amount due on account of contracts carried out in the past, under a new dedicated credit scheme funded by the Central Bank and made available at the aforementioned concessionary rates.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Approved two sets of amendments on public and confidential financial reporting rules. First, the Bank of Spain introduced changes to credit-risk classification of forborne exposures.

Approved the last section of the line of Guarantees, and prioritized loans for the self-employed and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), and comapnies in the tourism and automotive sectors. This fifth section bears a budget of EUR 15.5 billion.

Approved the grant of regulatory relief for Pawnshops through the relaxation of their maximum borrowing limit by increasing the allowed percentage of their total borrowings to pledge loans from 50% to 70% until 31 December 2021

Posted two revised Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) loan forgiveness applications implementing the PPP Flexibility Act of 2020. Both applications give borrowers the option of using the original 8-week covered period (if their loan was made before June 5, 2020) or an extended 24-week covered period.

Announced that Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac (the Enterprises) will extend their single-family moratorium on foreclosures and evictions until at least August 31, 2020. The foreclosure moratorium applies to Enterprise-backed, single-family mortgages only. The current moratorium was set to expire on June 30th.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Amended its "Affordable Loans 5-7-9%" program to provide affordable loans to businesses. Amendments included: the removal of mandatory profitability minimum from the previous tax period, the removal of restrictions on the use of funds received by businesses to finance working capital, the prohibition of the use of bank deposits as collateral, the removal of the restrictions on maximum loans, and an alternative calculation of loan rates based on a bank's operating expenses.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: National Bank of Georgia decided not to categorize credits that were offered grace periods by banks as negative and in case of due repayment, they would be assigned to the standard category.

Level 2 policy measures: Consumer protection measures and ensuring availability and acceptance of cash
Details of the measure: National Bank of Georgia issued a new regulation allowing consumers to cash sums not only via ATM but also via POS terminals at outlets (pharmacies, groceries).

BCBS discussed the impact of COVID-19 and reiterated guidance on capital buffers. They also stated that supervisors will provide banks sufficient time to restore buffers,taking into account economic and market conditions and individual bank circumstances.

Level 3 policy measures: Promoting digital channels in line with aml/cft requirements (via e-kyc, digital signature, and online document
Details of the measure: The National Bank of Georgia started issuing approvals for remote identification of customers by banks. By end May, the approvals for various products have been given to three banks.

The Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA) has published a frequently asked question (FAQ) providing clarification to authorised deposit-taking institutions (ADIs) in determining their capital requirements under Prudential Standard APS 112 Capital Adequacy: Standardised Approach to Credit Risk (APS 112).

Level 3 policy measures: Prioritize or review critical supervisory actions
Details of the measure: The stress tests submission deadline was delayed by 3 months to June 15, 2020; The transparency report regarding the pillar 3 credit risks, which the banks were obliged to submit from April, was delayed by 6 months; The credit issuing institutions, credit unions, and currency exchange stations were allowed to submit reports with a delay (until end April).

The NBG will not impose sanctions if the economic limits are breached due to the current shock (e.g. exchange rate devaluation, reserves/loss). It concerns violation of the economic limits (coefficients) solely and not the other types of legislative breaches.
The risk cover for the payroll rolls under the MOF gaurantee facilty has been enhanced to 60% of first loss (from 40%).

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Freezing of loan classification is increased untill Septemeber 30, 2020 from June 30, 2020.

Interests based on loan outstanding as of 31 March, 2020 for the months of April and May will be waived fully for up to taka 100 thousands, will be reduced 2 percent for  over 100 thousand but below one million and at one percent rate for loans over 1 million.

To support the recovery, two dedicated CCG product were created. First ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩRelance TPEÔøΩÔøΩ? will enable all companies with an annual turnover below MAD 10M to benefit from a 95% guarantee on new loan capped at 10% of their annual turnover.   ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩDamane RelanceÔøΩÔøΩ? will offer 80%-90% guarantee to companies depending on their size for companies (turnover above MAD 10M). The amount of the loan is capped at one month and hal of annual turnover for industrial companies, one month for others. 50% of the loan have to be used to pay suppliers to reduce payment delays.

The Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) of the Bank of Namibia has decided to reduce the Repo rate from 4.25% to 4.0%, so support domestic economic activity and safeguard the one-to-one link between the Namibian Dollar and South African Rand

For auto entrepreneurs impacted by the crisis, the CCG introduced a 'Garantie auto-entreprenneurs COVID 19 : a zero interest new loans caped at 15 KDH which can be spread over up to 3 years with 1 year of grace.  Interest rates are covered by the insurance sector.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: On June 2nd, public entities were requested to adopt the required measures to be able to process to digital receipts to reduce payment delays.

CB will provide funding to LCBs at a rate of 1% against the pledge of a broad spectrum of collateral, on the condition that LCBs in turn will on-lend to domestic businesses at 4%. This scheme along with the existing refinance Scheme will provide Rs. 150 billion in total to the businesses affected by the COVID-19 pandemic.

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: In May 2020, BAM invited credit institutions to suspend the payment of dividends for the year 2019.

Reduced SRR applicable on all rupee deposit liabilities of LCBs by 200 basis points to 2%, wef. the reserve maintenance period that commenced on 16.06.2020. This reduction in the SRR injects around Rs. 115 billion of additional liquidity to the domestic money market, enabling the financial system to expedite credit flows to the economy, while reducing the cost of funds of LCBs.ÔøΩÔøΩ

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Government and the banking sector will entirely cover the cost of interest payments due to postponed installments on the Marsh-June period, for households: caped at 3500 DH of repayment for housing credit and 1500 DH for consumer credit.

On  review  of  the  COVID-19  pandemic  related  situation,  it has been  decided  that  the regulatory measures introduced vide SEBI Press Release dated March 20, 20201, shall continue to be in force till July 30, 2020
The Central Bank announced it would lower the policy rate from 2% to 1.5%.

Lower medium term inflation outlook, driven mainly by subdued aggregate demand due to Covid-19 pandemic prompted the Bank of Mozambique's Monetary Policy Committee to cut the policy rate (MIMO rate) by 100 basis points to 10.25 percent. The committee also cut the Permanent Deposit Facility (FPD) and the Permanent Lending Facility (FPC) rates by 100 basis points to 7.25 and 13.25 percent.
The Monetary Policy Committee lifted the restrictions on the access to the standing lending facility (FPC) introduced in October 2016.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: The Council of Ministers approved (through Decree-law no. 37/2020) a MZN 1 billion line of credit to affected MSMEs, to be managed by the state-owned Banco Nacional de Investimentos.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in capital requirement (definition of capital, car, risk weights)
Details of the measure: Pillars 1 capital requirements for banks were reduced from 9% to 8.5%.  Also the solvency ratio went down from 12% to 11.6%.
Banks can also use liquidity buffers in the form of high-quality liquid assets until the end of June below the minimum LCR ratio (100%).

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: To support MFIs, Bank Al Maghrib smoothed exceptionally rules of provisioning for banks.

Authorization of new credit facilities for banks to incentivize continued financing and refinancing of loans to individuals and companies. On June 16, they announced an expansion of this program by 6.4% of GDP. Total announced monetary stimulus amounts to 20% of GDP.
CB cuts the overnight rate (from 3% to 2.25%)

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: Providing for adequate capital buffers for supervised financial institutions to ensure effective operation by deferring payments of all discretionary dividends and bonus payments for at least 90 days effective March 24, 2020. This preserves the capital of a financial institution and is intended to support the real economy.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: COVID-19 Recovery Loan for Large Businesses: MoF in partnership with the Bank of Maldives offering loans to registered resorts and businesses (with a turnover greater than MVR 10 million in 2019). This is an unresecured facility (with a soveriegn gaurantee) for 3 years at 6%. Loan has a 6 month grace period on repayments.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: COVID-19 Recovery Loan for SMEs: MoF in partnership with the SME Development Finance Corporation in offering loans to SMEs (with a turnover less than MVR 10 million in 2019). Loans are avaible for upto 10% of the sales revenue of 2019; capped at MVR 500,000. This is an unresecured facility (with a soveriegn gaurantee) for 3 years at 6%. Loan has a 6 month grace period on repayments.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Only large businesses and SMEs who had not laid off staff were eligible for the COVID Recovery Loans; now eligibility has been extended to allow firms who commit to rehire laid off staff
Bank of Uganda (BOU) has in the June 2020 Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) meeting reduced the Central Bank Rate (CBR) by 1 percentage point to 7 percent.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: (1)	Provide credit through SACCOs and Micro Finance Institutions to support micro and small-scale enterprises. An allocation of UShs 94 billion for FY2020/21;  (2)	Increase access to credit at Uganda Development Bank to offer low interest financing to manufacturing, agribusiness and other private sector firms, for which UShs. 1,045 billion over the medium term has been provided
Policy rate cut by 1 pc to 8.5%.
Policy rate cut by 1.5pc to 7.0%.
The Zimbabwe Ministry of Finance has joined the Global Call for Action on Remittances, an initiative by the Governments of Switzerland and UK to help maintain remittance flows to receiving countries.
Reduced reference interest (taux directeur Banque Algerie) rate from 3.25 to 3%.
Reduced mandatory capital reserves (reserves obligatoires) for banks from 8% to 6%.
Increase of the refinancing cap for public securities (below 1 year maturity from 90 to 95%; between 1 and 5 yearsfrom 80 to 90% and above 5 yeas from 70 to 85%).
Bank reserve requirement at the CB reduced from 2 percent to 0 percent.
Banks are now allowed to make maximum of four (4) restructuring for a credit exposures affected by the pandemic, irrespective of the number of times it has been restructured in the past.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Loans restructured due to covid-19 are not classified as deaulted. The same applies to moratorium and payment deferral.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in capital requirement (definition of capital, car, risk weights)
Details of the measure: To support MFIs, Bank Al Maghrib (the Central Bank) smoothed exceptionally rules of classification  for banks. Level 3 policy measures: Ensure public risk disclosures by banks
Details of the measure: Second, the Bank agreed to: (1.) increase the reporting requirements of banks with respect to non-performing and foreborne exposures and foreclosed collateral, (2.) supplement the information on operating and administrative expenses, and (3.) incporate minor changes to the data to be reported on leases as a result of the enforcement of Internatioanal Financial Reporting Standard (IFRS) 16 Leases.
CBA recommended banks to automatically extend the expiration dates of payment cards for customers receiving pensions, social benefits and targeted state social assistance untill September 30, 2020.
CBA lowered the refinancing rate to 7% from 7.25%. The floor of the interest rate corridor was set at 6.5%, while the ceiling was set at 7.5%.

CBA issued new rules for banks to adhere while conducting the FX operations with customers. Every customer willing to buy more than USD500 will be required to fill in special work with information on the source of income and purpose of use. The amounts of USD20K and more will automatically fall under surveillance of Financial Monitoring Services to investigate the investigate the source of funds to conversion. If valid evidence is not presented, the converted amount will be taxed at 14%.

The capital requirements of the commercial banks have been lowered which implies the elimination of the capital conservation buffer (2.5% of the risk weighted assets) and the portion of the pillar 2 buffer (2/3 of the currency induced credit risk buffer). This supervisory relief can free GEL 1.6 billion of capital, which can be used for absorbance of potential losses or funding the real economy with GEL 16 billion.

Regulation on Credit Concentration and Large Risks in Commercial Banks which should have been enacted from June 2020, has been postponed for 1 year. This will enable commercial banks to continue crediting the real economy with strict limits and keep working within the framework of the current rules. It is noteworthy that in case of enacting the regulation from June and consequently in case of Tier 1 capital calculation, 5 banks would breach the 25% limit on Top-1 largest group exposure totaled 109 million GEL.

Level 3 policy measures: Prioritize or review critical supervisory actions
Details of the measure: The National Bank suspended the on-site inspection of the entities being under the NBG supervision (except for the money laundering inspections which are going on remotely at this stage). The crediting procedures have been simplified, according to which the real estate estimation temporarily does not require the on-site visit. The requirement related to the updating of the financial statement has been eased as well.

New rules are introduced on mechanism for restructuring debt obligations of credit organizations to the Azerbaijan Entrepreneurship Development Fund in case of force majeure (natural disasters, epidemics, etc.) or delay in repayment of loan obligations under partial credit guarantee scheme approved by Cabinet of Ministers as part of Covid19 Action Plan.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Soft credit line for large enterprises
SFC Circular 21 providing instructions related to calculating insurance policy premiums as a consequence of changes in dynamics of insured risks due to COVID-19
SFC Circular 19 providing instructions to credit institutions on mandatory investment in Solidarity Securities - TDS (in accordance with Decree 685).
Banxico Circular 22 - Provisional measures regarding minimum payment amounts applicable to credit, loans or revolving financing associated with credit cards, in relation to the COVID-19 pandemic
Banxico Circular 17 - Government securities repurchase transactions with Banco de MÃ©xico to cover liquidity needs
Banxico Circular 25 - Financing to Banks guaranteed with qualified bank credit assets, for channeling it to MSMEs
Circular 20 - Financing to Banks and Development Banks for MSMEs, , related to Rules applicable to government securities repurchase transactions with Banco de MÃ©xico to cover liquidity needs.

Raised the ceiling of the gilt portion of the Asset Purchase Facility (APF). The Monetary Policy Committee voted by a majority of 8-1 to increase the target stock of purchased UK government bonds by an additional GBP 100 billion, bringing to the total level of planned asset purchases to GBP 745 billion by the end of the year 2020. The Committee acknowledged that liquidity conditions stabilized since the earlier period of disfunction, so asset purchases were set at a slower pace compared to the emergency pace of the previous period.
Increased the credit loss compensation limit of KredEx's extraordinary loan guarantee to 30 percent for new loans issued by banks.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in capital requirement (definition of capital, car, risk weights)
Details of the measure: Reduced the requirements for the minimum regulatory capital of banks from UAH 500 million to UAH 200 million. The National Bank of Ukraine also invalidated the special requirements for banks managing construction financing funds.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Decided to lower the interest rate that the Bank of Russia extends to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to support and maintain employment by 1 percentage point, decreasing the annual rate from a level of 3.50% to 2.50%. It will come into force on June 22, 2020, and will apply to both newly and previously granted loans with an aggregate limit of RUB 500 billion.
Decided to reduce the key interest rate by 100 basis points, bringing the annual rate to a level of 4.5%.

Released a new set of measures designed to ease restrictions on foreign investment in listed Chinese firms. Among other changes, the minimum asset threshold that foreign investors must meet in order to invest in Chinese A-shares has been  greatly reduced.
Extended conditional relief from the in-person voting requirements for fund boards that it originally provided in March 2020.  That relief will now extend at least through December 31, 2020.

Level 3 policy measures: Prioritize or review critical supervisory actions
Details of the measure: Approved an interim final rule to reduce assessments in response to the national emergency declared in connection with the coronavirus disease (COVID-19). Under the interim final rule, assessments due on September 30, 2020, for national banks, federal savings associations, and federal branches and agencies of foreign banks (collectively, banks) will be calculated using the December 31, 2019, "Consolidated Reports of Condition and Income" (call report) for each institution, rather than the June 30, 2020, call report.

Turkey's central bank revised its required reserve ratio rule to allow lenders with real loan growth rates of more than 15% to hold a smaller buffer through year-end.  The revision will be effective from the calculation date of 12 June 2020 with the maintenance period starting on 26 June 2020 to the calculation date of 25 December 2020.

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: Issued a statement requesting that commercial banks stop paying interim dividends and pause stock buybacks.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Announced adjustments to the rules for providing soft loans to systemically important enterprises. These loans were meant to restore working capital. Previously, the loans were restricted to companies that witnessed a 30% decline in quarterly production. The eligibility requirement was adjusted to monthly production. The government also increased the participation limit from a level of RUB 3 billion to RUB 5 billion.

Level 3 policy measures: Relief measures on customer identification (e.g. simplified cdd even in case of non-face-to-face relationships)
Details of the measure: Authorized, on a temporary basis, regulatory flexibilities regarding non-face-to-face identification for financial institutions.
Adjusted the Loan Prime Rate (LPR) as follows: the one-year LPR is 3.85% and the above-five-year LPR is 4.65%. The rates are effective until the next release.

Approved a final rule that mitigates the deposit insurance assessment effects of participating in the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) and the Paycheck Protection Program Liquidity Facility (PPPLF) and Money Market Mutual Fund Liquidity Facility (MMLF). Under the final rule, the FDIC will generally remove the effect of PPP lending in calculating an IDI's deposit insurance assessment. Among other changes, the final rule provides an offset to an IDI's total assessment amount for the increase in its assessment base attributable to participation in the PPP and MMLF. The final rule will be effective immediately upon publication in the Federal Register, with an application date of April 1, 2020, and changes will be applied to assessments starting in the second quarter of 2020.

Announced that on June 24 and 29, 2020, the central bank will execute swap line operations in the amounts of USD 7 billion and 4  billion dollars, respectively. Both operations will have a maturity of 84 days.
Decided to lower the central bank base rate by 15 basis points, bringing the most recent rate to a level of 75 basis points.

Issued the "Notice on Hubei Province Insurance Legal Institutions and Branches Exempted from Paying Insurance Insurance Funds for 2020," which exempts insurance institutions based in Hubei Province from paying protection fees in light of Covid-19.

Level 3 policy measures: Prioritize or review critical supervisory actions
Details of the measure: Issued, in conjunction with the state bank and credit union regulators, examiner guidance to promote consistency and flexibility in the supervision and examination of financial institutions affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. No action on the part of supervised institutions is required.
Placing in  Short-Term Treasury Securities (TES)  in the Colombian stock market.

Announced the first issuance of RMB 50 billion in Special Treasury Bonds (STB) to support the economy. The central government has mandated that all STB money go to cities and counties ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ rather than provincial governments. The STBs will be used for infrastructure, rent subsidies, loan discounts for key enterprises, loan discounts for new businesses, subsidies to help businesses stabilize employment, and basic living allowances for people in need, as well as other expenditures related to the coronavirus. This marks the first STB issuance since 2007.
Reported that the New York Federal Reserve (Fed) accepted its enrollment in the overnight transaction service called Temporary Foreign and International Monetary Authorities (FIMA) REPO Facility.

Decided to admit the balance of credit operations for financing working capital for companies with annual sales of up to BRL 50 million, contracted from June 29 to December 31, 2020, as a deduction from the compulsory reserve requirement on savings deposit resources, for a period of three years.

Reduced the Risk Weighting Factor (FPR) from 50% to 35% for time deposits with special guarantee (DPGE) exposures when the depositor is an institution associated with the Credit Guarantee Fund (FGC). The DPGE is a time deposit guaranteed by the FGC and aims to ensure liquidity for smaller institutions in an environment with greater risk aversion.
Extended until December 31, 2020, through Decree 544/2020, the suspension of the closure of bank accounts and the disqualification established in article 1 of Law No. 25,730.

The CNV ordered a series of regulatory measures for the local capital market regarding the coordination of operations in regulated markets and the monitoring of operations carried out in foreign markets. The General Resolution No. 843/2020 was approved by the Board of Directors of the organization.

Adopted a resolution in order to mitigate the requirements for the classification of loans of NBFIs. In particular, the resolution provides for weakening of requirements for classification of loans under watch and sub-standard categories with respect to classification of parallel loans to borrowers in one NBFIs and other weakenings.

Level 3 policy measures: Lower risks weights for credit with public guarantees
Details of the measure: Reserve Bank of India assigned 0% risk weights to the Guaranteed Emergency Credit Line under the Emergency Credit Line Guarantee Scheme.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩThe payments industry will be temporarily increasing the contactless card PIN limit from $100 to $200 to help reduce the risk of COVID-19 transmission by reducing physical contact with the payment terminal. The new $200 limit will be progressively introduced across certain cards and at certain retailers starting in April 2020.ÔøΩÔøΩ?

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩThe Central Bank has issued statements, urging customers to use online financial services, payment and settlement apps and online banking services, which is also aimed at increasing the operational capacity of financial organizations.ÔøΩÔøΩ?

Bank Indonesia (BI) cut the benchmark 7-day reverse repurchase rate by 25 basis points to 4.25%, the lowest since 2018.  BI also cut the deposit and lending facility rates by the same amount, taking them to 3.50% and 5%, respectively.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Central Bank introduced additional debt relief measures, including interest rate cuts by 2-4 percentage points for credit cards and personal loans, to help debtors during the coronavirus outbreak. The maximum interest rate for credit cards will fall to 16% per year from 18%, while the rates for personal loans will be reduced to 24-25% from 28%, effective from Aug. 1.

On June 16, 2020, the CBE issued a circular to make an amendment to the tourism initiative announced in March 2020 in light of the pandemic. CBE decided to issue a financial guarantee. This will be in the form of allocating EGP 3 billion of the total amount of its EGP 50 billion tourism initiative to facilitate: (i) the payment of the salaries and wages of the sector's employees for the months of May, June, and July 2020, and (ii) the payment of basic operating and maintenance expenses. 85 percent of the EGP 3 billion will be used for financing the payment of the salaries and wages of insured employees (at a maximum of EGP 15,000 per employee per month) while the remaining 15% of the funds will be used to finance basic operations and maintenance. Companies that can benefit from this new amendment include hotels, tourism projects, travel agencies, land tourism transportation companies, and restaurants and recreational activities providers in touristic areas. The interest rate for the financing under the new June 2020 amendment is set at 5% for a loan period of two years. There is also no set date for the expiration of this amendment, as it ends with the exhaustion of the allocated EGP 3 billion amount.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: The CBE has extended its decision to exempt EGP-dominated transfers between local banks from fees and commissions until September 15, 2020. The CBE first ordered banks to charge no fees and commissions in March 2020.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: On June 18, 2020, the CBE issued a circular to add newly founded medium-sized enterprises and small firms that are affiliated with big entities to its EGP 100 billion financing initiative to support the industrial, agricultural and construction sectors. The action was taken in order to help these firms recover amid the COVID-19 crisis by providing loans under the initiative at an 8 percent decreasing interest rate.

A new procedure was approved for providing additional support measures to SMEs. From June 16 to Sep. 15, 2020, the provision of deferred loan payments for a period sufficient to restore financial condition to borrowers experiencing temporary financial difficulties.

A new procedure was approved for providing additional support measures to SMEs. From June 16 to Sep. 15, 2020, an SME entity has the right to apply to a bank or microfinance organization with a request for additional support measures. The second is refinancing of loans under preferential terms within the framework of state programs to support business entities for borrowers servicing loans at market rates.
Extended until December 31, 2020, tthe period in which entities cannot charge punitive interest on the unpaid amounts of credits granted.
SEC provides in-person board meeting relief for corporates as part of broader exemptive orders providing temporary relief.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Rules for granting preferential loans at the expense of the Entrepreneurship Development Fund of the Republic of Azerbaijan.
Paraguay's central bank cut its benchmark interest rate by 50 basis points to 0.75%.
In an unscheduled meeting, Pakistan cut its policy rate by 100 bps to 7%.

Reached out to insurers to outline expectations regarding limit discretionary capital distributions and dividends in the months ahead, to ensure that they instead use buffers and maintain capacity to continue to underwrite insurance
Temporarily suspending issuing new insurance and superannuation licences for at least six months in response to the economic uncertainty created by COVID-19.
The Canadian Securities Administrators (CSA) published temporary blanket relief for market participants from certain regulatory filings, as a result of COVID-19.

At the Monetary Policy Meeting, the Policy Board of the Bank decided upon the following measures to facilitate corporate financing: 1. Introduction of the Special Funds-Supplying Operations to Facilitate Corporate Financing regarding the Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19); 2.  Increase in purchases of CP and corporate bonds

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: The Coronavirus Business Interruption Loan Scheme (CBILS) provides financial support to smaller businesses (SMEs) across the UK that are losing revenue, and seeing their cashflow disrupted, as a result of the COVID-19 outbreak.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: The Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act was passed by Congress with overwhelming, bipartisan support and signed into law by President Trump on March 27th, 2020.  This is an over $2 trillion economic relief package. It includes small business paycheck protetction Program (PPP) that provides small businesses with the resources they need to maintain their payroll, hire back employees who may have been laid off, and cover applicable overhead.
Suspension, as of 16 March 2020, of repayments for loans granted by BPI France, for a duration up to 6 months.

For Guarantee Banks, the maximum guarantee amount will be doubled to EUR 2.5m. The Federal Government will increase its risk share in the guarantee banks by 10%.  The large guarantee program (parallel federal-state guarantees), which has so far been limited to companies in structurally weak regions, will be opened up to companies outside these regions. Operating capital financing and investments can now be secured starting from EUR 50m of guarantee requirement and upwards, with a guarantee ratio of up to 80%.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Governing Council of the ECB approved the first set of measures to extend the scheme of the Bank of Italy relating to additional bank loans (Additional Credit Claims, ACC). The measures introduced aim to support lending to small and medium-sized enterprises and to promote access by Italian banks to the liquidity offered by the Eurosystem.
Second tranche of the credit guarnatee facility for SMEs.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: EUR 400 million credit line to most affected sectors such as tourism and transport

Measures to help restructure agricultural credits, digitalise SMEs through grants and loans to finance investment in digital equipment or solutions for remote working conditions (programme Acelera PYME, EUR 250 million) to facilitate teleworking, and facilitate the suspension of public contracts and prevent external (outside the EU) takeovers of Spanish firms in strategic sectors

Extension of the moratorium on mortgage payments (announced on March 17 for vulnerable groups) to offices/commercial premises of the self-employed impacted by the crisis, and from 1 month to 3 months.
A three-month credit moratorium on the payment of credits and non-mortgage loans by vulnerable groups.
Suspension of interest and loan payments for entrepreneurs in the tourism industry for one year.

The BCRA extended until September 30 the prohibition to financial institutions to charge fees or commissions for operations (deposits, withdrawals, consultations, etc.) carried out through all the ATMs authorized and operated in the country by them, without limits of amount. It also extended the validity of the limit to make withdrawals by ATMs per day and in a single withdrawal, of at least up to $ 15,000 regardless of the financial institution and / or the ATM network to which it belongs.

Banxico Circular 13 - legal certainty to financial entities subject to the Credit Card Rules and Provisions for the Determination of the Minimum Payment for Credit Cards, financial Institutions will not be obliged to collect minimum payment amounts for the periods payment between April and July of this year.

The crediting procedures have been simplified, according to which the real estate estimation temporarily does not require the on-site visit. The requirement related to the updating of the financial statement has been eased as well.

Banks were reminded about their responsibility in implementing stimulus package and were instructed to process loans under stimulus package quickly and set up a help desk at branch level  to help the borrowers.
Term deposit taking non-bank financial institutions are required to maintain CRR at a rate 1.5 percent on bi-weekly basis

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Full interest waiver to individuals and businesses for 3 months (July - Sep 2020) followed by partial waiver (50 percent) for additional six months (Oct 2020 - March 2021) from National Relief Fund; Estimated to cost Ngu 7.5 bn (US$ 100 million).

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Those repaying loans on time are given rebate of 1 percentage points by FIs.
Expired term loans segregated into viable and non-viable loans; viable loans shall be rescheduled and non-viable ones foreclosed.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: For business continuity, new soft-term bridging loans at concessional interest of 5 perecnt; Similarly, micro loans to agriculture at 2 percent and Cottage & Small Industry (CSI) loans at 4 percent, with a tenor of 12 months, to be extended by National CSI Development Bank.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Conversion of Concessional Working Capital Loan Scheme (Tourism, Wholesale and Manufaturing sectors) to Bridge Loans for Business Continuity on a terminating basis over 2-4 year; Interest accrued on the Working Capital Loan shall be capitalized on June 30, 2020 and amortized.
Government and Central bank to make in-depth assessment of Non-Performing Loan (NPL) from July 2020 to facilitate rehabilitations and/or foreclose loans.
Easing of other prudential measures (income recognition & asset classification, CAR and SLR) shall be done upon consultation with financial institutions.

The guidelines for preferential allotment of shares were modified to allow allotment of shares at a price not lower than the average of the weekly high and low of the volume weighted average price during two weeks preceding the relevant date.
The relaxations from compliance for REITs and InvITs were extended by 1 month.
In  view  of  the prevailing situation due  to  COVID-19  pandemic and  representation received from the Depositories, it has been decided to further extend the timelines for compliance by 2 months.
The relaxation of maximum time gap between two board/Audit Committee meetings has been extended by another month till July 31, 2020.

Announced a series of modifications to the regulations of the Guarantee Fund for Small Business Owners (Fogape), with the aim of perfecting this instrument and, in this way, contributing to more SMEs can access credits with a state guarantee from the State. Among the main modifications are the reduction of the deductible and the extension of guarantees for small businesses.

Decided to indefinitely maintain the ease of repos with portfolio securities. In other words, the biweekly repos auctions with portfolio titles will continue as long as deemed necessary. Previously, the Board had authorized these auctions for a maximum accumulated amount of COP 6.3 trillion.
Reduced its interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point to 2.50%.

Level 3 policy measures: Reduce non-essential regulatory reporting requirements for banks
Details of the measure: Allowed Italian financial institutions to defer sending their financial records (DAC2/MCAA/IGA) to the Agency of Revenue Information for the year 2020. The former deadline was June 30, 2020. The new deadline is September 30, 2020. This deferral affects the information exchanged with other EU Member States, other non-EU countries, and with the United States.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Altered the eligibility for the "Future Fund" credit facility. This means that companies that have participated in accelerator programmes are now eligible for the Future Fund. Companies will still be required to meet the "substantive economic presence" tests (that half or more employees are based in the United Kingdom, or that half or more of the revenues are from the United Kingdom sales).

Set out the Prudential Regulatory Authority's (PRA) views on the amendments to the Capital Requirements Regulation (CRR) first introduced on June 27, 2020, in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. The CRR includes: transnational arrangements for capital impact of International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) 9 Expected Credit Loss (ECL) accounting, the acceleration of certain CRR II measures that were initially scheduled to begin on June 28, 2021. and discretion to apply a temporary prudential filter to certain unrealised gains/losses measured at fair value through other comprehensive income.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Cleared legislation to extend the deadline for businesses to apply for coronavirus aid under the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP), which will expire at the end of Tuesday.

Established a new extension, until July 17, 2020, of the suspension of the exchange and financial summary proceedings instructed in the terms of the Foreign Exchange Penal Regime Laws No. 19,359 and of Entities Financial No. 21,526, respectively, without prejudice to the validity of the procedural acts that are carried out in said period as the intervention of the accused is not necessary in them.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Allocated HUF 100 billion in development funding for SMEs

Passed Emergency Decree 076-2020 in order to create the Business Support Fund for the Mype of the Tourism Sector (FAE Tourism), with a specialized guarantee fund of PEN 500 million. In addition to this, the norm establishes the transfer of PEN 50 million for the development of a new contest for the Tourism Emprende program.

Announced that Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac (the Enterprises) are allowing servicers to extend forbearance agreements for multifamily property owners with existing forbearance agreements for up to three months, for a total forbearance of up to six months.
Extended payment moratorium until 30 September from 30 June
Decided to conduct simultaneous purchase and sale of government securities under Open Market Operations (OMO) for ÔøΩÔøΩ_10,000 crores each on July 02, 2020.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Expanded the limit on its preferential (2% annual) loan program for the sectors most affected by the coronavirus. The Russian government increased the subsidies provided to banks by RUB 3.3 billion, bringing the total to RUB 15.75 billion. The government also raised the limits of loan guarantees by RUB 100 billion. This is the second expansion of the program, which was first implemented on June 1, 2020.

Decided to implement a Credit Guarantee and Interest Subsidy Scheme to accelerate lending by banks to businesses adversely affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. This scheme, which will be launched on July 1, 2020, will operate in parallel with the Saubagya COVID-19 Renaissance Facility and the new Facility approved by the Monetary Board under Section 83 of the Monetary Law Act, within the already announced threshold of LKR 150 billion.

Announced that Indonesian Exports Financing Agency (LPEI) and PT Bank Mandiri Tbk will guarantee bank loans in order to increase export financing and support the National Economic Recovery (PEN) from the impact of Covid-19.

Extended a series of measures introduced to limit negative consequences for citizens and other participants in the Russian financial system and economy. Many of these measures were set to expire on July 1, 2020, but have now been prolonged until September 30, 2020. The measures include the relaxation of in-person requirements for transactions such as obtaining a loan, fee waivers for selected late financial disclosures/documents/reports, and the resumption of supervisory activities that were paused at the onset of the coronavirus outbreak.

Level 3 policy measures: Reduce non-essential regulatory reporting requirements for banks
Details of the measure: PRA's approach to regulatory reporting and Pillar 3 disclosures in response to the Covid-19 outbreak, following the European Banking Authority's (EBA) statement. On June 26, PRA concluded that it would not be appropriate to continue to accept late submissions of Pillar 3 disclosures. The Bank noted that the Prudential Regulatory Authority will continue to take a flexible approach to submissions, but expects that Pillar 3 disclosures should not be affected by COVID-19 in most cases.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Authorized new lines of financing for MSMEs at a subsidized rate of 24%, which includes a special tranche for investment in capital goods of national origin and another with minimum requirements for companies that have not previously had access to credit.

Level 3 policy measures: Reduce non-essential regulatory reporting requirements for banks
Details of the measure: Extended the deadline for the presentation of the Interim and Annual Financial Statements (EECC), closing date May 31, 2020, and Intermediate EECC, closing date June 30, 2020, of all entities and investment instruments under controller of this organism. The measures were adopted within the framework of the social, preventive and mandatory isolation that has been in force since March 20, 2020, to confront the pandemic due to the COVID-19.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Announced a new AUD 250 million targeted package to help restart the creative economy and get the entertainment, arts and screen sectors back to work. A range of new grant and loan programs will roll out over the next 12 months to different parts of the arts sector.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Entered into a new agreement amounting to IRD 1.088 trillion in financing for Ultra Micro loans (UMi) through Financial Institutions UMi Financing Channels. IRD 400 billion will be earmarked for PT Pegadaian.
Decided to lower the target for the overnight interbank interest rate by 50 basis points to 5%.

Decided to cut the interest rate on the BSP's overnight reverse repurchase (RRP) facility by 50 basis points (bps) to 2.25 percent, effective Friday, 26 June 2020. The interest rates on the overnight deposit and lending facilities were reduced to 1.75 percent and 2.75 percent, respectively.

Level 3 policy measures: Use of recovery and resolution tools
Details of the measure: Launched a personal debt purchase program whereby lending institutions may sell non-collateralized delinquent personal debt to KAMCO, which in turn will take over individual debt and help debtors with debt adjustment plans.

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: Took several actions following its stress tests to ensure large banks remain resilient despite the economic uncertainty from the coronavirus event. For the third quarter of this year, the Board is requiring large banks to preserve capital by suspending share repurchases, capping dividend payments, and allowing dividends according to a formula based on recent income. The Board is also requiring banks to re-evaluate their longer-term capital plans.
Agreed to the suspension of deadlines for the care of institutions and people subject to supervision by the National Commission of Insurance and Bonds, due to the coronavirus called COVID-19.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Fintechs in Brazil, particularly, SCD are allowed to issue credit cards

Level 2 policy measures: Consumer protection measures and ensuring availability and acceptance of cash
Details of the measure: The central bank requested banks to mantain availability of branches for cash withdrawals and cheque deposits

Suspension of administrative deadlines - National Law of Administrative Procedures N ÔøΩ 19.549, Regulation of Administrative Procedures and other special procedures in the area of ÔøΩÔøΩ‹âÔøΩÔøΩPrevention of Money Laundering and Terrorism Financing.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: The central bank requested banks to send SMS to customers requesting usage of electronic payment mechanisms

Extended the deadline for compliance with the obligation imposed by RG 816/19 to apply to all Obligatory Subjects in the area of ÔøΩÔøΩ‹âÔøΩÔøΩPrevention of Money Laundering and Terrorism Financing. The measures were adopted within the framework of the social, preventive and mandatory isolation that has been in force since March 20, 2020 to confront the pandemic due to the COVID-19.
The central bank requested banks to review their business continuity scenarios and  implement business continuity plan

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Confirmed the third stage of the Work and Production Assistance Program, extending applications for the 0% interest loans until the end of July. In addition, the ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩPyme PlusÔøΩÔøΩ? credit line will be extended at a rate of 24% for the productive sector and 18% for cooperatives.

Defined the conditions for the purchase of private assets in the secondary market, provided for in Constitutional Amendment (EC) No. 106, of May 7, 2020. Assets with credit risk equivalent to BB- or higher, deposited in a central depository, not convertible into shares and with a maturity of 12 months or more will be eligible. For carrying out the operations, the reference prices published by Anbima and B3 will be taken into account. In order to better control risk, there will be limits in the BC's portfolio per issuer, per series of assets in the market and in relation to the risk classes of the assets.

SEBI/HO/CFD/CMD1/CIR/P/2020/38  dated  March  19,  2020, had relaxed  the  requirement  of  the  maximum stipulated  time  gap  of  120  days  between  two meetings of the board and Audit Committees of listed entities, as is required under Regulation 17(2) and 18(2)(a) of SEBI (Listing Obligations and Disclosure Requirements) Regulations, 2015 ('LODR Regulations'). This relaxation was provided for the meetings held/proposed to be held between the period December 1, 2019 and June 30, 2020

SEBI, vide circular No. SEBI/HO/DDHS/CIR/P/2020/42 dated March 23, 2020, had granted temporary relaxations in compliance requirements for REITs and InvITs owing to the impact of the CoVID-19 pandemic.

Deferment of Loan by one year without penal fees. Interest accrued during dferement shall not be compounded but capitalised at the end of deferred period. No penalty or fees during the deferment period.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: On June 29, 2020, the CBE issued a circular to amend its recent allocation of EGP 3 billion to helping tourism companies in paying the salaries of their employees as well as the expenses incurred for operating and maintaining their facilities. The amendments include the following: (i) Credit facilities could now be given for the payment of the salaries and wages of any three months, to be calculated from the date on which financing is given. In other words, they need not specifically be May, June, and July 2020. (ii) The loan period is now two years excluding the one-year grace period. In other words, tourism companies benefiting from the initiative could repay banks over a period of two years after the one-year grace period, increasing the tenor of the loan. (iii) Tourism companies are no longer required to submit proof, from a CBE-registered auditor, that they did not reduce their workforce or decrease wages since December 2019 in order to benefit from the initiative.

Level 2 policy measures: Consumer protection measures and ensuring availability and acceptance of cash
Details of the measure: The CBE is helping banks to roll out 6.5k ATMs across the country as part of a wider plan to add 20k machines nationwide as part of its financial inclusion and digitization strategy.
Mortgage payment holidays. The government has agreed with mortgage lenders that they will offer repayment holidays of 3 months to households in financial difficulty due to COVID-19
Enactment of the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) Flexibility Act that lessen the burden of PPP loans on borrowers  via a modified loan forgiveness
Trading on the Zimbabwe stock exchange was suspended "until further notice."

The central bank of the Czech Republic lowered the countercyclical capital buffer rate from the current level of 1% to 0.5%, effective on July 1, 2020, and reiterated that it was ready to release the buffer fully if needed.

On July 1, 2020, the refinancing rate will be brought down from 8% to 7.75% per annum; the rate on overnight credits ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ from 9% to 8.75% per annum; and the rate on overnight deposits ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ from 7% to 6.75% per annum.
Armenia's central bank cut the refinancing rate from 5% to 4.5%.
Armenia central bank cuts key refinancing rate to 5.0%.
Georgia's central bank cut its key refinancing rate from 8.50% to 8.25%.
Remove 6% penalty for commercial banks to access credit from BoB.
Extension of maturity for repos/reverse repurchase agreements; and Inclusion of all corporate bonds listed at BSE in the collateral pool.

BCC (in coordination with the financial sector association, Apbef) to put in place a mechanism to grant debt service postponements without fees or penalties to support individuals and businesses affected by the Covid-19 crisis (on a case by case basis).
The policy rate was reduced to 10%.
Insurance companies have been asked to suspend loan repayments for three months as well as suspend installment payments

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: To encourage the use of non-cash payments, the CBL has negotiated with mobile network operators the removal of fees for transactions below M50 and temporarily raised mobile money transaction limits.
The Board of Governors of the Central Bank of Liberia (CBL), during its 28 May 2020 sitting, approved a reduction in monetary policy rate to 25%.

Since the beginning of this month, BFM has injected MGA 420 billion through auctions, and plans to inject a minimum of MGA 200 billion by the end of the month. At the same time, BFM provides banks with the marginal lending facility, the daily amount of which is currently around MGA 50 billion for the entire banking system

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Encourage the use of digital means of payment, including mobile money, checks and transfers. This will limit movement and contact between people. BFM undertakes to take the necessary measures to support the issuance of electronic money by electronic money institutions
Immediately provide a three-month moratorium on interest and principal repayments for loans by borrowers on a case by case basis
Restructure and refinance or renegotiate loans for small and medium scale enterprises, corporates and other borrowers affected by COVID-19 on a case by case basis

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Reduce by forty (40) percent fees and charges related to internet banking, mobile payments and any other related services, except for POS and visa and master card related payments, in order to encourage usage of electronic payment transactions

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: Defer all payments of bonuses and dividends until the risk of COVID-19 is under control.

Reduced the Liquidity Reserve Requirement (LRR) on domestic currency deposits, thereby releasing K12 billion as additional liquidity availed to banks to directly support borrowers that are distressed as a result of COVID-19
Reduced Lombard Rate margin by 50 percent to reduce the cost of accessing funds from the Central Bank and enable banks to pass on the benefits to borrowers
Activate the Emergency Liquidity Assistance Facility and make it available to banks on a case by case basis

Level 3 policy measures: Use of recovery and resolution tools
Details of the measure: Approve the recapitalisation plan under the Prompt Corrective Action (PCA) Directive beyond 90 days in the unlikely event of a bank breaching the Prudential Capital Requirement Directive as a result of COVID-19

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Grant relief to banks on the provisioning of restructured loans and loans on moratorium impacted by COVID-19.
A drop in the reserve requirement rate from 7% to 5%
Establishment of a currency swap mechanism against Ouguiyas at an interest rate of 0%.
Mauritian households impacted by COVID-19 may request their commercial banks for a moratorium of six (6) months on capital repayments on their existing household loans as from the 1st of April 2020.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: In addition, for households earning a combined monthly basic salary of up to Rs50,000 the Bank of Mauritius will bear the interest payable for the period 1st of April 2020 to 30th of June 2020 on their outstanding household loans with commercial banks.

The Bank of Mauritius is introducing a Special Foreign Currency (USD) Line of Credit targeting operators having foreign currency earnings, including SMEs. This line of credit shall be for an amount of USD300 million, to be made available through commercial banks. Funds will be made available to commercial banks at 6-month USD Libor for this facility. This line of credit will be available from the 24th  of March 2020 until the 30th of June 2020 and repayment will be over a period of two (2) years from the effective date of disbursement.
The Bank of Mauritius is introducing a USD/MUR swap arrangement with commercial banks for an initial amount of USD100 million

Level 2 policy measures: Consumer protection measures and ensuring availability and acceptance of cash
Details of the measure: During the national confinement period, fees applicable on shared ATM services have been waived to enable customers to have access to the ATM of any bank regardless of the issuer of the card.

In light of ongoing developments, the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) of the Bank of Mauritius has, under the Chairmanship of the Governor, today 16 April 2020, unanimously decided to reduce the Key Repo Rate (KRR) by 100 basis points, from 2.85 per cent to 1.85 per cent per annum.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: The interest rate on advances to impacted economic operators under the Special Relief Amount, initially capped by the Bank of Mauritius at the fixed rate of 2.50 per cent per annum, now stands at 1.50 per cent per annum.
