Details of the measure: The loan should not be reclassified and credit institutions should not set up provisions for loans, as a result of restructuring.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: No Fees to Be Charged by Banks and Other Payment Service Providers on Donation Payments to Fight COVID-19.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in capital requirement (definition of capital, car, risk weights)
Details of the measure: Banks will be allowed to operate temporarily below the level of capital defined by the Pillar 2 Guidance (P2G).

Level 3 policy measures: Prioritize or review critical supervisory actions
Details of the measure: As regards the conduct of NBS on-site inspections of supervised institutions in the financial sector, individual activities will be postponed and modified so as to focus inspections on institutions' most important operations.

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: The Bank of Slovenia has adopted a macroprudential measure placing temporary restrictions on banks and savings banks in their profit distribution.
Banks will be allowed to exclude months that see a temporary decline in income as a result of the Covid-19 epidemic from their calculations of consumer creditworthiness.

Decreased the required reserves ratio of credit financial institutions for savings and other similar liabilities are temporarily to 1% in national currency and 5% in foreign currency from 1 April to 31 December, 2020.

In order to protect the interests of consumers of financial services, credit financial institutions may temporarily stop the work of their troubled and unprofitable banking service centers by August 1, 2020.

Depending on the available opportunities and financial situation of customers, they can extend and restructure some of their customers' loans, as well as provide grace periods for some borrowers who have financial problems.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Commercial banks were given the right not to change the classification of loan quality, the terms of which were revised on the basis of the above recommendations.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: According to the rules approved, the loans that have been serviced as of 1 March 2020 and restructured before the end of September 2020 shall not be considered as those attributed with certain signs of default.
NBU Launches Electronic License for Conducting Hryvnia Remittances without Opening Accounts.

Level 3 policy measures: Promoting digital channels in line with aml/cft requirements (via e-kyc, digital signature, and online document
Details of the measure: The main advantage of the new law is the remote identification and verification of customers. From now on, a visit to a branch or a personal meeting with a bank representative is not required to open an account in a new bank.
A revision is made to the reserve requirement regulation that links the reserve requirement ratios and remuneration rates to loan growth rates.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Provided clarification and extended the period of forbearance measures.

The legal reserve rate for cash deposits in national currency cut from 6% to 5.5%, while in foreign currency this rate decreased from 13.5% to 10%. Regarding deposits in securities and DPF in national currency, the reserve requirement decreased from 5% to 4.5%. Meanwhile, in foreign currency they remain 10% for DPFs greater than 720 days and a drop from 18% to 11% for other liabilities.
The Board of Directors of the Central Bank of Costa Rica (BCCR), in session on June 17, 2020, agreed to reduce the Monetary Policy Rate (TPM) by 50 basis points (p.b.), to locate it at 0.75%
Regulatory Deadlines for insurance sector: The Bank of Guyana has postponed the 30 March 2020 deadline for the submission of the 2019 Annual Supervisory Filing to 30 June 2020.
Onsite Inspections for insurance companies: All scheduled onsite inspections by the Bank of Guyana have been suspended until further notice. However, offsite monitoring of all insurer continues.
Insurance companies are encouraged to grant a 60 day moratorium on cancellations and non-renewals for non-payment of premiums, beginning April 6, 2020.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Companies are to expedite the use of online payments channels  via the use of credit cards, online banking, service providers such as Sure pay, MMG, etc.

Bank of Jamaica has reduced the cash reserve requirements of deposit-taking institutions (DTIs) by two percentage points, effective 15 May 2020. The foreign currency cash reserve requirement has been reduced to thirteen per cent (13%) while the domestic currency cash reserve requirement has been reduced to five per cent (5%).
A special USD Repurchase Facility is being established by Bank of Jamaica to provide US Dollar liquidity to Financial Institutions (FIs).

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: On May 26, 2020, , the National Microfinance Commission, introduced a temporary reform (from July 1, 2020 until June 30, 2021) to the ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩNorm on Credit Risk Management for Microfinance InstitutionsÔøΩÔøΩ? in order to reduce the specific provisioning requirements for the portfolios of personal loans held by these institutions.

On June 15, 2020, the BCN temporarily reduced reserve requirements in domestic currency from July 1, 2020 to June 30, 2021. During this period, banks can reduce the ratio of required reserves in domestic currency to as low as 4.5 percent (from 15 percent), if they extend credits to the private sector.

On June 19, 2020, the Superintendence of Banks and Other Financial Institutions (SIBOIF) issued a temporary financial regulation, allowing banks and other financial institutions to negotiate, at the request of their clients, an increase in the maturity of their loans and/or a moratorium on monthly payments of up to 6 months on credits granted before March 31, 2020, subject to certain safeguards. Borrowers can request to benefit from this measure until December 31, 2020.

On the same date, the SIBOIF issued another temporary financial regulation reducing the minimum monthly payment for credit cards from 3 to 2 percent of the total debt, including interests. This measure will be in force until March 31, 2021.
Paraguay cuts Policy Interest Rate to 1.25 % (- 1.00).

Level 2 policy measures: Consumer protection measures and ensuring availability and acceptance of cash
Details of the measure: Uninterrupted access to self-service terminals (e.g. ATMs, cash deposit machines) at all branches and accessible locations under the Government's Movement Control Order;

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: The following must be available during the Movement Order Control: Electronic banking, mobile banking, money changing and remittance services, payment card services and any other online services

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: The National Bank of Moldova stated that the bank, licensed banks and non-bank payment service providers will continue their activity, providing all financial services. The National Bank also encouraged the use of cashless payment methods.

Level 2 policy measures: Consumer protection measures and ensuring availability and acceptance of cash
Details of the measure: The NBM urged citizens not to disclose any information about their bank cards.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Announced that Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac (the Enterprises) will extend several loan origination flexibilities until August 31, 2020 to ensure continued support for borrowers during the COVID-19 national emergency. These include alternative appraisals on purchase and rate term refinance loans;, alternative methods for documenting income and verifying employment before loan closing, and expanding the use of power of attorney and remote online notarizations to assist with loan closings.

Decided to reduce the Standing Deposit Facility Rate (SDFR) and the Standing Lending Facility Rate (SLFR) of the Central Bank by 100 basis points each, to 4.50 per cent and 5.50 per cent, respectively.

Decided for the fourth time to reissue the special anti-epidemic government bonds for 2020 (10-year term), tendering on July 15. The total face value of competitive bidding will be RMB 70 billion. Interest will be calculated beginning on July 16.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Simplified the requirements for Russian Microfinance Institutions (MFIs) to obtain loans and guarantees as part of anti-crisis support for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). Application requirements were softened.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: On June 30th the authorities launched the phase two of the ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩReactiva PeruÔøΩÔøΩ? program, with five auction sessions totaling S/ 17.7 billion at an average interest rate of 1.49 percent and a with greater share of small and micro enterprises.

Created two new credit guarantee programs as part of the 'United for Colombia' initiative. Each will have a quota of COP 6 billion and will be available to large companies affected by the COVID-19 pandemic.

Announced an extension and expansion of the previous framework for deferring loan repayments, as follows: The period for submitting a request for a deferral of loan repayments for mortgages, consumer credit and business credit will be extended to October 30, 2020. Customers who have already received a deferral of mortgage repayments will be able to defer the payments until the end of 2020, even if the deferral exceeds 6 months. Customers who have not yet deferred mortgage repayments, and ask to do so, will be able to defer the payments for 6 months. Finally, Consumer loans up to NIS 100,000: Customers will be able to defer such loans for up to 6 months (at the customers' choice) without the bank's judgment, as opposed to the previous framework in which the deferral was for 3 months.

Announced a package of new measures to support middle-class families who have seen their income affected by the Covid-19 pandemic. The government expanded access to credit with a state guarantee scheme for higher education.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Announced a package of new measures to support middle-class families who have seen their income affected by the Covid-19 pandemic. The government will offer solidarity loans with a real interest rate equal to 0%, adjusted with inflation.

Extended the term of validity of Negative Debt Certificates (CND) and Positive Certificates with Negative Effects (CNEND) for another 30 days, both relating to federal tax credits and the Union's active debt.

Confirmed support for users of motor finance, buy-now pay-later (BNPL), rent-to-own (ROT), pawnbroking and high-cost short-term credit (HCSTC) products, who continue to face payment difficulties due to coronavirus (COVID-19). The support measures include debtor relief. Examples include a ban on repossessions until October 31, 2020, and the expansion of payment freezes on debt payments.
Announced that a corporate asset sell-off support program will begin to accept applications beginning on July 17.

Decided to lift administrative sanctions and grant a 30-day extension of deadline for companies that are unable to meet the quarterly or semi-annual reporting deadline of August 14 due to pandemic-related disruption in their business operation.

The BCRP will continue to take the necessary steps to support the payments system and the credit channel. In March the BCRP has implemented liquidity easing via one-day repos (S/ 1,400 million per day on average) and 6 month- and one-year repos (S/ 1,400 and S/ 1,500 million, respectively).
The Board of Directors of the Central Reserve Bank of Peru (BCRP) decided to lower the reference interest rate by 100 basis points, from 1.25 to 0.25 percent.
Amended Article 22 of the Bank Cards and Credit Cards Law (5464), increasing limits on retail transactions from TRY 1300 to TRY 2000.

Decided to permit listed Issuers  who have issued NCDs/NCRPS/CPs,  on  or  after  July  01,  2020  and intend/propose  to  list  such issued NCDs/NCRPS/CPs, on or before July 31, 2020, to use available financials as of December 31,2019.

Decided for the first time to issue the special anti-epidemic government bonds for 2020 (four periods; 10-year term), tendering on July 21. The total face value of competitive bidding will be RMB 70 billion. Interest will be calculated beginning on July 16.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Providing credit facilities in SRD at 7.5% interest for the private sector.

The CBvS offers commercial banks the opportunity to grant payment deferments for 3 to 6 months to companies, institutions and individuals who are affected by the negative effects of the COVID-19 crisis.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Extended until October 2020 loan benefits under the Emergency Assistance to Work and Production (ATP) program for the performing arts sector.

FSB supported the Basel Committee statement on buffer usage and announced that supervisors have agreed that banks will be given sufficient time to restore buffers, taking into account economic and market conditions and individual bank circumstances.
Bulgarian banks agreed with the central bank to extend the moratorium on bank loan repayments from the end of December 2020 until the end of March 2021.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: The European Commission said it has approved Slovenia's 222 million euro ($251 million) scheme aiming to back companies hit by the coronavirus pandemic. The public support will be provided via subsidised interest rates or loans and will be open to all companies.
At its meeting today, the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) of Bank Negara Malaysia decided to reduce the Overnight Policy Rate (OPR) by 25 basis points to 1.75 percent.

With nearly $28 billion bond-buying program without receiving interest, BI aims to help fund the economic recovery from the pandemic. BI will also be a standby buyer and help pay some interest rate expenses for 177 trillion rupiah worth of bonds that the government will sell in auctions to fund recovery schemes for some businesses. BI is set to pay the spread between market rates and its 3-month reverse repurchase rate minus one percentage point.

Level 2 policy measures: Consumer protection measures and ensuring availability and acceptance of cash
Details of the measure: The Central Bank of Liberia announced additional LD4 Billion Liberian Dollar banknotes to ease the demand for currency.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Parliament adopted a law on payment services and payment service providers, which includes the right to an electronic account.

The Central Bank of Eswatini (CBE) amended the domestic markets liquidity management framework and Open Market Operations tools, to enhance its liquidity management operations and introduce new operational tools. The CBE is moving towards a more active approach to domestic liquidity management with the ultimate objective of targeting a specific range for the level of excess liquidity in the domestic market that the CBE judges as consistent with maintaining the Foreign exchange currency peg to the South African rand.

In a bid to increase the foreign exchange flows into the country while controlling the flow of foreign exchange to other countries, the Government has decided to extend the validity period of the Gazette Notification (Extraordinary Gazette No. 2169/3 dated 02.04.2020) relating to controlling foreign exchange outflows issued on April 2, 2020 for a further six months w.e.f. July 2, 2020.

The GoSL on July 13, 2020 has taken further measures to encourage opening of SDAs as stated below. 1. Expansion of the sources of funding SDAs a. Any person who has arrived in Sri Lanka from overseas on or after 01.01.2020 can open SDAs with any Authorized Dealer on or before 07.10.2020, out of foreign exchange legitimately acquired and brought into Sri Lanka by such person subject to: i. a declaration made to the Sri Lanka Customs at the port of arrival where the amount of such foreign exchange exceeds USD 15,000 or an equivalent amount in any designated foreign currencies. ii. a declaration to the relevant Authorized Dealer where the amount of such foreign exchange is equal or less than USD 15,000 or an equivalent amount in any designated foreign currencies. b. Any person in, or resident in, Sri Lanka can open SDAs with any Authorized Dealer on or before 07.10.2020, out of foreign currency notes in his possession up to the limit of USD 15,000 and subject to such terms and conditions of the prevailing Regulations and Orders, subject to a declaration on the source of funds to the Authorized Dealer.  c. In this regard, the amount of foreign currency that can be retained by a person in, or resident in Sri Lanka in his possession has been increased from USD 10,000 to USD 15,000 with effect from 01.07.2020.

Modified the Main Street Lending Program to provide greater access to credit for nonprofit organizations such as educational institutions, hospitals, and social service organizations. The Fed lowered the minimum number employees required for nonprofits to qualify, eased donation-based funding, and adjusted several financial eligibility criteria to accommodate a wider range of nonprofit operating models.
Suspended the deadlines for the care of institutions and people subject to supervision by the National Commission of Insurance and Bonds, due to the coronavirus called COVID-19.

Announced the official launch of the special purpose vehicle intended to support businesses facing liquidity problems by purchasing corporate bonds and CP on July 17. The SPV's bond purchasing program will be operated on a temporary basis for six months from July 14, 2020 until January 13, 2021, with the possibility of extension afterwards.
Lowered the BI 7-day Reverse Repo Rate by 25 bps to 4.00%, Deposit Facility (DF) rate by 25 bps to 3.25% and Lending Facility (LF) rate by 25 bps to 4.75%.

Decided renew the special anti-epidemic government bonds for 2020 (four periods; 10-year term), tendering on July 23. The total face value of competitive bidding will be RMB 70 billion. Interest will be calculated from July 16.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in capital requirement (definition of capital, car, risk weights)
Details of the measure: Created the Working Capital program for the Preservation of Companies (CGPE). The new program complements and assists previous measures to combat the economic effects of Covid-19, generating new incentives for access to credit for companies with revenues of up to BRL 300 million, the so-called micro and small and medium-sized companies.

Reduced FX reserve requirement ratios by 300 basis points for banks that met real credit growth conditions, and released USD 5.1 billion in market liquidity. Additionally, banks that met real credit growth conditions for the first time were provided with approximately USD 9.2 billion of liquidity, and thus, a total amount of USD 14.3 billion of liquidity was provided to the banking system.

Announced the "SME Leasing of Equipment and Tools" program, which was the fourth government support program granted to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) within the National Investment and Economic Recovery plan. The Ministry of Public Finance will guarantee individual loans worth up to RON 5 million; the size of the guarantee depends on the intended use of the loan. The loans will be provided by the National Credit Guarantee Fund for Small and Medium Sized Enterprises SA - IFN (FNGCIMM SA - IFN), a state-owned non-bank financial institution.
Introduced new repo operations in the amount of PEN 970 million at an interest rate of 2.53%.
The ECB and National Bank of Serbia set up a repo line of ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ1 billion with three month maturities to remain in place until June 2021.
The ECB and Bank of Albania set up a repo line of ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ400 million with 3 month maturities that will operate until June 2021.

Level 3 policy measures: Reduce non-essential regulatory reporting requirements for banks
Details of the measure: Changed the terms for specialized depository institutions to draw up and submit reports during 2020. On July 10, 2020, the Bank of Russia (BoR) Board of Directors postponed the original deadlines established by the BoR, and on July 20, 2020, the postponements were legalized.
SEBI announced it would extend the regulatory measures announced on March 20, 2020 to August 27, 2020.
The Central Bank prohibits buying dollars from IFE beneficiaries
The CB decided to ease restrictions on the purchase of dollars at the official value and simplify the requirements established so that companies can access the Single and Free Exchange Market (MULC)
The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic (BCRD) announced that it will be expanding its operations in foreign currency installments without delivery (NDFs) to avoid capital outflows.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: BOJ formally invited interested digital currency providers  to develop and test potential CBDC solutions in its recently established Fintech Regulatory Sandbox.
Adjustments to repo operations with corporate securities.

Banco de MÃ©xico announces adjustments in its operation in the interbank funding, on the date of entry into force of the decisions of monetary policy and the mechanics of calculating interest in open market operations.
The Board of Governors of Banco de MÃ©xico decided to decrease by 50 basis points the objective for the overnight Interbank Interest Rate at a level of 5%.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Government of Mexico announces extension of Regulatory Facilities in the Financial and Housing Sectors.

Level 3 policy measures: Relief measures on customer identification (e.g. simplified cdd even in case of non-face-to-face relationships)
Details of the measure: Regulatory facilities regarding face-to-face identification for credit institutions.

BB allows loan rescheudling for COVID affected borrowers of leather and leather goods sector ahead of Eid ul Adha when raw leathers are procured at bulk. Rescheudling with two percent down payment will allow current loans and term loans to flow to this sector to continue business. Commercial banks can do it by themselves based on banker-customer relationship.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Special loan classification and provisioning are announced for the CMSMEs. Past due or overdue for six months but less than 18 is substandard, 18 months but less than 30 is doubtful and 30 months or beyond is bad/loss.

Decided to renew for the third time the special anti-epidemic government bonds for 2020 (four periods; 10-year term), tendering on July 28. The total face value of competitive bidding will be RMB 70 billion. Interest will be calculated from July 16 and the coupon rate will be 2.86%.

Debt moratorium of banks extended by 6 months (mid-January 2021) for low impact, 9 months (mid-April 2021) for medium and 1 year for highly impacted (mid-July 2021) sectors; MFIs allowed to extend debt moratorium by 6 months (up to mid-January 2021)

In case of failure to complete the construction of or operate the industry or project within the grace period due to COVID-19, one-time grace period will be extended by maximum 2 years for tourist level hotel, 1 year for loan provided to highly affected sector, 9 months for loan provided to moderately affected sector and 6 months for loan provided to low affected sector.
The policy rate was decreased from 9.5% to 9%.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: The NBT exempted credit financial institutions from paying a fee for interbank settlements carried out through the systems of the NBT, including through the Interbank Automated System (RTGS) and the Interbank Automated System (ABS) until September 01, 2020 and recommended that credit financial institutions review interbank fees for their clients.

Serbia's central bank is introducing a preferential remuneration rate for banks that are issuing dinar-denominated loans under a guarantee scheme aimed at mitigating the negative impact of the COVID-19 crisis.
FED cuts Funds Rate to 1.00 - 1.25 % (- 0.50).
Bahrain cuts Key Policy Rate to 1.75 % (- 0.50)
Pakistan cuts Policy Rate to 12.50 % (- 0.75)
Namibia cuts Repo Rate to 4.25 % (- 1.00)
Rwanda cuts Key Repo Rate to 4.50 % (- 0.50)
Serbia cuts Key Policy Rate to 1.25 % (- 0.25)
The GoSL introduced the Special Deposit Account (SDA) on 08.04.2020 to seek assistance for the national effort to overcome the effects of COVID-19 outbreak in the country.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Obtaining loans against SDAs: SDA holders can obtain loans from Authorized Dealers against SDAs as follows; a. Residents in Sri Lanka Rupees b. Non-resident SDA holders who are eligible to obtain loans as per the prevailing regulations"
Controlling foreign exchange outflows, issued on April 2, 2020.
Australia will ramp up support for small businesses hit by the pandemic, offering guaranteed loans of up to A$1 million ($698,000) to about 3.5 million firms.
The Philippines cut reserve ratios for thrift banks to 3% and to 2% for rural and cooperative banks from July 31.
On 24 July 2020, the Bank of Russia Board of Directors decided to cut the key rate by 25 bp to 4.25% per annum.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in capital requirement (definition of capital, car, risk weights)
Details of the measure: CBR Board of Directors approved extension of application of lower risk weights (70%) to the loans issued to the manufacturers of pharmaceutical and medical equipment through the end of 2021.  Risk weights on loans to non-commodity exporters guranteed by EXIAR (The Russian Agency for Export Credit and Investment Insurance) were lowered from 20% to 0%.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Additional 98 mln USD microfinance preferential loans will be channeled through three state-owned banks under the state-program "One Family One Entreprenuer".
Reduction in refinancing rate from 11.75% to 10.75%.

Extension by the ned of July of the measure according to which families and companies affected by the contingency were not obliged to pay the financial institutions the capital and / or interest on their loans.

Fonacot implements Relief Plan for accredited workers that allows to postpone payments, without extra charges and without affecting the history credit. The measure applies to monthly payments in April and May In the face of the health emergency derived from the COVID-19 pandemic.
Fonacot to extend until 31 July the Its Releave Plan (Plan de Alivio Fonacot).

Broadened the set of firms eligible to transact with and provide services in three emergency lending facilities. Encouraging a broader range of agents for the Term Asset-Backed Securities Loan Facility (TALF) and counterparties for the Commercial Paper Funding Facility (CPFF) and Secondary Market Corporate Credit Facility (SMCCF) will increase the Federal Reserve's operational capacity and insight into the respective markets.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Approved a ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ2.6 billion (PLN 11.5 billion) Polish loan scheme to support companies affected by the coronavirus outbreak and to help maintain supply chains.

Agreed with the Magyar Nemzeti Bank to set up a repo line arrangement of ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ4 billion to provide euro liquidity to Hungarian financial institutions to remain in place until June 2021, unless an extension is decided. Max maturity will be three months.
Carried out a fourth exchange of local public debt by exchanging COP 3.9 billion in TES UVR 2021 Securities with the National Treasury for TES Securities maturing between 2030 and 2034.
Decided to pledge a sum of USD 1 billion worth of US Treasury Bonds held in the CBSL reserve and enter into the overnight repo facility with the Fed.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in capital requirement (definition of capital, car, risk weights)
Details of the measure: Introduced a new methodology for assessing credit risk to qualify for mortgages. The move was supposed to free up around RUB 300 billion of bank capital for expanded mortgage lending.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in capital requirement (definition of capital, car, risk weights)
Details of the measure: Reduced the risk ratio from a level of 20% to 0% on loans to non-commodity exporters covered by the Russian Agency for Export Credit and Investment Insurance (EXIAR).

Level 3 policy measures: Caps on interest rates or fees
Details of the measure: Cut the interest rates associated with loans to medical and pharmaceutical manufacturers by 70% until the end of 2021.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in capital requirement (definition of capital, car, risk weights)
Details of the measure: Reduced the risk ratio for private shares issued under debt-equity exchanges from a level of 150% to 100%, until mid-2022. The Bank of Russia (BoR) also postponed by one year an increase in the risk registered by banks that purchase capital issued by non-financial organizations. BoR also postponed by one year an increase the default debt risk ratio by one year to mitigate the period of arrears and the realization of credit risk due to the pandemic.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in capital requirement (definition of capital, car, risk weights)
Details of the measure: Reduced the risk ratio for investments in subordinated liabilities (including perpetual bonds) of non-financial organizations from a level of 150% to 100%. The decision was an attempt to incentivize the purchase of perpetual bonds issued by large companies, and boost investment activity during the recovery period.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Reduced the interest rate on loans from the Bank of Russia to creditors that offer loans to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) from a level of 2.5% to 2.25%.The decrease applied to both new and existing loans, with an aggregate limit of RUB 500 billion.
Eased the conditions of guaranteed loans, allowing a higher maximum loan amount and favorable contract terms.

Decided to renew for the fourth time the special anti-epidemic government bonds for 2020 (four periods; 10-year term), tendering on July 30. The total face value of competitive bidding will be RMB 70 billion. Interest will be calculated from July 16 and the coupon rate will be 2.86%.

Signed an agreement with the Central Bank of the People's Republic of China (PBoC) to increase the amount of the existing swap line from RMB 22,000 million to RMB 50,000 million, equivalent to approximately USD 7,100 million.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Allowed electronic payments of as little as one forint.
Published substantive updates to the Covid-19 Loan Guarantee Scheme, including loosening restrictions on eligibility and extending the draw-down period for current participants.

RBI signed a Currency Swap Agreement with the Central Bank of Sri Lanka under the SAARC Currency Swap Framework 2019-22. Under the agreement, Central Bank of Sri Lanka can make withdrawals of US Dollar, Euro or Indian Rupee in multiple tranches up to a maximum of USD 400 million or its equivalent. The agreement will be valid until November 13, 2022.

Announced an extension through December 31 of its lending facilities that were scheduled to expire on or around September 30. The three-month extension will facilitate planning by potential facility participants and provide certainty that the facilities will continue to be available to help the economy recover from the COVID-19 pandemic.

The Prudential Regulatory Authority (PRA) provided guidance and set expectations for all PRA-regulated firms about the EBA guidelines on COVID-19 reporting disclosures. The PRA specified the disclosure templates and timing.

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: Announced updates to the recommendations on the distribution of dividends. The Bank of Spain extended the ECB's recommendation on the distribution of dividends and variable remuneration to the least significant entities.

Approved the first portion of a line of guarantees worth EUR 8 billion: EUR 5 billion for the self-employed and small and mediums-sized enterprises (SMEs), and EUR 3 billion for other companies. The State guarantee covers 80% of new loans for self-employed workers and SMEs, and 70% for other companies. The Instituto de CrÃ©dito Official (ICO) will continue to manage this line.
Banca d'Italia updated capital buffer policies to be in line with the ECB's recommendations.

Committed to provide repayment flexibility to other individuals and all SME borrowers affected by COVID-19. The flexibility offered by each bank will take into account the specific circumstances of borrowers. This includes: allowing borrowers to pay only the interest portion of the loan over a period of time; lengthening the overall period of the loan to reduce monthly instalments; providing other forms of flexibility until a borrower is in a more stable position to resume repayments in full.

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: Updated its capital management guidance for banks and insurers, in particular easing restrictions around paying dividends as institutions continue to manage the disruption caused by COVID-19. In additional guidance for the banking sector, APRA has indicated that for the remainder of the calendar year boards should: seek to retain at least half of their earnings when making decisions on capital distributions (and utilise dividend reinvestment plans and other initiatives to offset the diminution in capital from capital distributions where possible); conduct regular stress testing to inform decision-making and demonstrate ongoing lending capacity; and make use of capital buffers to absorb the impacts of stress, and continue to lend to support households and businesses.

Announced an extension through December 31 of its lending facilities (the Term Asset-Backed Securities Loan Facility (TALF) and Secondary Market Corporate Credit Facility (SMCCF))  that were scheduled to expire on or around September 30. The three-month extension will facilitate planning by potential facility participants and provide certainty that the facilities will continue to be available to help the economy recover from the COVID-19 pandemic.
Chilean President Sebastian Pinera on Friday signed into law a plan to allow citizens to withdraw 10% of their pensions savings .

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: The National Bank extended until November 30 the simplified rules of credit risk assessment in the restructuring of loans made by banks in response to economic problems of borrowers caused by the pandemic of coronavirus COVID-19.

The Central Bank and lender organizations have developed mechanisms that allow for an individualized approach to the borrowers while precluding credit history from deterioration due to non-fulfillment of the payments under loan contract.

All restructuring facilities loan due to COVID 19 will be reported to Public Credit Registry managed by OJK (SLIK) with special mark/flagged notes (COVID 19), starting from March 2020. With this regard, Private Credit Bureau shall adjust the credit scoring for data with special mark. TK: It's captured as redit reporting and restructuring
The negative effects of credit records due to COVID-19 will not be reflected  to the credit history and current situation of the persons or firms.
Bangladesh Bank has announced credit guarantee facility to banks for working capital loans of cottage, micro and small enterprises.

Bank rate is reduced to 4 percent from 5 percent after 17 years, and overnight repo rate is reduced to 4.75 percent from 5.25 percent and reverse repo rate to 4 percent from 4.75 percent in the Monetary Policy Statement for FY2020-21, considering the COVID-19 crisis.
Authentication / certification of any filing / submission made to stock exchanges under   the   LODR Regulations may   be doneusingdigital   signature  certifications till December 31, 2020
Slashed its policy rate by 25 bps to 3.50% during it July 2020 meeting. The move follows a 50 bps cut in the May meeting, bringing borrowing costs to its lowest level on record

The South African Reserve Bank's Monetary Policy Committee has voted to cut the country's rates by a further 25 basis points. This takes the total cut in 2020 to 300 points, lowering the repo rate to 3.5% and the prime lending rate to 10%.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Authorities adjusted the fees for basic accounts, accounts of recipients of social protection/benefit transfers will pay a maximum fee of EUR 1.47

The NBS passed temporary regulation to allow that citizens that cannot withdraw money authorize a person to do so: ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩThe Instruction enabled certain categories of payment service users to request a payment of funds based on a one-off authorisation, which does not have to be certified by a public notary, and which the authorised person would present to the bank, along with the original and valid personal documents of both the person giving the authorisation and the person authorised thereby to request a payment from the account. This way, banks are obligated to enable the payment of funds from the account to a user who meets at least one of the following conditions: the user is a person aged 55 and older; the user is a person provided with adult accommodation services within the meaning of the law governing social protection;  the user is a person hospitalised in a health institution for medical treatment;    the user is a person whose working ability has been revoked or who does not have working ability; the user is a person deprived of freedom within the meaning of the law governing the execution of criminal sanctions; the user has not been issued a payment card with which they could make use of the funds in their current account.ÔøΩÔøΩ?

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: 20 March 2020: Instructions were issued to Financial Institutions to waive off registration fees and charges for providing online banking services

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: 06 April 2020: Considering the government's request, financial institutions were instructed to waive off fees charged from Senior citizens for cash withdrawals carried out through ATMs connected to the Common ATM Switch.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: 12 May 2020: Waived off the service charge on currency notes deposits (serviceable currency notes) by LCBs for three months period from 01 April 2020 to 30 June 2020 considering the pandemic situation.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Facilitate existing customers to register for online banking products without having to physically present themselves at bank branches for registration.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: 30 March 2020: In order to facilitate transactions of e-money account holders, approval was granted to increase the e-money wallet limit from Rs. 10,000 to Rs. 25,000 during this period temporarily.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: 01 April 2020: Increased the maximum per transaction value limit from Rs. 10,000 to Rs. 25,000 for mobile app based transactions carried out through JustPay payment solution of LankaClear (Pvt) Ltd.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: 10 April 2020: Enhanced limits applicable for merchants of a mobile phone based e-money system in order to facilitate more digital transactions during the period

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: 08 June 2020: Online payments by comstomers to government and other institutions through the LankaPay Online Payment Platform were further enabled through increasing the maximum per transaction value limit.

26 March 2020: Financial institutions were allowed to open wallet or wallet facilitation accounts by digitally fulfilling know your customer (KYC) requirements. However financial institutions were instructed to physically verify the KYC details subsequently

Level 2 policy measures: Consumer protection measures and ensuring availability and acceptance of cash
Details of the measure: 02 April 2020: Approval was granted to a remittance service provider to provide cash home-delivery services enabling disbursement of foreign remittances to be delivered to beneficiaries during the period.

Level 2 policy measures: Consumer protection measures and ensuring availability and acceptance of cash
Details of the measure: 04 April 2020: Considering the difficulty of withdrawing cash from ATMs during this period, approval was granted to a LCB to provide door-step cash delivery services
15 May 2020: Validity period of cheques of value less than Rs. 500,000 were extended.
04 June 2020: Validity period of cheques issued by Employees' Provident Fund Department (EPF) of the Central Bank were extended to 30 June 2020.
NBH cut policy rate from 0.75% to 0.6%.
The CBE announced a further cut to the discount rate of 25 basis points.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: More businesses can benefit from the Coronavirus Business Interruption Loan Scheme (CBILS) due to changes to EU state aid rules. Previously, business which were classified as "undertakings in difficulty" were unable to access CBILS. Starting July 30, 2020, businesses with fewer than 50 employees and a turnover of less than GBP 9 million can apply to CBILS.

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: Recommended companies to not distribute dividends, avoid the repurchase of ordinary shares, and refrain from paying variable pay until January 1, 2021.

Incorporated the European Banking Authority's guidelines on legislative and non-legislative moratoriums on loan payments in the context of COVID-19. The National Bank of Romania will carry out these guidelines in its supervisory activities.

Approved changes in the Management Regulations of Market Conduct of the Financial System, through SBS Resolution No. 1870-2020. In order to provide more alternatives to users when contracting a credit card, the issuing companies are required to have at least one card that does not charge a membership fee and that allows access to payment networks and infrastructure , without charging commissions.

Added a window for the purchase of Term Deposits for up to USD 8,000 million, which is open to the same participants as the previous window, that is, to all SOMA participants. This is in the context of the likely pressure on financial markets arising from the Government decision to allow withdrawal of pension funds by pensioners up to ten percent and the consequent need for the fund administrators to sell their assets (see measure 3221).

Announced the continuation of the Bank Bond purchase window for the remainder of USD 4.1 billion from the March program, which is intended to contain volatility scenarios. This is in the context of the likely pressure on financial markets arising from the Government decision to allow withdrawal of pension funds by pensioners up to ten percent and the consequent need for the fund administrators to sell their assets (see measure 3221).

Established a special program of spot purchase operations carried out jointly and simultaneously with the forward sale, on the open market, of eligible instruments issued by banking companies (CC-VP Program). Under this program, the Central Bank will buy, in cash, bank bonds and, jointly and simultaneously, will sell instruments of the same type in installments to the same counterparty. This is in the context of the likely pressure on financial markets arising from the Government decision to allow withdrawal of pension funds by pensioners up to ten percent and the consequent need for the fund administrators to sell their assets (see measure 3221).

Approved an extension of the temporary policy that allows for the purchase of certain single-family mortgages in forbearance that meet specific eligibility criteria set by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac (the Enterprises). The policy is extended for loans originated through August 31, 2020.

Reduced the permissible interest rate of forint-based traditional life, pension, health and annuity insurances from 2.3 to 1.8 percent from January next year, and EUR based schemes from EUR 1.1 to 0.6 percent.

EC approved Spanish plans to set up a fund (Solvency Support Fund) with a budget of ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ10 billion that will invest through debt and equity instruments in companies active in Spain affected by the coronavirus outbreak.

EC approved three Italian schemes, with an overall budget of ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ6 billion, mainly consisting of incentives to the recapitalisation by private investors of small and medium-sized enterprises ('SMEs') affected by the coronavirus outbreak.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Resolved to extend until August 31, the validity of part of the transitional measures announced in April for the treatment of credit risk provisions applicable to supervised banks and credit unions.

Issued a joint statement to provide prudent risk management principles for financial institutions to consider while working with borrowers as loans near the end of initial loan accommodation periods applicable during the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) outbreak.

Amended the Regulation for managing market risk, to reduce the limit to the global overbought position in foreign currency of companies in the financial system. Thus, the global position of overbought in foreign currency may not exceed 10% of the effective equity of the company or the average of global positions as a percentage of the effective equity that the company has registered during the period between December 2019 and May 2020, whichever is greater. Prior to the modification, said position was 50% of effective equity.

Established deadlines for the continuity of the procedures and the resolution of the procedures under the jurisdiction of the National Commission of Insurance and Bonds during the period of duration of the health emergency.

Issued an interim final rule clarifying rules regarding account withdrawals from collective investment funds (CIF). The rule amends the OCC's requirements applicable to national banks and federal savings associations administering CIFs invested primarily in real estate or other assets that are not readily marketable and codifies the time a bank generally has for withdrawing accounts from those CIFs.

Decided on to lift administrative sanctions and grant a 30-day extension of reporting deadline to all fifteen companies that applied for sanctions exemptions due to pandemic-related disruptions in their business operation.

Announced a 90-day repayment deferment for trade facilities under the Pre-approved Principal Payment Holiday Scheme (Scheme). The HKMA has written to all authorized institutions (AIs) requesting them to implement the new arrangement.
Placed COP 250 billion in nominal value in Short-Term Treasury Securities (TCO) with maturities of June 8, 2021 on the Colombian stock market.

Extended again, until August 16, 2020, the suspension of the summary exchange and financial proceedings instructed under the terms of the Foreign Exchange Penal Regime Laws No. 19,359 and Financial Entities No. 21,526, respectively, without prejudice to the validity of the procedural acts that are carried out in said period because the intervention of the accused is not necessary in them.
On May 18, the BOM decided to (i) extend the maturity of the line of credit to 364 days, and (ii) keep the line of credit open until further notice.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: The extension, for a period of three (3) months, of the following measures: A. Electronic Money Institutions 1. Electronic money institutions (e-Mola, Vodafone M-Pesa and Mobile Wallet / mKesh) are now not charge charges and commissions on transfers from client to client up to the maximum limit daily of 1,000.00 MT. 2. The limit per transaction in the mobile wallet is adjusted from 25,000.00 MT to 50,000.00 MT. 3. The daily limit for transactions in the mobile wallet is adjusted from 125,000.00 MT to 250,000.00 MT. 4. The annual transaction limit for Tier I (tier I) customers in the mobile portfolio is adjusted to 400.000,00MT. 5. The commissions and charges to be charged for the new limits should not be higher than the maximum value of the price list in force. Banks no longer charge fees and commissions for transactions made through channels up to a maximum daily limit of 5,000.00MT, for individual customers, except for ATM withdrawals.

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: BaFin reiterated its position on dividend payments.

BCRP placed S/ 21 548 million (US$ 6,130 million) in the second stage of national government-guaranteed repos at an interest rate of 1.61 percent. The second stage of Peru's S/30 billion Reactiva PerÃº Program (US$ 8,535 million) seeks to provide liquidity to companies of all sizes at low rates and in particular tends to favor micro and small businesses in greater proportion.

The NBS Executive Board held an extraordinary session today and adopted regulations which enable bank borrowers and financial lessees to further postpone their liabilities under loans, loan products and leasing. Borrowers have been offered one more suspension in the settlement of their liabilities to banks/financial lessors, maturing in the period between 1 August 2020 and 30 September 2020, as well as a suspension in the payment of liabilities that matured in July 2020, and which the borrower has not settled.

Level 3 policy measures: Ease other macroprudential measures (eg, dti, ltv)
Details of the measure: In accordance with the new regulation, in the case of first home buyers, banks may approve a mortgage loan to a natural person provided that the amount of the loan does not exceed 90% of the value of the property mortgaged (exception from the general limit of 80%).

Banks will be encouraged to offer to borrowers refinancing or change of the maturity date of the last instalment of consumer, cash and other loans (except housing loans and current account overdrafts) approved by 18 May 2020 for additional two years relative to the current repayment regime.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Expired term loans segregated into viable and non-viable loans; viable loans shall be rescheduled and non-viable ones foreclosed.
Expired term loans segregated into viable and non-viable loans; viable loans shall be rescheduled and non-viable ones foreclosed.

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: The Bank of Italy published a Recommendation in which it called on the less significant banks to refrain from distributing dividends, taking any irrevocable commitments regarding the payment of dividends and making share buybacks until 1 October 2020.
The Bank of Italy will therefore not request the replenishment of the LCR before the end of 2021.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Fonacot implements Relief Plan for accredited workers that allows to postpone payments, without extra charges and without affecting the history credit. The measure applies to monthly payments in April and May In the face of the health emergency derived from the COVID-19 pandemic.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Fonacot implements Relief Plan for accredited workers that allows to postpone payments, without extra charges and without affecting the credit history. The measure applies to monthly payments in April and May In the face of the health emergency derived from the COVID-19 pandemic.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Fonacot to extend until 31 July the Its Releave Plan (Plan de Alivio Fonacot).

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Fonacot to extend until 31 July the Its Releave Plan (Plan de Alivio Fonacot).

The supervisory agency (AFR) approved additional measures to support small and medium-sized businesses- deferral for bank loan and microcredit agreements for SMEs is issued for 60 days from August 3 to October 1, 2020, based  on the application of the borrower and without providing documents confirming the deterioration of the financial condition. The current regime will be applied to SMEs working on slected industries (18 such industries weere identified).
It seems necessary to smoothly run the minimum banking service by placing high priority on the health and safety of employees working in banks and financial institutions and of customers.

Revised the Priority Sector Lending (PSL) guidelines to include an incentive framework for banks. While higher weight will be assigned for incremental priority sector credit in the identified districts where credit flow is comparatively lower, a lower weight would be assigned to incremental priority sector credit in identified districts where the credit flow is comparatively higher.
Decided to strengthen credit discipline through appropriate safeguards for opening of current accounts and CC/OD accounts for customers availing credit facilities from multiple banks.

Level 3 policy measures: Ease other macroprudential measures (eg, dti, ltv)
Details of the measure: Decided to increase the permissible loan to value ratio (LTV) for loans against pledge of gold ornaments and jewellery for non-agricultural purposes from 75 per cent to 90 per cent. This relaxation shall be available till March 31, 2021.

Decided that, in respect of MSME borrowers facing stress on account of the economic fallout of the pandemic, lending institutions may restructure the debt under the existing framework, provided the borrower's account was classified as standard with the lender as on March 1, 2020. This restructuring shall be implemented by March 31, 2021.

Decided to provide a window under the Prudential Framework to enable the lenders to implement a resolution plan in respect of eligible corporate exposures without change in ownership, while classifying such exposures as Standard subject to specified conditions. Such conditions are considered necessary to ensure that the facility of this resolution window is available only to the COVID-19 related stressed assets.

Introduced an optional facility to provide banks more flexibility/discretion to manage their day end cash reserve ratio (CRR) balances. Banks will be able to set the amount (specific or range) that they wish to keep as balance in their current account with RBI at the end of the day.

Established special refinance facilities for a total amount of INR 650 million for all India financial institutions (AIFIs) ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ the National Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development (NABARD); the Small Industries Development Bank of India (SIDBI); the National Housing Bank (NHB); and EXIM Bank ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ in order to support their role in meeting funding requirements of various sectors.

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: Urged finance companies incorporated in Singapore to cap their total dividends per share (ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩDPSÔøΩÔøΩ?) for FY2020 at 60% of FY2019's level. The finance companies are also encouraged to offer shareholders the option of receiving the dividends to be paid for FY2020 in scrip in lieu of cash.
Signed a currency swap agreements with the Bank of the People's Republic of CHINA (PBC). The new agreements will be valid for 3 years.

To support citizens facing reductions in income, the Bank of Russia recommended that financial institutions: continue to restructure loans, refrain from imposing penalties and fines on restructured loans, suspend procedures for forced eviction of debtors, extend the period for settlement of insured events, and refrain from factoring debt restructuring into assessments of creditworthiness. Most of these recommendations apply until December 31, 2020.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in capital requirement (definition of capital, car, risk weights)
Details of the measure: To support consumer lending, the Bank of Russia (BoR) cancelled the premia paid on risk ratios for unsecured consumer loans issued up to August 31, 2020. The BoR also lowered the premiums to risk ratios on unsecured consumer loans extended from September 1, 2020.

To support small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), the Bank of Russia enabled financial institutions to: restructure loans to SMEs under their own programs, to forgo penalties and fines on restructured loans, to restructure loans and borrowings by changing currency from foreign currency to rubles, and to exclude the corona-related debt restructurings from assessments of borrower creditworthiness.

Decided on additional measures within the Targeted Economic Support Scheme (TESS) launched initially in March 2020 to further enhance the capacity of the banking sector to support the economy. These measures consist into reviewing the existing thresholds of two prudential ratios: the Net Stable Funding Ratio (NSFR) and the Advances to Stable Resources Ratio (ASRR) by temporarily relaxing the requirements for the structural liquidity position of banks.
Reduced to zero the liquidity limits offered to Primary Dealers in the framework of Open Market Operations (OMOs), effective from 12 August 2020.
Assigned a total of PEN 22 million at an average interest rate of 2.72 percent among the entities of the financial system.
The CB decided to extend again, until August 30, 2020, the suspension of the summary exchange and financial actions
SBV  cut the interest rate it pays on banks' reserves by 0.2-0.5% as part of its efforts to help the economy weather the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic.

Announced revised pricing for its Municipal Liquidity Facility (MLF). The revised pricing reduces the interest rate spread on tax-exempt notes for each credit rating category by 50 basis points and reduces the amount by which the interest rate for taxable notes is adjusted relative to tax-exempt notes.
Carried out a total of PEN 711 million in repo transactions at an average interest rate of 2.43 percent.
Decided to lower the target for the overnight interbank interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.5%, effective August 14, 2020.

Approved a bill that empowers the Central Bank of Chile to buy debt instruments issued by the Treasury in the open secondary market in exceptional and transitory situations, in which it is required to preserve the normal functioning of internal payments and external.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Launched a zero-rate credit line for the cultural industries sector. This benefit will reach people adhering to the monotributistas and self-employed regime who develop activities related to the cultural industry, who may have a credit of up to ARS150,000.  It is proposed that the Zero Rate Credit Line contemplate a grace period of twelve (12) months from the first crediting. After said period, the credit will be reimbursed in a minimum of twelve (12) equal and consecutive monthly installments.
Conducted a repo auction of TRY 10 billion via the traditional auction method. The maturity of this repo auction has been determined as 16 September 2020.
Conducted a repo auction of TRY 10 billion via the traditional auction method. The maturity of this repo auction has been determined as 8 September 2020.

Annouced that banks' borrowing limits at the Central Bank of the Republic of Turkey (CBRT) Interbank Money Market for O/N transactions will be reduced to half of their current limits effective from 19 August 2020.
Conducted a repo auction of TRY 10 billion via the traditional auction method. The maturity of this repo auction has been determined as 9 September 2020.
Carried out a total of PEN 15 million in repo transactions at an average interest rate of 2.95 percent.
ECB and National Bank of the Republic of North Macedonia set up a ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ400 million repo line to remain in place until June 2021.
Placed in the Colombian public securities market COP 250 billion in nominal value in Short-Term Treasury Securities (TCO) maturing on June 8, 2021.

Level 3 policy measures: Reduce non-essential regulatory reporting requirements for banks
Details of the measure: Extended the deadline for submitting the Annual Financial Statements (EECC) with closing June 30, 2020 and July 31, 2020 and Intermediate EECC with closing July 31, 2020 of all entities and investment instruments under the control of this body.

The National Bank of Romania (NBR) cut the policy rate by 25 basis points to 1.50% and the lending facility (Lombard) rate by 25 basis points to 2.00%. Moreover, it lowered the deposit facility rate to 1.00% from 1.25%, while pledging to maintain secondary market debt purchases and repo transactions in order to continue to ensure sufficient liquidity in the economy.

ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ2 billion (US$ 2.36 billion) Italian guarantee scheme to support trade credit insurance market in the context of the coronavirus outbreak. The scheme will ensure that trade credit insurance continues to be available to all companies, avoiding the need for buyers of goods or services to pay in advance, therefore reducing their immediate liquidity needs.
CB reduced policy rate by 25 bp to 2.25.
CB reduced policy rate by 25 bp to 2.00%.

The Bank of England, the Bank of Japan, the European Central Bank and the Swiss National Bank, in consultation with the Federal Reserve, have jointly decided to further reduce the frequency of their 7-day operations from three times per week to once per week from Sep 1.

The Bank of England, the Bank of Japan, the European Central Bank and the Swiss National Bank, in consultation with the Federal Reserve, have jointly decided to further reduce the frequency of their 7-day operations from three times per week to once per week from Sep 1.

Decided to raise FX reserve requirement ratios for banks fulfilling real credit growth conditions by 700 basis points for precious metal deposit accounts and by 200 basis points for all other FX liabilities for all maturity brackets.
Conducted a repo auction of TRY 10 billion via the traditional auction method. The maturity of this repo auction has been determined as 18 September 2020.
Conducted a repo auction of TRY 10 billion via the traditional auction method. The maturity of this repo auction has been determined as 22 September 2020.
Conducted a repo auction of TRY 10 billion via the traditional auction method. The maturity of this repo auction has been determined as 23 September 2020.

Approved amendments to the BSP's rules on real estate loan limits of universal and commercial banks (U/KBs) and thrift banks (TBs) - which have been increased from 20 to 25 percent of loan portfolio (net of interbank loans). U/KBs and their subsidiary TBs are also required to comply with the real estate stress test (REST) limits, after assuming a 25 percent write-off of real estate exposures, on both solo- and consolidated basis: 1) 10 percent Capital Adequacy Ratio (CAR) and 6 percent Common Equity Tier 1 capital ratio (for U/KBs, and their subsidiary TBs), and 10 percent CAR and 6 percent Tier 1 ratio (for TBs that are not subsidiaries of U/KBs.  Under the new guidelines, the methodology for computing a bank's REST limits was revised to exclude residential real estate loans to individuals for own occupancy and foreclosed real estate property.
Carried out a total of PEN 1.55 billion in repo transactions at an average interest rate of 2.44 percent.

Decided to conduct simultaneous purchase and sale of government securities under Open Market Operation (OMO) for an aggregate amount of ÔøΩÔøΩ_20,000 crores in two tranches of ÔøΩÔøΩ_10,000 crores each. The auctions would be conducted on August 27, 2020 and September 03, 2020.

Published regulations that modify the treatment of guarantees granted by the Treasury in the calculation of risk-weighted assets. The adjustments to Chapter 12-1 of the Updated Compilation of Standards (RAN) establish that said guarantees will be assigned to category 2, recognizing the lower risk due to the effect of the state guarantee.

Issued a statement that clarified the Prudential Regulatory Authority's (PRA) approach to International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) 9 and capital requirements in response to the Financial Conduct Authority's (FCA) guidance on retail mortgage payment deferrals. The PRA expressed that tailored forbearance arrangements are likely to be a good indicator of significant increases in credit risk (SICR), credit impairments, or defaults. This expression represents a return to the PRA's pre-crisis stance on payment forbearance.
Introduced new BCRP repo operations in the amount of PEN 3.31 billion at an interest rate of 2.72%.
South Soudanese pound as legal tender, all business transactions should be carried out in SSP, USD use should be limited.
Announced the extension of the temporary ban on stock short sale for six months from September 16, 2020 to March 15, 2021, given market volatility amid concerns over a resurgence in COVID-19 cases.

Conducted a central bank bills swap (CBS) operation on August 27, 2020 in order to improve the liquidity of bank-issued perpetual bonds, support banks to replenish capital through perpetual bond issuance, and enable the financial sector to better serve the real economy. The operation registered RMB5 billion, with a term of three months and a rate of 0.10 percent.
The CB has extended once again the suspension term to file foreign exchange and financial summary proceedingsÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩup to September 20, 2020
Credit card bills due between September 1 and September 30 may be refinanced twelve months ahead of maturity, with a three-month grace period and nine fixed installments, at a 40% APR plus VAT

Central Bank decides to implement a mechanism to accelerate the use of the Rapid Liquidity Facility (FLR) of RD $ 60 billion and that these resources can be used for refinancing and payment of arrears
CB reduces its monetary policy rate by 50 basis points, from 3.50% to 3.00% annually

The CB decided to narrow the interest rate corridor, by reducing the interest rate of the permanent liquidity expansion facility (1-day Repos) from 4.50% to 3.50% per annum, while the interest rate of paid deposits ( Overnight) remains at 2.50% annually
Government of Guyana has reached an agreement with the local banking sector to extend the moratorium on loan payments until the end of the year and to cut interest rates.

Announced that Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac (the Enterprises) will extend the moratoriums on single-family foreclosures and real estate owned (REO) evictions until at least December 31, 2020.  The foreclosure moratorium applies to Enterprise-backed, single-family mortgages only. The REO eviction moratorium applies to properties that have been acquired by an Enterprise through foreclosure or deed-in-lieu of foreclosure transactions. The current moratoriums were set to expire on August 31, 2020.

The European Central Bank (ECB) and the National Bank of Romania (NBR) agreed to extend the framework arrangement for the repo lines that supply NBR with euro liquidity. This repo line was established in the context of market failures induced by COVID-19. The NBR can borrow up to EUR 4.5 billion from the ECB. The end date was extended from December 31, 2020 to June 30, 2021.
Announced that LKR 40,000 million Treasury bills are to be issued through an auction on 2 September 2020.

Implemented modifications to the Regulation of Management of Market Conduct of the Financial System. The standard specifies that companies must implement policies and procedures for the adequate treatment of clients with temporary difficulties in paying their credits, within the framework of a national emergency declaration, incorporating the following minimum aspects: (i) adequate communication to the clients on the procedures and deadlines for the presentation of their request, (ii) the reception and evaluation of the client's request, without application of interest or additional charges to those originally agreed while the evaluation lasts, (iii) the analysis of alternatives of payment, with adequate information to the client on their characteristics, benefits and risks, and (iv) the periodic monitoring of the client, having to take actions in the face of new difficulties that this may present.

Decided to allow banks to hold fresh acquisitions of SLR securities acquired from September 1, 2020 under HTM up to an overall limit of 22 per cent of NDTL up to March 31, 2021 which shall be reviewed thereafter.

Announced it will conduct term repo operations for an aggregate amount of ÔøΩÔøΩ_100,000 crore at floating rates (i.e., at the prevailing repo rate) in the middle of September to assuage pressures on the market on account of advance tax outflows. In order to reduce the cost of funds, banks that had availed of funds under long-term repo operations (LTROs) may exercise an option of reversing these transactions before maturity. Thus, the banks may reduce their interest liability by returning funds taken at the repo rate prevailing at that time (5.15 per cent) and availing funds at the current repo rate of 4 per cent.

Level 3 policy measures: Ensure minimal functionality in the primary and secondary markets
Details of the measure: Announced simultaneous purchase and sale of government securities under Open Market Operation (OMO) for an aggregate amount of ÔøΩÔøΩ_20,000 crores in two tranches of ÔøΩÔøΩ_10,000 crores each. The first auction was conducted on August 27, 2020 and the second auction is scheduled for September 03, 2020.
