The European Central Bank (ECB) and the Hrvatska narodna banka (Croatian National Bank, HNB) as well as the Banca NaÔøΩÔøΩionalÔøΩÔøΩ a RomÃ¢niei (National Bank of Romania, BNR) have agreed to extend the respective euro liquidity lines by six months until the end of June 2021.
Decided to renew until September 25 (September board session) the expiration dates of future dollar sale contracts with financial compliance, through the auction mechanism in the days of expiration.
Lowered its interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point to 2%.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in capital requirement (definition of capital, car, risk weights)
Details of the measure: Announced the following updates to the special capital treatment that applies when loan payment deferrals or premium deferrals have been granted: 1) The special capital treatment for payment or premium deferrals granted before August 31 will remain limited to a maximum of six calendar months from the effective date of the deferral. 2) A new payment or premium deferral granted for the first time after August 30 and on or before September 30 will receive the special capital treatment for the duration of the deferral, up to a maximum of three calendar months from the approval date of the deferral. 3) Payment and premium deferrals with approval dates after September 30, will not be eligible for the special capital treatment.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Announced the following updates to the special capital treatment of loans subject to payment deferrals: 1) Loans granted payment deferrals before August 31 will continue to be treated as performing loans under the CAR Guideline for the duration of the deferral, up to a maximum of 6 calendar months from the effective date of the deferral; 2) Loans granted new payment deferrals after August 30 and on or before September 30 will be treated as performing loans under the CAR Guideline for the duration of the deferral, up to a maximum of 3 calendar months from the approval date of the deferral; and 3) Loans granted payment deferrals with approval dates after September 30, 2020 will not be eligible for the special capital treatment.

Lifted regulatory adjustments to protect the interests of pension plan members and beneficiaries, and which allowed administrators of federally regulated private pension plans to focus their efforts on addressing the many challenges posed by COVID-19.

Decided to increase the size of the Term Funding Facility and make the facility available for longer. Under the expanded Term Funding Facility, authorised deposit-taking institutions (ADIs) will have access to additional funding, equivalent to 2 percent of their outstanding credit, at a fixed rate of 25 basis points for three years. ADIs will be able to draw on this extra funding up until the end of June 2021.
Announced to all deposit money banks that the interest rate on local currency savings deposits shall be negotiable subject to a minimum of 10% per annum of the Monetary Policy Rate.
Extended until March 31, 2021 the application period for principal moratorium for the 80% Guarantee Product and the 90% Guarantee Product under the SME Financing Guarantee Scheme.
Placed COP 250 billion in nominal value in the Colombian public securities market in Short-Term Treasury Securities (TCO), maturing on June 8, 2021.
Extend ATM card expiry dates till end of the year instead of 30 June 2020 and not to withhold ATM cards in ATM machines and facilitate the release of ATM cards

Level 3 policy measures: Prioritize or review critical supervisory actions
Details of the measure: Extending the time period to send final accounts to CBOS to after the end of the containment period and return of work in the banking sector to its normal state.

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: To reduce the impact of Covid on the financial situation of the banks in 2020 to distribute only 50% of distributable profits
the measures attached.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Settle payments on a daily basis in relation to point of sale payments.

Armenia's parliamentary committee approved a bill that allows the increase in the coverage of guaranteed deposits in national currency for individuals from the current 10 million drams to 16 million and the coverage of currency deposits from 5 million drams to 7 million.
Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) created a new term facility to provide banks and finance companies an additional channel to borrow SGD funds at longer tenors and with more forms of collateral.
MAS also expanded the collateral accepted at its USD facility.

The Financial Stability Board (FSB) announced extensions to the implementation timelines for minimum haircut standards for non-centrally cleared securities financing transactions (SFTs), to ease operational burdens on market participants and authorities, and thereby assist them in focusing on priorities from the impact of COVID-19. For bank-to-non-bank transactions, the updated implementation date is January 2023 (instead of January 2022).

Announces swap facility for providing forint liquidity and, in some cases, foreign currency swap tenders. The MNB will inform Hungarian banks about terms for swap tenders with maturities of up to 2 weeks.

Hungarian Financial Stability Board (PST) amends the Interbank Financing Ratio (BFM) requirement. On-balance sheet derivative liabilities are now exempted from the BFM requirement. This requirement will be implemented the day following its publication in the Hungarian Gazette.

Amending some provisions of the Executive Regulations of the Capital Market Law No. 95 of 1992 - further simplified and clarified of some of the controls and procedures necessary to implement purchase offers for the purpose of acquisition.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: In its National Address, the President mentioned that as an additional aid to SMEs,  state subsidies of interest rates up to 6% per annum will be provided to all existing loans to SMEs in the affected sectors of the economy. The subsidy will cover a period of 12 months, starting from the moment of the announcement of the state of emergency, i.e. from March 16, 2020.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: State agencies and public legal persons that deal with the public may give their clients positive incentives to pay by non-cash payment methods, including reducing the amounts due by a percentage not exceeding 5% of its value, refunding part of the amounts paid by these means, at a rate not exceeding 3% of its value, and setting up points programs, or rewards that include financial or in-kind benefits, in a manner that does not exceed 5% of the value of the amounts paid by these means.

IRDAI has granted exemption to insurers from requirement of issuing policy document and copy of the proposal in physical form in respect to certain policies including all motor, and fire insurance policies, till March 31, 2021. The IRDAI has issued new guidelines to all the general insurers on the matter of ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ Issuance of Electronic Policies and dispensing with physical documents and wet signature on the proposal form.

The FCA published new guidance for providing mortgage relief to borrowers. This is not an amendment or extension of the June guidance that expires on October 31, 2020. The measures allow firms to offer further short and longer-term support reflecting the circumstances of their customers. This includes extending the repayment term or restructuring of mortgages. Where consumers need further short-term support, firms can continue to offer arrangements for no or reduced payments for a specified period to give customers time to get back on track. This additional guidance will come into force on 16 September 2020.
Extended the deadline for business recovery plan submission from 1 October to 1 December 2020, provided they are systemically important

Level 3 policy measures: Ensure minimal functionality in the primary and secondary markets
Details of the measure: The NBU has eliminated obstacles for foreign investors to enter the Ukrainian securities market through establishment of the direct access to the purchase and sale of government bonds with the help of a "nominee holderÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ.

Reinforcement of internal controls, such as strengthening the standards for accruing provision for loan loss provisions for real estate PF loans, and establishing standards for additional provision for loan loss provisions in advance to ensure consistent operation.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Montenegrin small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and mid-caps in tourism and other sectors severely affected by COVID-19 will benefit from a  EUR 50 million loan that the European Investment Bank (EIB) has signed with the Montenegrin Investment and Development Fund (IDF).

The total guarantee commitment is raised from HK$50 billion to HK$70 billion. Meanwhile, the maximum repayment period of the guaranteed loans is increased from 3 years to 5 years. Borrowers with existing loans under the Special 100% Loan Guarantee can apply to their lending banks for increasing the loan amount and/or extending the repayment period if they deem appropriate, and in general no additional supporting documents will be required.

The postponement ended on September 15, 2020 as scheduled, with the CBE issuing a circular on September 14 saying that banks should review their existing lending facilities while setting up ways for debtors to pay their debts in a way that is consummate with their ability to pay (aka restructurings). Banks will postpone all credit entitlements for both institutional and individual customers (include consumer loans and real estate loans for personal housing), for a period of 6 months with no additional returns or fines applied for late payment.

Enhanced the supervision of fair customer service, and charged financial service providers to take appropriate care of debtors affected by COVID-19. The Bank of Thailand (BOT) described new supervisory guidelines about market conduct, acceptable business practices, compliance expectations, and customer service (especially loan forgiveness and moratoria) during the COVID-19 crisis.

The state-owned Small Industry Credit Guarantee Corporation (TCG) signed a Memorandum of Understanding, which outlined the Soft Loan Plus Loan Guarantee Program," with 18 partner banks. The program was meant to provide Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (SMEs) with liquidity and access to funding sources.

Loan Restructuring Framework for COVID-19-related Stress. RBI introduced a one-time restructuring scheme for accounts impacted by Covid-19 on August 6, 2020, with the intent to facilitate revival of real sector activities and mitigate the impact on the ultimate borrowers. RBI has provided a window under the Prudential Framework to enable the lenders to implement a restructuring plan in respect of eligible corporate exposures without change in ownership, and personal loans, without downgrading those accounts, subject to specified conditions. The scheme allows lenders to restructure exposures for a maximum of two years and requires lenders to identify eligible accounts by December 31, 2020. A separate restructuring scheme for MSMEs was also introduced on August 6, 2020. RBI also constituted an Expert committee to make recommendations on the required financial parameters with sector specific benchmark ranges for such parameters to be factored in the resolution plans in respect of borrowers eligible for the one time restructuring scheme. Based on the committee's report, RBI issued guidelines on September 7, 2020 on key financial parameters to be considered while finalizing the restructuring plans in respect of eligible borrowers.

Loan Restructuring Framework for COVID-19-related Stress ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ Financial Parameters RBI constituted an Expert committee to make recommendations on the required financial parameters with sector specific benchmark ranges for such parameters to be factored in the restructuring plans in respect of borrowers eligible for the one time restructuring scheme. Based on the committee's report, RBI issued guidelines on September 7, 2020 on key financial parameters to be considered while finalizing the restructuring plans in respect of eligible borrowers.

Relaxation from default recognition due to restructuring of debt Based on its assessment, if the credit rating agency is of the view that the restructuring by the lenders/ investors is solely dueto COVID-19 related stress or under the aforementioned RBI framework, CRAs  may  not  consider  the  same  as  a  default  event  and/or  recognize default.

The Reserve Bank will conduct additional special open market operation involving the simultaneous purchase and sale of Government securities for an aggregate amount of ÔøΩÔøΩ_20,000 crore in two tranches of ÔøΩÔøΩ_10,000 crore each. The auctions would be conducted on September 10, 2020 and September 17, 2020. The RBI remains committed to conduct further such operations as warranted by market conditions. The Reserve Bank will conduct term repo operations for an aggregate amount of ÔøΩÔøΩ_100,000 crore at floating rates (i.e., at the prevailing repo rate) in the middle of September to assuage pressures on the market on account of advance tax outflows. In order to reduce the cost of funds, banks that had availed of funds under long-term repo operations (LTROs) may exercise an option of reversing these transactions before maturity. Thus, the banks may reduce their interest liability by returning funds taken at the repo rate prevailing at that time (5.15 per cent) and availing funds at the current repo rate of 4 per cent. Details are being notified separately. Currently, banks are required to maintain 18 per cent of their net demand and time liabilities (NDTL) in SLR securities. The extant limit for investments that can be held in HTM category is 25 per cent of total investment. Banks are allowed to exceed this limit provided the excess is invested in SLR securities within an overall limit of 19.5 per cent of NDTL. SLR securities held in HTM category by major banks amount to around 17.3 per cent of NDTL at present. However, there are inter-bank variations with some banks close to the 19.5 per cent of NDTL limit. Accordingly, it has been decided to allow banks to hold fresh acquisitions of SLR securities acquired from September 1, 2020 under HTM up to an overall limit of 22 per cent of NDTL up to March 31, 2021 which shall be reviewed thereafter. Details are being notified separately.

The Central Bank of Costa Rica Board of Directors approved a special credit facility for financial intermediaries for 700 billions of colones (US$1.17 billion). Board of Directors of the Central Bank of Costa Rica (BCCR) approved the creation of a special medium-term credit facility for financial intermediaries regulated by the General Superintendency of Financial Institutions (SUGEF). The new instrument will provide financial intermediaries with a medium-term, low-cost source of national currency financing to transfer these resources, on also favorable terms, to pandemic-affected households and enterprises.

Mexico's central bank said on Tuesday that it has extended measures designed to strengthen credit channels and provide liquidity in the financial system. Banxico said liquidity facilities first announced in April will be extended until the end of February 2021, while a government' securities repurchase window is being increased by a further 50 billion pesos (US$2.37 billion).

Second round of the program "Reactiva PerÃº". Peru's Central Reserve Bank held the twenty-fifth national government-guaranteed Portfolio Repos auction session and allocated a total of S/33 million (US$9.37 million) at an average interest rate of 3.24% among financial system entities.

Level 3 policy measures: Ensure minimal functionality in the primary and secondary markets
Details of the measure: The central bank announced that it would reduce its purchases in auctions of new federal T-bills ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ short-term government debt with a maturity of 12 months or less ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ to 10 per cent of each weekly auction.  The central bank said it would cut its share of auctions of provincial money-market securities (PMMP) ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ the provinces' equivalent to T-bills ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ to a maximum of 10 per cent.

- Raised treshold requirements for creditors to initiate insolvency proceedings: new money treshold to issue a statutory demand for an unpaid debt  increased response timelines for a debtor to respond to a statutory demand from 21 days to 6 months  - Directors no longer liable for incurring debts while insolvent (for the initial 6 months period).  - Possibility for businesses with total business loans of up to $10 million to defer their loan payments for up to 6 months - Documents filed and signed electronically, virtual court hearings have been introduced, increased out-of-court mechanisms: binding mediation where a SME tenant experiences hardship as a result of COVID-19.

- Extension of the terms of lease agreements  - Eviction orders in connection with the default in payment of leased properties' (including commercial ones) monthly fees are supended until 30 September 2020
Classification of loans will not be degraded in the event of a default in payment

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: In September 2020, NBG has issued a Rule on Customer Strong Authentication which aims to secure protected authentication of payment service user and mitigation of risk of fraud while conducting electronic payments. This policy measure is expected to increase trust towards digital payments in Georgia and support implementation of the Open Banking services. This rule has also increased the limit for the simplified authentication requirement for small value card transactions from GEL 100 to GEL 150 (no PIN requirement), coming into effect in April 2021, which makes a process of payment more convenient and easier for consumers.

Project of Law No 1.397/20 that contains transitory amendments to the Brazilian Insolvency Law:  In-court and out-of-court foreclosure measures initiated in connection with obligations that were due after 20 March 2020, will be suspended for 60 days encouraging the debtor and creditor to renegotiate their obligations. If no settlement can be found at the end of the 60-day period, debtor can initiate an in-court preventive negotiation proceeding, provided there is evidence of a 30% revenue reduction in comparison with the prior trimester.  After the filing of a preventive negotiation request, the judge will suspend foreclosure measures for another 60 days and will assign a professional negotiator to conduct the discussions between the parties.  Obligations due after publication of the Law will w in connection with ratified judicial or extrajudicial reorganisation plans will be suspended for 120 days, without the necessity of convening general creditors meetings; and judicial reorganisation plans for small and micro companies will allow payment of debts in up to 60 monthly instalments, instead of the 36 instalments that are currently provided for in the Law, among other provisions that seek to prevent bankruptcy during the Covid-19 pandemic.  Judiciary employees, including judges, will render their services remotely, through virtual means.  On March 31 2020, the National Justice Council approved Normative Act No. 0002561-26.2020.2.00.0000 providing recommendation to judges of standardised procedures to be followed in connection with judicial reorganisation proceedings during the COVID-19 pandemic, including: prioritized analyses of creditors and debtors' withdrawal requests, suspension of in-person General Creditors Meetings; extension of the stay period upon the necessity of suspending any General Creditors Meeting; among others. On 1 April 2020, Provisional Measure No 936 was enacted by the President creating the Emergency Programme for Labour and Income Protection through which additional and complementary labour measures were established, including 'proportional reduction in salaries and in working hours, for up to 90 days', 'temporary suspension of labour agreements, for up to 60 days' and 'creation of the Emergency Benefit for Labour and Income Protection' through which the Federal Government will compensate employees placed in temporary suspension or proportional reduction programmes with monetary assistance.

The State of Emergency Measures Act (in force until the termination of the state of emergency) contains measures that apply to insolvency matters and pending insolvency cases:  - Suspension of procedural terms on judicial, arbitral and enforcement proceedings - Suspension of Limitation periods, by expiration of which certain rights terminate or arise for private legal and natural persons. - The obligation for the debtor that has become either insolvent or over-indebted to file a petition for opening of insolvency proceedings has been extended to one month after the termination of the state of insolvency  - Remote court hearings, filing of documents electronically
State Council issued Decree No. 206 of 2020, announcing the: - Suspension of most court hearings until 16 April 2020.

- Legislative change to the insolvency test: the ordinance nÔøΩ 2020-341 of 27 March 2020 provides that the insolvency test which would ordinarily be performed for a company as at 12 March 2020 will now be extended for three months after the state of health emergency ends on 24 May 2020. - A conciliation procedure is automatically extended until 24 August 2020. - Removal of the three-month waiting period between two conciliation procedures  - The observation period, the simplified liquidation procedure and the payment of employees' claims by the AGS (Employees' Claims Payment Guarantee Institution) are automatically extended to 24 June 2020. - Insolvency practitioners acting as the representative of the debtor (administrateur judiciaire), representative of the creditors (mandataire judiciaire), liquidator (liquidateur judiciaire) or as officer of the implementation of the plan (commissaire ÔøΩÔøΩ l'exÃ©cution du plan) may request before the president of the court the extension of all statutory time limits imposed on them in Part VI of the Commercial Code until 24 August 2020. - Safeguard or reorganisation plans are automatically extended until 24 June 2020. - The insolvency practitioner acting as the officer of the implementation of the plan may also request before the President of the court the extension of the plan until 24 August 2020. - After 24 August 2020, and for a time limit of six months (up to 24 February 2021), the insolvency practitioner acting as the officer of the implementation of the plan or the Public Prosecutor may request before the court the extension of the plan for a time limit of one year. - Employees' claims which are due on the day of the opening of the insolvency proceedings will be paid by the AGS in the limits provided by the law. - The insolvency practitioner appointed as the representative of the creditors will provide without delay the AGS with the statement of the employee's claims. - The hearing ordinarily planned two months after the opening of a reorganisation procedure and ruling on the continuation of the observation period has now been removed up to one month after the cessation of the state of health emergency i.e. 24 June 2020. - The acts allowing the referral to the court by the debtor shall be provided to the court administration service by any appropriate means up to one month after the cessation of the state of health emergency. - Communication between the court administration service, the insolvency practitioners (administrateur judiciaire and mandataire judiciaire), the supervisory judges, the Public Prosecutor, the controllers and the employees' representative shall be done by any appropriate means up to one month after the cessation of the state of health emergency. - Contractual sanctions of non-performance from debtor are temporarily lifted in order to take account of enforcement difficulties.  -  French insolvency practitioners launched a freephone number available to directors affected by the Covid-19-related economic crisis. - Digital hearings using audiovisual telecommunication means.

- Temporary suspension of the duty to file for bankruptcy  - Limitation of the directors' and managers' liability in case of an insolvency caused by Covid-19 -  Petitions by creditors to commence insolvency proceedings, filed between 28 March 2020 and 28 June 2020 (a date that may be extended by executive order) can only lead to the commencement of insolvency proceedings if the debtor was already illiquid or overindebted on 1 March 2020.

- Extension of the e-lodgment platform  - Remote hearings via videoconference - Insolvency practitioners have discretion to defer certain deadlines or obligations - Creation of the online Dispute Resolution Scheme  - Suspension of judicial proceedings from 29 January 2020 until 3 May 2020

Cura Italia Decree:  - the filing of any bankruptcy petition is stayed until 30 June 2020 - any pending debt-restructuring agreements and composition with creditors proceedings are suspended for a six-month period; upon certain conditions, amendments to the restructuring plan, or composition plan, as well as the filing of a new plan, are allowed, if the plan has not been approved yet by creditors. - With reference to hearings and judicial proceedings, a general postponement of all civil, criminal, insolvency, tax and administrative hearings (with some exceptions, in relation to urgent matters) and suspension of relevant procedural terms were granted in March and further extended until 11 May 2020. - Hearings are automatically postponed after 11 May 2020 (with some exceptions, in relation to urgent matters) and any procedural terms (e.g., deadlines for filing briefs, or other actions) relating to the pending proceedings are suspended. - Virtual hearings + electronic filings  - employers cannot commence collective dismissal procedures, nor carry out individual dismissals for economic reasons; and collective dismissal procedures commenced after 23 February 2020 are suspended.
- A limitation of a petition by creditors for bankruptcy proceedings against debtors on the basis of deficits caused by the Covid-19 outbreak

- Limitation or prescription periods have been suspended between 12 March 2020 and 1 July 2020. - The maximum term to comply with the obligations under a judgment concerning the return of goods, recovery of debt or evictions from premises is extended from 10 days to 60 days, except the cases when judgment should be enforced immediately. Further, all enforcement proceedings in relation to administrative decisions commenced before the state of emergency was declared (12March 2020) have been suspended for the duration of the state of emergency. The moratorium of debt recovery is not applicable for administrative decisions that may already be executed on a compulsory basis from the time it comes into effect without waiting until it becomes indisputable. - Time limits for taking a decision on delivering a commercial pledge have been extended from 30 days to 60 days - Creditors are prohibited from submitting an application for insolvency proceedings of a legal person from 22 March 2020 until 1 September 2020. - Employees' claims in the event of the employer's insolvency are covered by the guarantee fund to a limited extent, including the right of the employee to receive remuneration and other paid absences for the last three months of the employment relationship during the 12 months preceding the employer's insolvency proceedings. The employee is also entitled to compensation for paid annual leave, the right to which was acquired in the 12-month period before the occurrence of the employer's insolvency. - Time of restriction for creditors to file for insolvency will be taken into account on a case-by-case basis, when deciding to satisfy employee claims ensured by the State.  - From 5 April 2020 until the end of the state of emergency and six months thereafter the time period for the implementation of a plan of Measures of Legal Protection Proceedings can be set for up to four years for new plans and those that have not yet been extended, if the majority of creditors specified in the Insolvency Law agree. Plans that have been already extended once can be extended for another year if the majority of creditors specified in the Insolvency Law agree. - Debtors will be allowed until 31 December 2020 to request that plan of Measures of Legal Protection Proceedings are set for up to four years for new plans and those that have not yet been extended. Debtors will also have the opportunity to request an extension of previously extended plans by 1 September 2020. - Creditor committee meetings for insolvency proceedings of a legal person and for the purposes of coordinating the plan of Measures of Legal Protection Proceedings can be held remotely from 5 April 2020 until the end of the state of emergency. - During the state of emergency, applications for legal protection proceedings and insolvency proceedings of a legal person can be submitted electronically. - Hearings by videoconference

On 10 April 2020, the Companies Commission of Malaysia announced two measures to provide temporary winding up protection for companies: - The value of indebtedness for a statutory demand leading to winding up has been increased from RM10,000 to RM50,000. - Companies have been given a period of six months from the current 21 days to respond to the statutory demand.  The Temporary Measures for Reducing The Impact of Coronavirus Disease 2019 (Covid-19) Bill 2020 is expected to be introduced shortly.

The Chief Justice of Nigeria and Chairman of the National Judicial Council, issued a circular referenced NJC/CIR/HOC/II/631 on 24 March 2020 directing the immediate suspension of court sittings for an initial period of two weeks except for urgent, essential or time-bound matters.

On 11 May 2020 the Executive issued Legislative Decree number 1511 that created 'Procedimiento Acelerado de RefinanciaciÔøΩ_n Concursal' (PARC). On June 7th the President of the council of ministers issued the Supreme Decree number 102-2020-PCM that defined the regulatory standard for the PARC. This new procedure came into force on 8th June 2020. The objective of this procedure is to: - Allow a to enter into an agreement with its creditors known as ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩPlan de RefinanciaciÔøΩ_n Empresarial (PRE)ÔøΩÔøΩ?: approval if the the holders of more than 50% of the creditors recognized by the bankruptcy authority, vote in favour of the proposal submitted by the company to the PARC. The key objective of this procedure is to protect the business as a going concern by rescheduling unpaid debts that would result in avoiding the company going into insolvency.  Legislative Decree number 1511 and Supreme Decree number 102-2020-PCM, have established that PARC will be an exclusively electronic procedure. That means that all procedural actions made by the debtor, the creditors and the authority in the PARC, will be always using digital channels (mainly e-mail).

In partnership with Association of Banks of Azerbaijan, the CBA launched a free package of Basic Banking Services for low-income population. In its initial stage, the project will support 600,000 registered unemployed citizens within the framework of the Coronavirus Support Fund.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: The CBA increased the limit of contactless transactions with payment cards without entering PIN codes from AZN 50 to AZN 100.

Level 2 policy measures: Consumer protection measures and ensuring availability and acceptance of cash
Details of the measure: The Ministry of Labor and Social Protection, the CBA, and the Association of Banks of Azerbaijan announced that pensions and social benefits can be obtained from ATMs and POS terminals without fees.
CBA lowered the refinancing rate to 6.75% from 7%. The floor of the interest rate corridor was set at 6.25%, while the ceiling was set at 7.25%.

On 31 March 2020, the Anti-crisis Law that provides for certain financial relief measures for entrepreneurs came into force. According to this law:  - parties may mutually amend the terms and conditions of loan repayments stipulated in a credit agreement concluded with micro, small and medium entrepreneurs.  - during the state of epidemic the statutory term for filing an insolvency motion by the debtor does not start to run and, where it had already started to run, it is interrupted and will start to run afresh following the termination of the state of epidemic. - if a ground for filing for debtor's insolvency arises during the epidemic threat or state of epidemic, it is presumed that the grounds for insolvency are caused by CovidÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ19. - in case a debtor properly files for insolvency within a deadline calculated in accordance with the provisions of the Anti-crisis Law then, absent an earlier insolvency motion (e.g. a creditor's motion), the deadlines specified by the insolvency law that are counted from the date of filing shall be prolonged by the number of days between the date of the actual filing (as permitted by the Anti-crisis Law) and the date when the motion should have been filed by the debtor pursuant to the insolvency law regardless of the application of the above provisions of the Anti-crisis Law.  - the Anti-crisis Law provisions on the catalogue of 'urgent matters' that will be delegated to a different court in case the pertinent court stops the performance of official duties as a result of Covid-19 has been changed so that now restructuring motions within the meaning of the restructuring law and motions for conclusion of an arrangement at a creditors' meeting of an individual who does not conduct business activities are to be treated as urgent matters.  The "Anti-crisi Shield 4.0" which entered into force on 24 June 2020 introduces a simplified restructuring proceeding: - Until 31 June 2021 debtors are allowed to start simplified arrangement process by signing an agreement with a restructuring advisor and announcing the opening of proceedings for approval of arrangement in official gazette. From that day: (i) pending enforcement actions are suspended and new actions cannot be started; (ii) debtor shall not pay debts subject to arrangement by virtue of law (e.g. unsecured); (iii) landlord of the debtor may not terminate the lease without creditors council consent. The proceedings allow the debtor to restructure all its secured debt, if the new payment terms provided that the secured creditors would receive 100% of their claims. - Stay of enforcement is lifted if the debtor has not filed for the court's approval of the arrangement within 4 months. - The proceedings are mainly run by the restructuring advisor hired by the debtor who would act as arrangement supervisor.

According to a Supreme People's Court notice, Chinese courts have utilised and made full use of information technology in litigation since the outbreak of Covid-19. - online creditor meetings have been held

The State Duma passed amendments to the Insolvency Law to address the COVID-19 crisis, empowering the Government to introduce a moratorium on the filing of insolvency petitions (the ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩmoratoriumÔøΩÔøΩ?) and prescribing other supportive measures for debtors covered by the moratorium (ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩprotected debtorsÔøΩÔøΩ?), including a simplified procedure for the approval of settlement agreements. As a result: - The Government has introduced a moratorium on the filing of insolvency petitions from 6 April 2020 to 6 October 2020. The moratorium applies to a person if that person's main commercial activity is in the list of the industries most affected by COVID-19, or if the company is included in the list of companies systemically important for the national economy or of strategic enterprises. - The reform temporarily suspends a protected debtor's obligation to file an insolvency petition and limits the rights of other persons to file insolvency petitions in respect of the protected debtor during the moratorium period. - A protected debtor can voluntarily waive the benefit of the moratorium by way of a public announcement registered with the Unified Federal Register of Information Regarding Insolvency. Further, courts will not stay insolvency proceedings against protected debtors that were pending before 6 April 2020. - a simplified procedure for the approval of settlement agreements if insolvency proceedings of a protected person commence within three months after the termination of the moratorium has been introduced: settlement agreements must be approved by 50% of the creditors of a protected debtor present at the creditors' meeting and all secured creditors present at the creditors' meeting (rather than 50% of all registered creditors and all secured creditors). Additionally, a creditor may approve specific conditions of a settlement agreement with a protected debtor during the moratorium period, and it will be a valid approval of a settlement in the insolvency of the protected debtor. - a protected debtor that has filed an insolvency petition during the moratorium may apply for approval of a restructuring plan after the court introduces the first insolvency procedure and the first creditors' meeting takes place. There is no need for approval of the debt restructuring plan by the creditors. The court would approve it if the following criteria are met: the debtor's income for the accounting period in 2020 has decreased by 20% or more as compared to the relevant accounting period in a previous year (if the accounting period is not yet complete, the court would consider the debtor's income for 2019 and 2018); the debtor has no indebtedness on claims of compensation for damage to health or loss of life, or in relation to severance payments and employees' salaries; its creditors have not reached a decision on amicable settlement at a creditors' meeting; its creditors have not filed pre-moratorium insolvency petitions that have been returned by the court due to the introduction of the moratorium; and the debtor files an insolvency petition one month after the introduction of the moratorium or later (i.e. not earlier than 6 May 2020). -  Change in the consequences of insolvency of individual entrepreneurs if more than 50 % of their unsettled debt has matured during the moratorium and/or such debts were subject to a debt restructuring plan or a settlement agreement approved in court proceedings initiated during the moratorium. In this case, as compared to ordinary insolvency, after the insolvency proceedings are complete, the debtor may still be registered as an individual entrepreneur and carry out entrepreneurial activity, as well as hold positions in the management bodies, or otherwise participate in the management, of a legal entity (with the exception of a credit organization).  The Russian Supreme Court has decided that the courts have the right to extend procedural timeframes in the course of insolvency proceedings due to the COVID-19 crisis, depending on the circumstances of each specific case. Legislative amendments now set out the specific process for calculating the timeframes available for challenging suspicious or potentially preferential transactions by a protected debtor. If insolvency proceedings are initiated against a protected debtor within three months after the moratorium is terminated, the period available for challenging the above transactions will be calculated as the sum of the following three periods: the pre-commencement period: the challenge period for the relevant type of transaction under Articles 61.2 and 61.3 of the Insolvency Law, i.e. one month / six months / one year / three years, as applicable; the moratorium period: six months, unless the relevant period is extended by a decision of the Government; and the post-moratorium period: the period prior to the initiation of the insolvency proceedings, but, in any case, no more than three months. - Legislative amendments have been made to provide for the possibility of holding creditors', employees' and other meetings by absentee ballot. - Videoconference hearings where possible.  - From 19 March to 30 April 2020, all documents had to be filed electronically or by mail.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: There will be no charge for mobile money transactions of up to Ksh.1,000. The current tariff for transactions above Ksh.70,000 will remain.  There will be no charge by Payment Service Providers (PSPs) and commercial banks for transfers between mobile money wallets and bank accounts

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Customers will continue to be exempted from all charges and commissions for all bank transfer services until December 31st, 2020 Also: - 	With regards to mobile payment services, the following will continue: o	Issuance of e-wallets is free of charge and this extends to the creation of virtual cards  o	Canceling all commissions and fees related to transfers between mobile phone accounts. - 	Prepaid cards will be issued with no cost to the public.  - 	Fees and commissions related to cash withdrawals will continue to be canceled throughout the aforementioned period

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: The central bank extended the period to waive fees at ATMs, initially the period was extended for September 2020, but the central bank issued a new extension for December 2020

FEES 1.	Electronic money institutions (e-Mola, Vodafone M-Pesa and Mobile Wallet / mKesh) will provide free transfers from client to client up to the daily maximum of 1,000.00 MT. 2.	The commissions and charges to be charged for the new limits should not be higher than the maximum value of the price list in force. 3.	Banks no longer charge fees and commissions for transactions made through channels up to a maximum daily limit of 5,000.00MT, for individual customers, except for ATM withdrawals. 4.	Commissions and charges on transfers between banks and credit institutions are reduced by 50% LIMITS 1. The limit per transaction in the mobile wallet is adjusted from 25,000.00 MT to 50,000.00 MT. 2. The daily limit for transactions in the mobile wallet is adjusted from 125,000.00 MT to 250,000.00 MT. 3. The annual transaction limit for Tier I (tier I) customers in the mobile portfolio is adjusted to 400.000,00MT.

The Covid-19 (Temporary Measures) Act 2020 allows debtors affected by the coronavirus to enjoy the protection of a moratorium against a variety of obligations and legal actions, including the commencement of insolvency proceedings. These measures, along with the more stringent requirements needed to presume the debtor's inability to pay debts, is expected to reduce the number of insolvency cases.  The temporary insolvency measures Act relieves pressure on officers by introducing a defence against personal liability where they have incurred the debt in the ordinary course of business during the prescribed period and before the appointment of a judicial manager or liquidator in the case of companies, before the appointment of a liquidator for LLPs and before the passing of a resolution approving the windingup or the making of a court order directing winding-up of a registered business trust. This safe harbour provision acts as a safety net which allows businesses to carry on trading even while insolvent. The Act will make it more difficult for a company to be wound up compulsorily by the court on the basis that it is unable to pay its debts: - The Act will increase the minimum sum owing from SGD$10,000 to SGD$100,000 in the context of companies and LLPs.  - the statutory period to respond to demands from creditors will be extended from three weeks to six months.  These new requirements will apply so long as the written demand is made after the Act is in force. After the expiration of the Act, these measures will continue to apply to any written demand served during the prescribed period. - Under the Act, the right to commence insolvency-related proceedings is only affected when a notification of relief has been received. In such situations, there is a moratorium against commencing and continuing insolvency-related proceedings.

The court system suspended its services for a period of two weeks, from 24 February 2020 to 6 March 2020, and an additional two-week suspension (until 20 March 2020) was announced for the courts in Daegu. Even after such suspension period, an alternative operation system (weekly suspension by each tribunal) is planned until 17 April 2020.

The Royal Decree-Law 9/2020 of 27 March 2020, on urgent complementary measures in the labour area to mitigate the effects of Covid-19 provides that:  -  Debtors that are in insolvency will not have the duty to file for insolvency until 31 December 2020, even if the debtor has filed a 5bis Notice. - Courts will not process any applications for insolvency that have been submitted by creditors since 14 March 2020 (i.e., the date of the declaration of the State of Alarm). If by 30 December 2020 the debtor files for insolvency, the debtor's application shall be processed in preference, even if this application is submitted after the creditors' application for insolvency. In case the debtor has filed a 5bis Notice by 29 September 2020, the rules contemplated in the Spanish Insolvency Act will apply. As a result, the debtor will have 4 months to file for insolvency from the date of filing of the 5bis Notice. During those 4 months any petition for insolvency filed by a creditor will not be processed. It will have time to apply for insolvency until 29 January 2020.  - If a statutory or legal mandatory cause for winding-up occurs prior to or during the State of Alarm, the period for the management body to call a general shareholders' meeting (to adopt a dissolution resolution or resolutions to remove such cause) is postponed until the termination of the State of Alarm.

On 22 March 2020, the President of the Turkish Republic issued the Decree to Suspend Enforcement and Bankruptcy Proceedings. Accordingly: - Except for enforcement proceedings concerning alimony receivables, all pending enforcement, or debt collection, and bankruptcy proceedings for all corporates as well as individuals are suspended until 30 April 2020; and - The initiation of new enforcement and bankruptcy proceedings and implementing interim attachment orders has been prohibited for all corporates as well as individuals until 30 April 2020.
The CNBV issues regulatory facilities regarding remote onboarding of clients for credit institutions.
Banco de MÃ©xico decided to reduce the target for 50 basis points the overnight Interbank Interest Rate at a level of 4.5%.

Law 156 dated June 30, which established a formal moratorium on loans granted by banks, cooperatives and finance companies for all natural and legal persons economically affected by the national emergency due to the pandemic started second phase July 1.
SAMA has decided to extend the Deferred Payments Program for 3 months until December 14, 2020.

Level 3 policy measures: Reduce non-essential regulatory reporting requirements for banks
Details of the measure: The National Bank of Ukraine has identified the specifics of the submission of business recovery plans by Ukraine's banks and banking groups in 2020, allowing them: to extend the deadline for business recovery plan submission from 1 October to 1 December 2020, provided they are systemically important not to include into business recovery plans a list of critical functions (the termination/suspension of which can threaten the financial stability of Ukraine or have an adverse impact on its economy) to submit business recovery plans in electronic form only, signed with a respective digital signature. The relevant amendments are stipulated in NBU Board Resolution No. 128 On Amendments to NBU Board Resolution No. 46 dated 3 April 2020 dated 2 September 2020. The Resolution enters into force on the day following the day of its official publication.

Effective September 21, 2020, the Bank will reduce the amount it purchases at auction from 20 percent to 10 percent of tendered amounts. The Bank may adjust its purchase percentage further if market conditions warrant.

APRA has received and completed its review of all ADI comprehensive plans for the assessment and management of loans with repayment deferrals, provided in response to APRA's 9 July letter to all ADIs. Where applicable, any entity-specific feedback, or clarifying questions have been facilitated by APRA's supervisory teams.
A second period of deferred loan repayments/ moratoria that was recently allowed by the NBRNM

To reduce the negative effects of the coronavirus pandemic on exporters, the Ministry of Trade announced the "Stock Financing Support Package" for exporters who were left with excess stocks on failure to sell products due to the cancellation of orders and the decrease in demand. Loans within the scope of the package will be extended in TL from the CBRT on CGF guarantee.
The amount of total undue CBRT swap positions conducted via TL currency swap auctions was raised to 50% of the Foreign Exchange and Banknotes Markets transaction limits.

With the BRSA Decision No. 9010, an obligation of calculating a new ratio on daily and solo bases was introduced for banks to support the financing needs arising from the negative effects of the coronavirus pandemic on the production and employment of the real sector. Within the scope of the decision, the sum of TL placements, TL deposits, TL repo and TL loan transactions that banks will engage with financial institutions located abroad are limited to 0.5% of the most recently calculated equity. It was noted that the limitation would be effective until the exceptional conditions arising from the coronavirus pandemic would disappear.

The Union of Chambers and Commodity Exchanges of Turkey (TOBB) relaunched its SME financing project named "TOBB Breath Credit". The project loans target enterprises with a turnover below TRY 25 million and 80% of the loans are covered by the Treasury-backed CGF guarantee.

The amount of total undue swap sales (the CBRT's foreign currency purchases on spot, sales at maturity) conducted at the TL Currency Swap Market via the quotation method was raised to 30% from 20% of the Foreign Exchange and Banknotes Markets transaction limits.

Level 3 policy measures: Lower risks weights for credit with public guarantees
Details of the measure: With the BRSA Decision No.8999, it was decided to apply a 0% risk weight in the calculation of the value at credit risk of banks' receivables from the central government denominated in FX in accordance with the Standard Approach within the scope of the Regulation on Calculation and Evaluation of Capital Adequacy of Banks.

The Capital Markets Board of Turkey (CMB) introduced restrictions on the amount of FX-TL derivative transactions engaged by capital market institutions with non-residents due to increased imbalances and risks in global markets caused by the coronavirus pandemic. Within the scope of the restriction regarding TL purchase at maturity, the ratio of the said transactions to the equity capital amount pertaining to the previous month, which constitutes a basis for the most recent capital adequacy statements, was set at 1%. Meanwhile, it was decided that the ratio of the amount of derivative transactions involving TL sale at maturity to the equity capital amount pertaining to the previous month should not exceed: (i) 1% for transactions due in seven days, (ii) 2% for transactions due in 30 days, and (iii) 10% for transactions due in one year. Additionally, for both TL purchases at maturity and TL sales at maturity, any termination of the transaction before maturity or extension of the maturity, the written approval of the CMB was required.

With the BRSA Decision No.8989, revisions were made to the restrictions introduced in relation to banks' derivative transactions involving both TL purchase at maturity and TL sale at maturity due to increased imbalances and risks in global markets caused by the coronavirus pandemic. Within the scope of the restriction regarding TL purchase at maturity, the ratio of the said transactions to the most recently calculated legal equity was reduced to 1% from 10% and the application of different maturity-based weights utilized in the calculation of the total transaction amount was abandoned. Meanwhile, it was decided that the ratio of the amount of derivative transactions involving TL sale at maturity to the most recently calculated equity should not exceed: (i) 1% for transactions due in seven days, (ii) 2% for transactions due in 30 days, and (iii) 10 % for transactions due in one year. Additionally, for both TL purchases at maturity and TL sales at maturity, any termination of the transaction before maturity or extension of the maturity, the written approval of the BRSA was required.
The amount of the CBRT's total swap position to be established via TL Currency Swap auctions was raised to 30% from 20% of the Foreign Exchange and Banknotes Markets transaction limits.

Level 3 policy measures: Reduce non-essential regulatory reporting requirements for banks
Details of the measure: With the BRSA Decision No. 8976, in the scope of miscellaneous regulatory actions, the deadline for fulfilling the obligation of reporting, releasing or notifying the BRSA and other related authorities by banks, independent audit institutions, rating agencies, asset management companies and financial leasing, factoring and financing companies was extended by 60 days. Furthermore, apart from the additional time given above in the Regulation on Banks' Credit Transactions, in order to eliminate the problems that may occur in the credit allocations of banks, it was decided that records would be kept regarding missing documents that should be obtained under paragraph (1) of article 11/A of the said Regulation but could not be obtained from loan customers, and incomplete information and documents would be completed in six months' time following the loan allocation, and that missing information and documents among those requested from the existing loan customers pursuant to paragraph (2) of article 11/A would be completed by the end of 2020.

With a Presidential Decision published in the Official Gazette dated 25 March 2020 and No. 31079, principal and interest repayments of loans by tradesmen and craftsmen pertaining to April, May and June were postponed for three months and without interest once they declare themselves adversely affected by the pandemic.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: With a Presidential Decision published in the Official Gazette dated 30 March 2020 and No. 31084, the lending priority was given to firms and SMEs which had liquidity needs and collateral deficit as having been negatively affected by the pandemic developments.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: In order to financially support customers with household income of TRY 5,000 or less through public banks, a ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩBasic Needs SupportÔøΩÔøΩ? loan package was launched to meet the payments of the middle and low income groups, such as food expenses, rent, electricity, water and natural gas bills.

With an announcement made on 27 March 2020, the BAT shared the details of the CGF-backed ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩCheque Payment Support LoanÔøΩÔøΩ?, which aims to contribute to the protection of the commercial reputations of the bank customers, and the ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩEconomic Stability Shield Credit SupportÔøΩÔøΩ? aimed at meeting the working capital needs of corporate and commercial customers.

Level 3 policy measures: Caps on interest rates or fees
Details of the measure: With the BRSA decision No.8975, the minimum payment amount for personal credit cards was reduced to 20% from 30% of the credit card term debt.

Level 3 policy measures: Caps on interest rates or fees
Details of the measure: The CBRT revised the monthly maximum contractual interest rate for credit card borrowings in Turkish lira as 1.25% and the monthly maximum overdue interest rate as 1.55%, and the same rates for credit card borrowings in FX as 1.00% and 1.30%, respectively.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: A provisional article was added to the Law on Exclusion of the Records Regarding Bad Cheques, Protested Bills and Loans and Credit Card Debts No. 5834 and dated 22 January 2009. Accordingly, records regarding bad cheques, protested bills, credit cards and other credit debts of real and legal persons having default in the payments regarding the capital, interest and/or its ancillaries of the cash or non-cash credits whose payment dates in terms of the capital or installment were before 24 March 2020 as well as of individuals and credit customers kept with the Risk Center of the Banks Association of Turkey (BAT) will not be taken into consideration by credit institutions and financial institutions in financial transactions engaged with those persons on condition that the delayed part of the payments is paid or restructured in full until 31 December 2020. Restructuring of existing credit debts or extension of new credits by credit institutions and financial institutions in this scope will not have any legal or criminal liability for these institutions.

With the BRSA Decision No. 8970, the minimum deferral duration for loans to be monitored under Stage 2 category was increased to 90 days from 30 days, effective from 17 March 2020 to 31 December 2020.

According to the BRSA Decision No. 8967: - Within the scope of the Regulation on Calculation of Liquidity Coverage Ratio (LCR), the minimum ratio of 100% and 80% in the consolidated or unconsolidated total and FX LCR, respectively, may be disregarded, until 31 December 2020. Therefore, banks were temporarily exempted from issues such as notifying the BRSA about the causes of non-compliance and the measures planned to be taken, as well as the obligation to resolve the non-compliance within two weeks. On the other hand, LCR reporting will continue with the exception of development and investment banks (DIB). - Within the scope of the Regulation on Calculation and Evaluation of Liquidity Adequacy, DIBs are exempted from ratio limitations until 31 December 2020 although their obligation to send account statements continues.

According to the BRSA press release, until 31 December 2020; i) To support CAR: - In calculation of CAR, impairments in the fixed interest rate securities at fair value through other comprehensive income portfolio on 23 March 2020 may not be reflected in equities. - For monetary and non-monetary FX assets and related special provisions (excluding those monitored with historical costs) that are a component of the value at credit risk, the buying exchange rate on 31 December 2019 can be used. ii) With the regulation on FX Net General Position (FXNGP)/Capital ratio: - Value decrements of FX securities on 23 March 2020 may be disregarded in the calculation of the FXNGP, - The facility provided for calculation of CAR may also be used in calculation of equities.

The remuneration rate applied to reserve requirement maintained in terms of TL was reduced to 8% from 10% for banks that complied with the annual real credit growth conditions, and the 0% rate applied for banks that did not comply with the conditions was left unchanged.

Within the scope of the measures taken in response to the coronavirus pandemic, the CMB decided to implement the equity protection rate for margin trades to be completed to 35% (which was formerly 50%) if the collateral rate fell below that rate, effective from the decision date until further announcement. Besides, the CMB also decided to abandon the implementation of article 35 of the CMB CommuniquÃ© on Margin Trading, Short Sales and Lending and Borrowing of Securities, with Serial No.V-65. With the same decision, announcement or notification periods were extended for portfolio management companies, brokerage firms, mutual funds (including real estate, venture capital and stock exchange investment funds), pension investment funds, capital market instruments and businesses that are or are not traded on a stock exchange and/or other regulated market places.

To contain the adverse economic effects of the coronavirus pandemic, the BAT advised that (i) the credit demands of corporate firms, SMEs and individuals be assessed and met in a swift manner by considering the funding opportunities and the credit limit, (ii) opportunities to access loans and credit conditions be improved, (iii) credit channels be kept open, (iv) flexibility be provided with respect to maturity, payment, installment and collateral conditions, and (v) debt restructuring demands be concluded sooner rather than later.The BAT also indicated that it would be more beneficial for customers who proved to be adversely affected by the pandemic to be notified to the Risk Center as such so that a sounder assessment could be made for such customers.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: With the BRSA Decision No. 8950, the deferral duration of 90 days regarding the receivables to be liquidated was increased to 180 days for financial leasing and factoring companies and to 240 days for financing companies until 31 December 2020.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: With the BRSA Decision No.8948, the minimum deferral duration of 90 days for banks' non-performing loans was extended to 180 days effective till 31 December 2020. Thus, it will be possible to monitor loans with a deferral of up to 180 days under Stage 1 and Stage 2 portfolios. Moreover, the decision abolished the obligation of monitoring for loans that are currently monitored under Stage 3 portfolio and classified as performing loan after being restructured, and whose principal and/or interest payment is delayed more than 30 days during the one-year monitoring period or which are restructured once again during the monitoring period.

With the BIST Decision No.2020/21, the upper limit of the circuit breaker trigger rate applied in the instruments that are traded in the continuous trading method, was removed until further announcement, notwithstanding the lower limit at 5% effective since 13 March 2020.

The BRSA announced through a press release that as a part of its prudent supervision approach, the business continuity plans prepared by banks on a regular basis were reviewed and all necessary measures were taken.

With the BIST Decision of 12 March 2020 and No.2020/20, price margins were reduced to 10%, the circuit breaker triggering rate was reduced to 5% and circuit breaker order collection period was raised to 30 minutes applied in the equities traded in BIST Stars and BIST Main Market.

In view of the likely impacts of the noticeable surge in consumer loans on growth composition, inflation and external balance, as well as the increase in loan growth triggered by TL loans that were extended to facilitate early repayment or early restructuring of FX cash loans, the CBRT revised the reserve requirements (RR) practice that was linked to the annual real credit growth rate. The banks with an annual real loan growth rate above 15% were allowed to benefit from the RR incentives if their adjusted real loan growth rate, which is calculated by deducting the entire real changes in loans with a longer-than-two-year maturity extended to selected sectors and housing loans with a five-year and longer maturity from the numerator of the growth rate formula, was below 15%. Besides, banks with an annual real loan growth rate below 15% were allowed to benefit from the RR incentives if their adjusted real loan growth rate, which is calculated by deducting 75% of the real change in retail loans excluding housing loans with a five-year and longer maturity and the entire TL loans extended starting from 9 March 2020 to facilitate early repayment or early restructuring of FX cash loans from the numerator of the growth rate formula, was above 5%.

As a part of the measures taken to counter the likely effects of the coronavirus pandemic, FX RR ratios were reduced by 500 bp across all liability types and maturity brackets for banks that complied with the real credit growth conditions within the scope of the RR practice.

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: Provisional article restricts dividend distributions by joint-stock companies until 30/12/2020 to being less than 25% of the net profit for the year 2019. Additionally, profits of the previous years and the distributable reserves shall not be subjected to distribution. General assemblies shall not give the board of directors the authority to distribute advance dividends either.
Announced that businesses with at least a 25% decline in revenue can receive a  six month loan payment moratorium, starting January 1, 2021.

The Filipino government ordered relevant companies to refrain from applying interest, penalties, fees, and other charges during a grace period. This grace period applies to financing companies, lending companies, and microfinance non-governmental organizations.

Review the models used in the calculation of expected credit losses and determine factors unseen that were not taken into account when designing and verifying these models.  Checking the measurement of quality, adequacy and efficiency of information systems, and current and future information used in Models. Each bank must provide the Central Bank with a report approved by the two committees within a month of its date. Review and risk of the results of reviewing the models used in calculating losses. The expected credit ratings, including the adjustments made to those models and their impact on the portfolio Bank credit after calculation (ECL) according to the audit results.
BaFin will let less significant institutions under its supervision exclude certain exposures to central banks from the leverage ratio.
