Electronic money institutions (e-Mola, Vodafone M-Pesa and Mobile Wallet / mKesh) will provide free transfers from client to client up to the daily maximum of 1,000.00 MT. 2.	The commissions and charges to be charged for the new limits should not be higher than the maximum value of the price list in force. 3.	Banks no longer charge fees and commissions for transactions made through channels up to a maximum daily limit of 5,000.00MT, for individual customers, except for ATM withdrawals. 4.	Commissions and charges on transfers between banks and credit institutions are reduced by 50% LIMITS 1. The limit per transaction in the mobile wallet is adjusted from 25,000.00 MT to 50,000.00 MT. 2. The daily limit for transactions in the mobile wallet is adjusted from 125,000.00 MT to 250,000.00 MT. 3. The annual transaction limit for Tier I (tier I) customers in the mobile portfolio is adjusted to 400.000,00MT.

Level 2 policy measures: Enhancing tools for out-of-court debt restructuring and workouts
Details of the measure: The Royal Decree Law 16/2020 provides the following measures to maintain the continuity of companies subject to a refinancing agreement, creditors' arrangement or out-of-court agreements: - During the year following the declaration of the State of Alarm, a debtor may submit a proposal for the amendment of the creditors' arrangement that is into force. The amendment may not affect the claims accrued or incurred during the period of compliance of the original arrangement or the preferential creditors to whom the effectiveness of the arrangement has been extended or who have adhered to it once it has been approved, unless they vote in favour or they expressly adhere to the proposed amendment. The court will give notice of the requests for the declaration of noncompliance with the creditors' arrangement submitted by creditors within six (6) months since the declaration of the State of Alarm, but will not admit them for processing until three (3) months have elapsed since the end of this period. During those three months, the debtor may submit a proposal to modify the creditors' arrangement, which will be processed in priority to the application for the declaration of noncompliance. The same rules described above shall apply to out-of-court payment agreements. During the period of one year from the declaration of the State of Alarm, the debtor will not have the duty to request the opening of the liquidation phase when, during the effectiveness of the creditors' arrangement, the debtor becomes aware of the impossibility of fulfilling the committed payments and the obligations incurred after the approval of the creditors' arrangement, provided that the debtor submits a proposal for the modification of the creditors' arrangement and this is admitted for processing within this period. During the period of one year from the declaration of the State of Alarm, the court will not issue a ruling opening the liquidation phase even if the creditor proves the existence of one of the presumptions to declare the opening of the insolvency proceedings. Within one (1) year since the declaration of the State of Alarm, a debtor who has entered into a refinancing agreement approved by the court may inform to the court that it has commenced or intends to commence negotiations with its creditors aiming to amend the existing agreement or to reach a new one, even if one year has not elapsed since the previous application for approval (which is the time bar typically applicable for this type of agreements). During the six (6) months following the declaration of the State of Alarm, the court shall notify to the debtor any requests submitted by the creditors for the declaration of noncompliance with the refinancing agreement, but these requests will not be processed until one (1) month has elapsed from the end of the six (6) month period. During that month the debtor may inform to the court that it has commenced or intends to commence negotiations with its creditors to amend the agreement approved or to reach a new one, even if a year has not passed since the previous application for approval. If no agreement with creditors is reached within three (3) months since the debtor has inform to the court the commencement of negotiations, the court will admit for processing the creditors' requests to declare the noncompliance with the refinancing agreement. RDL 16/2020 foresees the following changes with regards to the classification of claims which determines the order of payment in the context of an insolvency proceedings: - In the event of failure to comply with the provisions of a creditors' arrangement approved or the amended arrangement within two (2) years since the declaration of the State of Alarm, claims deriving from cash receipts for loans, credits or other transactions of a similar nature granted to the debtor or deriving from personal or guarantees provided to the debtor by any person, including those who, according to the Spanish Insolvency Act, have the status of persons specially related to the debtor, shall be deemed to be ranked as super priority claims, provided that the creditors' arrangement or the amendment of such arrangement states the identity of the obligor and the maximum amount of the financing to be granted or the guarantee to be provided. - In insolvency proceedings declared opened within two years after the enactment of the State of Alarm claims derived from cash receipts for loans, credits or other transactions of a similar nature which, since the enactment of the State of Alarm, have been advanced to the debtor by those who, according to the Spanish Insolvency Act, have the status of person specially related to the debtor, will be considered as non-preferential unsecured claims (as opposed to the subordinated ranking that would apply otherwise).  - In insolvency proceedings declared opened within two years after the enactment of the State of Alarm, claims held by subrogated creditors who, according to the law, have the status of persons specially related to the debtor as a result of the payment of non-preferential unsecured or preferential claims made on behalf of the debtor from the time of the enactment of the State of Alarm, will be considered as non-preferential unsecured (and not subordinated). RDL 16/2020 foresees a series of rules to accelerate the processing of insolvency proceedings, providing a preferential processing of certain actions aimed at protecting workers' rights, maintaining the continuity of the company and preserving the value of debtor's assets and rights, as well as the simplification of certain acts and incidental pleas.  The State of Alarm establishes the suspension of the terms and the suspension and interruption of the procedural deadlines of all types of courts, including commercial courts. The calculation of procedural deadlines will be resumed when the State of Alarm or its extensions are no longer in effect.

Registrar's Circular No 4 of 2020, 5 April 2020: - All matters adjourned from 7 April 2020 to 4 May 2020 unless it is assessed to be essential and urgent. Certain applications for extension of time or variation of court orders relating to insolvency and restructuring matters are considered urgent. - Greater use of teleconferencing, videoconferencing for hearings, written submissions and email.  The courts will resume hearing cases from 8 June 2020. In order to facilitate cases which were adjourned and accumulated during the circuit breaker period, the court will not enter its usual recess in June. Remote hearings will continue to be used for various hearings. Safety measures such as limiting the number of people in court, temperature screenings and other social distancing measures will also continue.

The courts have generally been closed during this period of restricted movement under the MCO. For urgent civil applications, the courts allow a hearing to be conducted by way of an online text system known as e-Review, through exchange of emails or through video conferencing. On 22 April 2020, the Chief Registrar of the Federal Court announced that certain Court of Appeal hearings on 23 April 2020 would be conducted through video conferencing and will be streamed live on the court website.

The BoE provided guidance to FMIs with regards with distribution of profits: "When UK FMIs' boards are considering any distributions to shareholders or making decisions on variable remuneration, we expect them to pay close attention to the additional risks and potential financial and operational demands arising from Covid-19. We would expect you to discuss with us in advance of making any distribution to shareholders"
FCA will provide one additional year for trading venues and CCPs offering trading and clearing of exchange-traded derivatives to start applying open access rules.

The central bank eased compliance requirements including for payments infrastructure: Through 30 September 2020, banks may open bank accounts to clients without the personal presence of an individual opening an account or his/her representative, provided that a bank account opened in this period is needed to make or receive socially important payments.
The RBI extended the timeline for compliance with various payment system requirements

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Ministry of Tourism provided funds in the amount of 26 million HRK to subsidize the interest rate of up to two percentage points for liquidity lending to entrepreneurs involved in tourism activities as part of the COVID - 19 Measure. The COVID-19 Measure for SME entrepreneurs involved in tourism activities is implemented as a temporary measure within the working capital lending program, and is applied to requests which were received and approved by CBRD until 31/12/ 2020, or until the secured funds have been exhausted. Credit entitlement does not exist, rather the CBRD adopts a special decision regarding each request.

Level 3 policy measures: Reduce non-essential regulatory reporting requirements for banks
Details of the measure: The dates for the major UK banks and building societies to submit their first reports on their preparations for resolution and publicly disclose a summary of these reports have been extended by a year. These firms will now be required to submit their first reports to the PRA by October 2021 and make public disclosures by June 2022. The Bank will also make its first public statement on these firms' resolvability by June 2022. The decision to extend these deadlines has been taken to alleviate operational burdens on firms and ensure firms' senior management are able to engage fully in the RAF report submission and disclosure process.

Level 3 policy measures: Reduce non-essential regulatory reporting requirements for banks
Details of the measure: First, FDIC extended the submission date by 90 days, to September 29, 2020, for the resolution plans from Barclays, Credit Suisse, Deutsche Bank, and UBS. And second, the agencies extended the submission date by 90 days, to September 29, 2021, for the targeted resolution plans from the large foreign and domestic banks in Category II and Category III of the agencies' large bank regulatory framework.

Level 3 policy measures: Promoting digital channels in line with aml/cft requirements (via e-kyc, digital signature, and online document
Details of the measure: To ensure continuous operations of FX selling/remitting institutions, the BSP issued Circular No. 1080 dated 27 March 2020 (Operational relief measures for FX transactions under the FX Manual) and other related Circular Letters that allow electronic submission of all documentary requirements for FX sale and submission to FX-selling/remitting institutions of documents: (a) with e-signatures/digital signatures for those originally required to be in hardcopy and/or requiring signature; and (b) without e-signatures/digital signatures/required notarizations, subject to the conditions and required attestations under Item II.4 of Circular No. 1080. - Moreover, with the issuance of Circular No. 1080, the use of peso deposit account of non-residents (including those OFWs residing for more than a year outside the Philippines) for purposes of sending remittances may be facilitated amidst the community quarantine as the documentary requirements for sale of FX under said account could be submitted via electronic means.

Level 3 policy measures: Relief measures on customer identification (e.g. simplified cdd even in case of non-face-to-face relationships)
Details of the measure: To ensure continuity of their access to financial and government services, the BSP has eased the requirement for the presentation of valid identification document for customer onboarding and transactions during the said period (Memorandum No. M-2020-015 dated 30 March 2020 on Relief Measure on Customer Identification to Manage the Corona Virus Disease 2019 Situation).

Level 3 policy measures: Relief measures on customer identification (e.g. simplified cdd even in case of non-face-to-face relationships)
Details of the measure: Approval of amendments to the operational relief measures for BSP-supervised financial institutions under Memorandum No. M-2020-011 dated 19 March 2020 and M-2020-015 dated 30 March 2020. The amendments are effective until 31 March 2021.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Memorandum No. M-2020-008 dated 14 March 2020 - encourages BSP-supervised financial institutions (BSFIs) to temporarily suspend fees and charges imposed on the use of online banking platforms or electronic money to enable consumers to facilitate banking transactions during the COVID-19 situation.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Memorandum No. M-2020-027 dated 21 April 2020 ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ waives transaction fees charged for fund transfer instructions made with PhilPaSS during the ECQ period. As such, BSFIs are therefore urged to channel forward the temporary relief measure to the banking public.

Memorandum No. M-2020-041 dated 15 May 2020 ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ extends the temporary waiver of fees provided under M-2020-027 (waives transaction fees charged for fund transfer instructions made with PhilPaSS during the ECQ period) until 29 May 2020.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: Memorandum No. M-2020-031 dated 25 April 2020 - through collaborative efforts of the Philippine Payments Management, Inc. (PPMI), BSFIs have initiated the suspension of PESONet and InstaPay fees for the duration of the ECQ period. The same unified action is strongly encouraged to be extended for the fees charged by BSFIs for other fund transfer services and interbank ATM transactions.  In response to the BSP's call to strengthen the use of digital payments to help curb physical payment transactions amid the Covid-19 pandemic, some members of the PPMI will continue to extend the waiver of fees for PESONet and InstaPay transactions until end of 2020.

Loans granted to large enterprises shall be recognized as a form of alternative compliance with reserve requirements for banks and QBS effective 29 May 2020 up until 30 December 2021 (Circular No. 1087 dated 27 May 2020)

Level 3 policy measures: Relief measures on customer identification (e.g. simplified cdd even in case of non-face-to-face relationships)
Details of the measure: Order granting an exemption from customer identification program requirements for loans extended by banks (and their subsidiaries) subject to the jurisdiction of the Federal Banking Agencies to all customers to facilitate purchases of property and casualty insurance policies. Applicability to Institutions Under $1 Billion in Total Assets

Tap TLTRO with tenors of up to three years for a total amount of up to ÔøΩÔøΩ_1,00,000 crore at a floating rate linked to the policy repo rate. The scheme will be available up to March 31, 2021 with flexibility with regard to enhancement of the amount and period after a review of the response to the scheme. Liquidity availed by banks under the scheme has to be deployed in corporate bonds, commercial papers, and non-convertible debentures issued by the entities in specific sectors over and above the outstanding level of their investments in such instruments as on September 30, 2020. The liquidity availed under the scheme can also be used to extend bank loans and advances to these sectors.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: The Prime Minister announced the establishment of the MSME Revolving Fund to the value of E45million. The fund is targeted at assisting small and medium businesses that have been adversely affected by the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. The Prime Minister also announced that the funds will be distributed by EswatiniBank, a development finance institution.
Implemented a one-time 60-day grace period for all loans that are existing, current and outstanding, falling due, or any part thereof on or before 31 December 2020.

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: With the Law on Reducing the Effects of Coronavirus on Economic and Social Life numbered 7244 published in the Official Gazette numbered 31102 and dated April 17, 2020, the Provisional Article 13 was included in the Turkish Commercial Code numbered 6102 (ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩTCCÔøΩÔøΩ?) stipulating that: a) Stock companies are prohibited from distributing any dividend exceeding 25 percent of the net profit for the fiscal year 2019 until September 30, 2020. Accordingly, Board of Directors cannot be authorized to distribute any dividend for the mentioned time period. b) The companies, more than 50 % capital of which are directly or indirectly owned by the state, special provincial administration, municipality, village, other public legal entities, or funds, more than 50 % capital of which are owned by the state, are exempted from such limitation.

ASIC is extending the temporary relief for capital raisings and financial advice due to the continuing uncertain impacts of COVID-19. ASIC is also extending the financial advice relief related to the COVID-19 early release of superannuation scheme in light of the extension of the scheme by the Government.

The FCA has confirmed measures to ensure that firms provide tailored support for users of certain consumer credit and overdraft products who continue to face payment difficulties due to coronavirus (Covid-19).  The FCA expects firms to: - Recognise the uncertainties and challenges that many customers will face in the coming months as the crisis develops, and provide tailored support which reflects their individual circumstances.  - Work with customers approaching the end of a payment deferral to provide support before they miss payments.  - Be flexible and employ a full range of shorter and longer-term options to support their customers and minimise stress and anxiety experienced by customers in financial difficulty. - Give customers time and opportunity to repay and do not pressurise them into repaying their debt within an unreasonably short period of time.  - Put in place sustainable repayment arrangements which are affordable and take account of their customers' wider financial situation including their other debts and essential living expenses.  - Prevent customers' balances from escalating once they have put in place a repayment arrangement by suspending, reducing, waiving or cancelling any interest, fees or charges necessary to make that happen.  - Recognise and respond to the needs of vulnerable customers.

Level 2 policy measures: Consumer protection measures and ensuring availability and acceptance of cash
Details of the measure: FRA required nonbank microfinance providers (MFPs) to provide fee-free services, including electronic transactions.

Level 3 policy measures: Relief measures on customer identification (e.g. simplified cdd even in case of non-face-to-face relationships)
Details of the measure: SBS increased transaction (threefold) and account balance limits (fivefold) of basic accounts.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: SBS exempted, until 31 December 2020, e-money issuers from setting up a fideicomiso (civil law alternative to a trust) to safeguard client funds. Instead, the funds must be placed in a current account at an institution classified as at least A+ by a rating agency.

Level 3 policy measures: Promoting digital channels in line with aml/cft requirements (via e-kyc, digital signature, and online document
Details of the measure: The transaction and balance limits for e-money accounts were increased. From mid-May until 31 December 2020, institutions can open accounts for beneficiaries of G2P transfers without requiring clients to sign a contract and following simplified customer due diligence procedures

Level 3 policy measures: Reduce non-essential regulatory reporting requirements for banks
Details of the measure: On October 20, 2020, the FDIC Board of Directors voted to issue an interim final rule (IFR) to provide temporary relief from the Part 363 Audit and Reporting requirements for insured depository institutions (IDIs) that have experienced temporary growth.  The intent of the IFR is to neutralize burdens that IDIs may incur or have incurred because of temporary increases in their consolidated total assets resulting from participation in recent COVID-19-related stimulus activities, including the PPP, PPPLF, and MMLF, as the effort to develop processes and systems to comply with the requirements of Part 363 can be substantial.

Level 3 policy measures: Relief measures on customer identification (e.g. simplified cdd even in case of non-face-to-face relationships)
Details of the measure: In circulars issued earlier on March 26, the SBP had said that banks and microfinance banks should use National Database and Registration Authority (NADRA) Verisys instead of biometric verification for verification purposes to mitigate possible risks of identity theft. This measure has been extended from June 30 to December 31 for banks. In the case of microfinance banks, biometric verification will resume on January 31, 2021 for medium priority customers, and on March 31, 2021 for normal priority customers.

FRA required nonbank MFPs to provide, on a case by case basis, reduction or deferral of 50% of loan installments for a minimum of two months (total grace period to be determined individually) for loans current as of 29 March 2020. Deferred installments are to be paid after the ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩbasic installmentsÔøΩÔøΩ? are paid, at the end of the loan term.  MFPs are required to reduce financing costs for borrowers paying their installments regularly, exempt clients from accelerated payment fees, and pay, on behalf of their clients, the value of the compulsory credit life microinsurance premia until the end of the current exceptional period. Banks are required to inform customers of the costs of their moratoria.
Banks are required to meet all costs related to the extension and restructuring of loans, i.e., no fees are permitted.
Banks have been encouraged to provide loans without any collateral i.e. taking clean exposure of up to Rs 5 million

raised the remuneration rates on required lira reserves by 200 basis points for all banks, taking a further backdoor tightening step that rolls back measures it had adopted to ease the coronavirus fallout.  The central bank said banks that meet real loan growth requirements will have a 9% remuneration rate on lira required reserves, while the rate for others will be 2%.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: The government is extending for additional three months the grace period for the interest-free loans provided earlier to mitigate the pandemic's effect on the economy. It will also provide through the Development Bank of North Macedonia new low interest loans worth a total of 100 million euro to local companies.

The Government of FBiH will allocate BAM 20 million (around EUR 10 million) to the Guarantee Fund of the FBiH Development Bank, which provides commercial banks with loan guarantees for companies in strategic development sectors.

The Surinamese economy is officially running at a rate of SRD 14,018 for the purchase of the US dollar from September 22, while it is being sold for SRD 14,290 by the official exchange offices and foreign exchange banks.

Oficio MÃºltiple NÔøΩ 11150-2020-SBS: the SBS allowed regulated institutions to provide relief to borrowers who had been up to 15 days past due as at 29 February 2020, but were affected by the crisis. Initially, loan tenors could be extended for up to 6 months. Regulated institutions can provide this relief by modifying the contractual terms for borrowers (individuals and companies) upon their request or in bulk (without contacting/notifying each borrower). In the latter case, a borrower not interested in this special rescheduling must contact the lender.
Loan tenors could be extended for up to 12 months , for relief granted on or after 29 May 2020.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: OFICIO MÔøΩ_LTIPLE NÔøΩ 11170 - 2020 - SBS : The SBS allowed suspension of the counting of days past due for loans more than 15 days late as of 29 February

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: OFICIO MÔøΩ_LTIPLE NÔøΩ 13805-2020-SBS: The SBS allowed suspension of the counting of days past due for loans more than 15 days late as of 29 February. The suspension could last until the end of the state of emergency.

BOZ allowed all institutions to grant moratoria on principal and interest payments from 1 April 2020 for up to one year on existing credit facilities, without risk downgrading or reporting the event as a default to the credit reference bureau. Past due loans and NPLs can be included in the relief. If under specific liquidity support facilities provided by BOZ, the loan extension can be for more than one year. Relief is granted based on the lender's evaluation of a borrower's request. The decision to grant relief rests with the lender, but those institutions that benefited from the suspension of their obligations towards BOZ under the liquidity facility (Targeted Medium Refinancing Facility), are strongly encouraged to grant relief to their clients. Institutions may charge fees for granting the relief.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: According to the Presidential Decree, and until January 1, 2022, the State Fund for Entrepreneurship support, will provide subsides to exporters for pre-export trade financing credits (both existing and new loans), including working capital loans, on the following terms: a) for local currency loans - up to 50% of the interest rate, but no more than 10pp, b) for foreign currency loans - up to 50% of the interest rate, but no more than 5pp.

According to the Presidential Decree, and until January 1, 2022, the State Fund for Entrepreneurship support will provide partial credit guarantees for trade finance loans (including working capital loans), both new and existing, provided by banks, up to 50 percent of the loan amount and not exceeding 8 bln soms. The fees charged for these partial credit guarantees will be reduced by half.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: According to the Presidential Decree, an Export Support Fund is being created under the Export Promotion Agency, with 100 mln USD initial capital to be formed at the expense of the state Fund for Reconstruction and Development. The Fund will provide loans to banks for lending export operations, with a maturity of up to 1 year and amount not exceeding 1 mln USD, subject to a positive credit history of a borrower.

Fully implement  the existing  NBE  Directives that  provide for renegotiation i.e., refinancing and/or rescheduling of  loans and  advances  for  sectors that have been hardly hit by the impact of Covid-19 through undertaking case by case assessment and decision making at the discretion of each individual bank in a responsible manner;

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: Temporarily suspends the conditions stipulated under Article 6.1.6 of Asset Classification and Provisioning Directive No. SBB/69/2018 and Article 7.1.6 of Asset Classification and Provisioning for Development Finance Institution Directive No. SBB/52/2012 and the requirement for categorizing such renegotiated loans as substandard loans, 1.e . exempting bank's from holding provision that have been required otherwise on same.

Temporarily suspends Article 8.2 of Asset Classification and Provisioning Directive No. SBB/69/2018 that restricts bank's short term loan and advances from being at least 40%; and medium and lon g term loans and advances not to exceed 40% and 20% of the total loans and advances, respectively.

Level 3 policy measures: Prioritize or review critical supervisory actions
Details of the measure: Temporarily suspends undertaking of quarterly supervisory ratings on each individual bank except sending of the information to banks for their knowledge without necessarily requiring taking of rectification measures.
Extension of a debt moratorium to 12 months in respect of capital outstanding of leasing facilities granted to tourism related vehicles.

Level 3 policy measures: Caps on interest rates or fees
Details of the measure: Established maximum interest rates applicable on Sri Lanka Rupee (LKR) denominated loans and advances granted by LCBs and LSBs (interest rate on credit card advances ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ to 18% pa, on temporary overdrafts ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ to 16 pa, on money lent for pawing advances ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ to 10% pa)
Extension of a debt moratorium for tourism industry to 31 March 2021 (for banks)

Level 3 policy measures: Reduce non-essential regulatory reporting requirements for banks
Details of the measure: Delayed submission of returns under Section 31 . The provisions of Section 31 read with clause (t) of Section 56 of the Act shall not apply to Primary Co-operative Banks till December 31, 2020.

Level 3 policy measures: Reduce non-essential regulatory reporting requirements for banks
Details of the measure: Reserve Bank of India - for the State Co-operative Banks and Central Co-operative Banks  - extends the period for furnishing of the returns under Section 31 of the Act for the financial year ended on March 31, 2020 by a further period of three months in terms of the first proviso to the above section.  Accordingly, all State Co-operative Banks and Central Co-operative Banks shall ensure submission of the aforesaid returns to the Reserve Bank and NABARD on or before December 31, 2020.

Special Financial Relief Programme for individuals.  - Reduced Instalment Plans for Property Loans,: Individuals with residential, commercial and industrial property loans who are unable to resume making full loan repayments may apply to their respective bank or finance company to make reduced instalment payments pegged at 60% of their monthly instalment, for a period of up to 9 months. For most individuals, the 60% reduced monthly instalment will cover interest and partial principal payments. This will ease individuals' cashflow, while still allowing borrowers to pay down their principal amount. - Loan Tenure Extension for Renovation and Student Loans: Individuals with renovation and student loans may apply to their respective bank to extend their loan tenures by up to 3 years. This will lower individuals' monthly instalments and ease their cashflow burden. - Extended Assistance for Personal Unsecured Credit and Debt Consolidation Plan: Individuals who face difficulty repaying their unsecured revolving credit facilities, who can provide proof of income impact of at least 25% and with repayments that are between 30 and 90 days past due, may apply to their lender till 30 June 2021 to convert their outstanding balances to term loans at a reduced interest rate.
Special Financial Relief Programme. Partial Deferment of Principal Payments on Secured SME Loans and Loans under Enterprise Singapore. Customised Restructuring Programmes.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) announced that it will extend the MAS SGD Facility for ESG Loans. The Facility will provide Singapore Dollar (SGD) funding at an interest rate of 0.1% per annum for a two-year tenor to eligible financial institutions to support loans made under the TBLP and the Enterprise Financing Scheme ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ SME Working Capital Loan (the ESG Loan Schemes) from 1 April 2021 to 30 September 2021.

In March of this year, the (COVInsAG) suspended the obligation to file for insolvency for the managers of companies that have become insolvent as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic and still have prospects of reorganizing themselves by taking advantage of government assistance or in other ways. The suspension of the application obligation expires on September 30, 2020. The changes provide for the suspension of the application obligation to be extended to December 31, 2020.

UniCredit and the European Investment Bank (EIB) have agreed to provide new resources aimed at stimulating the recovery of the pandemic-hit economy. They have just signed an agreement that will see the EIB allocate ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ200 million to UniCredit to lend on to SMEs (companies with up to 250 employees) and mid-caps (up to 3 000 employees)

Businesses in England required to close due to local lockdowns or targeted restrictions will now be able to receive grants worth up to ÔøΩ1,500 every three weeks, To be eligible for the grant, a business must have been required to close due to local Covid 19 restrictions. The largest businesses will receive ÔøΩ1,500 every three weeks they are required to close. Smaller businesses will receive ÔøΩ1,000.

ÔøΩ5million Equity Investment Fund targeted at early stage and seed stage SMEs. he Covid-19 Equity Investment Fund will provide matching equity investment or convertible loan notes of up to a maximum of ÔøΩ700,000 for technology and innovative businesses. The scheme is typically focussed on the sectors of advanced manufacturing, materials and engineering, digital and creative technologies, life and health sciences, cyber security, precision medicine, big data, internet of things and analytics.

The FCA has published additional guidance setting out how firms should provide tailored support to mortgage borrowers who have benefitted from payment deferrals under the current guidance and who continue to face financial difficulties, as well as those whose financial situation may be affected by coronavirus after 31 October.

The Bank of Japan, acting as agent of the Minister of Finance of Japan, and Bank Negara Malaysia signed the second Bilateral Swap Arrangement (BSA). This BSA enables both authorities to swap their local currencies (i.e. Japanese Yen and Malaysian Ringgit, respectively) for US Dollar. The arrangement will provide up to USD 3 billion for both countries.

The Bank of Japan, acting as agent of the Minister of Finance of Japan, and Bank Negara Malaysia signed the second Bilateral Swap Arrangement (BSA). This BSA enables both authorities to swap their local currencies (i.e. Japanese Yen and Malaysian Ringgit, respectively) for US Dollar. The arrangement will provide up to USD 3 billion for both countries.

Level 3 policy measures: Reduce non-essential regulatory reporting requirements for banks
Details of the measure: Extension of time to submit monthly accounting and regulatory data requirements.  Extension also for submitting supervision reports and financial statements for publication. Deadline is now December 9 2020.

Time extension for submitting the quarterly Suspicious Transaction Report (STR) and the annual report on the prevention of money laundering and financing of terrorism. Deadline is now December 09, 2020.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Credit line for productive investments for MSMEs with specific terms and maximum interest rates. Mandatory minimum balance for certain institutions (i.e., large banks).
Banxico decided to lower the target for the overnight interbank interest rate by 50 basis points to 6%.

Level 3 policy measures: Ensure minimal functionality in the primary and secondary markets
Details of the measure: Increase of liquidity during trading hours to facilitate the optimal functioning of financial markets and payment systems.

IVASS recommends undertakings to refrain, at least until 1 January 2021, from: -making a dividend distribution or giving an irrevocable commitment to make a dividend distribution; -buying back ordinary shares; - creating an obligation to pay the variable remuneration component to key managers. IVASS will closely monitor compliance with these recommendations.

Extension to January 31 2021 of the following IVASS recommendations on limitations to: -making a dividend distribution or giving an irrevocable commitment to make a dividend distribution; -buying back ordinary shares; - creating an obligation to pay the variable remuneration component to key managers.

The FCA announces proposals to help customers who hold insurance and premium finance products and who continue to face financial difficulties because of coronavirus (Covid-19) to: (i) reduce the impact of financial distress, (ii) ensure that customers continue to have insurance that meets their needs.

FCA ssued guidance to help borrowers with interest-only and partial capital repayment (part-and-part) mortgages whose mortgages have matured since 20 March 2020 or will do so in the next 12 months, given the impact of the Covid-19 (coronavirus) pandemic. The measures announced are: - making a new rule that will make it easier for lenders to offer switching options to consumers who are in a closed book within the same financial group. This would mirror the flexibility that active lenders have, under our existing rules, when their existing customers wish to switch. - issuing guidance stating that firms should allow borrowers to delay repayment of the capital at maturity on interest-only and part-and-part mortgages up to 31 October 2021, provided borrowers are up-to-date with payments and they continue to make interest payments The rule will come into force from 23 October 2020. The guidance will come into force from 31 October 2020.

The Board of Directors of Banco de la RepÃºblica (the Central Bank of Colombia, BDBR) reduced the benchmark interest rate by a quarter percentage point from 2% to 1.75%.https://www.banrep.gov.co/en/board-directors-banco-republica-central-bank-colombia-bdbr-reduced-benchmark-interest-rate-quarter

The Board of Directors of the Central Bank (BDBR) decided to roll over the non-delivery forward contracts for the sale of US dollars through auctions held on the dates of maturing contracts until 30 October 2020..

The Board of Directors of the Central Bank (BDBR) decided to roll over non-delivery forward contracts for the sale of US dollars through auctions held on the dates of maturing contracts until 27 November 2020.

With the Board Decision dated 18.04.2020, all deposit and participation banks became subject to compliance with an Asset Ratio (AR) requirement, effective 01.05.2020. AR is designed to accelerate the flow of bank funding into the economy, thereby mitigating the adverse economic effects of the COVID-19 pandemic.  The amended AR formula is as follows: numerator (Loans + (Securities x 0.75) + (CBRT Swaps x 0.5)); denominator (TRY Deposit + (FX Deposit x 1.75* )) * For the portion of the ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩFX DepositÔøΩÔøΩ? item up to the amount FX Loans, this coefficient shall be applied as 1.

The asset ratio (AR), which was determined as 100% for deposit banks and 80% for participation banks in the Board Decision No. 9000, should be regulated as 95% and 75% respectively, and within this scope
The Asset Ratio, which was determined as 95% for deposit banks and 75% for participation banks in the Board Decision 10.08.2020-9125, shall be applied as 90% and 70% respectively.

Extension of a debt moratorium for further 6 months commencing form October 1, 2020 until March 31, 2021. The moratorium should be granted for both capital and interest on the request made by affected borrowers (for licensed commercial banks). Extension can be requested by COVID-hit businesses and individuals by 30 November. For pawning facilities due dates falling during moratorium period extended until 01 April 2021.
Central Bank extends the Grace Period of 4% Working Capital Loan Scheme (all 3 Phases) from 6 Months to 9 Months
The Bank will discontinue the Bankers' Acceptance Purchase Facility (BAPF) and the Canada Mortgage Bond Purchase Program (CMBP) with the last operation scheduled for October 26, 2020.

As overall financial market conditions continue to improve in Canada, usage in several of the Bank of Canada's programs that support the functioning of key financial markets has declined significantly. Effective on October 21, 2020 the Bank of Canada will reduce the frequency of its Term Repo operations from weekly to bi-weekly. In addition, effective immediately, the eligible securities for regular Term Repo operations will include only Canadian dollar-denominated marketable securities that are directly-issued or explicitly guaranteed by the Government of Canada or by a Canadian provincial government and that are eligible for the Standing Liquidity Facility.

The Bank of Canada is announcing its intention to introduce a Corporate Bond Purchase Program (CBPP). To support the flow of credit for corporate issuers in Canada, the CBPP will purchase eligible corporate bonds in the secondary market. The program size will be capped at $10 billion and will be restricted to senior secured and unsecured bonds originated by Canadian incorporated companies with a remaining maturity of up to 5 years and a minimum credit rating of BBB or equivalent.

Extension of the need to  obviate the need to conduct face-to-face (ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩF2FÔøΩÔøΩ?) meetings in order to minimize the risk of infection during the sale process of insurance policies, the Insurance Authority (ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩIAÔøΩÔøΩ?).

The Central Bank of Egypt (CBE) cut rates by 50 bps in November 2020, following 50 bps cut in September 2020 . The CBE's overnight deposit rate now stands at 8.25% and the lending rate is 9.25%, while the main operation and discount rates are 8.75%. This is to support the economic recovery after the slump induced by COVID-19. The CBE has now shaved 400 bps over three interest rate cuts since the beginning of 2020.
The Central Bank of Egypt (CBE) cut interest rates by 50 bps on September 24, 2020. This was the first cut since the emergency 300 bps rate cut in March 2020 in response to COVID-19.

According to the CBE circular released on September 14, 2020, banks were instructed to be flexible on a case by case basis in light of the current economic situation. If an extension beyond the initial six months is needed, then it could be considered depending on the case; or the loan could be restructured. The CBE did not extend the moratorium.

Level 2 policy measures: Promoting and ensuring availability of digital payment mechanisms
Details of the measure: The Bank of Mozambique decided to extend until December 31, 2020, the increase in the limits in mobile money transactions and balances. On the other hand, the Bank of Mozambique did not extend the elimination and reduction in some fees and commissions charged in mobile money and electronic transfers.

The Executive Board of the National Bank of Moldova (NBM) voted unanimously to reduce the base rate applied to the main short-term monetary policy operations by 0.1 percentage points, to 2.65 percent annually. Similarly, interest rates on overnight loans and deposits were reduced to 5.15 percent and 0.15 percent annually, respectively.

Measures for credit restructurings, including computing a lower amount of specific reserves when a restructuring is agreed with the client, recognition of the specific reserves that are released by the restructuring of a loan as additional reserves, recognize higher regulatory capital by considering additional reserves as part of complementary capital, and reducing capital requirements for credit risk.
To encourage financial inclusion and the granting of new credits, the following measure will be carried out: a) the use of the capital buffer is extended until December 31, 2021.
Reduction in the cash rate target, the three-year yield target and the interest rate on new drawings under the Term Funding Facility to 10 basis points, from the current 25 basis points.
Reduction in the interest rate on Exchange Settlement balances to zero from the current 10 basis points.

Introduction of a program of government bond purchases. In particular, we are intending to buy $100 billion of government bonds over the next six months, purchasing bonds issued by the Australian Government as well as by the states and territories.

The Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA) has published a new frequently asked question (FAQ) for authorised deposit-taking institutions (ADIs) on the credit risk capital treatment of loans covered by the Coronavirus SME Guarantee Scheme.

The Government will undertake a significant reform to Australia's insolvency framework. Key elements of the reforms include: - The introduction of a new debt restructuring process for incorporated businesses with liabilities of less than $1 million, drawing on some key features of the Chapter 11 bankruptcy model in the United States. - Moving from a rigid one-size-fits-all ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩcreditor in possessionÔøΩÔøΩ? model to a more flexible ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩdebtor in possessionÔøΩÔøΩ? model which will allow eligible small businesses to restructure their existing debts while remaining in control of their business. - A rapid twenty business day period for the development of a restructuring plan by a small business restructuring practitioner, followed by fifteen business days for creditors to vote on the plan. - A new, simplified liquidation pathway for small businesses to allow faster and lower cost liquidation. - Complementary measures to ensure the insolvency sector can respond effectively both in the short and long term to increased demand and to meet the needs of small business. The reforms will cover around 76 per cent of businesses subject to insolvencies today, 98 per cent of whom who have less than 20 employees.

The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System issued a final rule that neutralizesÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩdue to the lack of credit and market riskÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩthe regulatory capital and liquidity effects for banks that participate in certain Federal Reserve liquidity facilities.

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: Federal Reserve Board announces it will extend for an additional quarter several measures to ensure that large banks maintain a high level of capital resilienceFor the fourth quarter of this year, large banksÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩthose with more than $100 billion in total assetsÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩwill be prohibited from making share repurchases. Additionally, dividend payments will be capped and tied to a formula based on recent income

OSFI is announcing an eight-month extension for DTIs to continue to exclude central bank reserves and sovereign-issued securities from their leverage ratio exposure measures. Accordingly, these exposures will be exempted from the leverage ratio until December 31, 2021.
Reserve Bank of India defer the implementation of NSFR guidelines by six months. These guidelines will now come into effect from October 1, 2020 as against April 1, 2020.

In view of the continued uncertainty on account of COVID-19, on a review, the Reserve Bank of India has decided to defer the implementation of NSFR guidelines by a further period of six months. These guidelines shall now come into effect from April 1, 2021.
The Reserve Bank of India decided to defer the implementation of the last tranche of 0.625 per cent of the Capital Conservation Buffer (CCB) from September 30, 2020 to April 1, 2021.

The Reserve Bank of India decided to conduct open market operations (OMOs) in State Developments Loans (SDLs) as a special case during the current financial year. The OMOs would be conducted for a basket of SDLs comprising securities issued by states.

Details of the measure: The Reserve Bank of India revised limits for the risk weight of regulatory retail portfolios and rationalized risk weights for individual housing loans.
Repealing of the asset ratio (AR) as of 31.12.2020.

Details of the measure: Guidelines for Non Face-to-Face Customer Identification and Verification Using Electronic Interface Provided by the Department for Registration of Persons.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: The Prudential Regulatory Authority (PRA) modified the minimum provisioning requirements available to all consenting Credit Unions from Saturday 2 January 2021 until Saturday 31 December 2022. Minimum provisioning requirements for bad debt will be reduced to the rates set out  by the PRA.
Borrowers will benefit from a suspension of payments and interest on their Canada Student Loans for six months, which can be extended up to a total of 18 months of leave.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC), the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (collectively, the agencies) published a rule finalizing the interim final rule to delay the estimated impact on regulatory capital stemming from the implementation of Accounting Standards Update No. 2016-13, "Financial InstrumentsÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩCredit Losses (Topic 326): Measurement of Credit Losses on Financial Instruments" (CECL) by banks.
The liquidity requirements are extended until March 2021, with which banks will be able to temporarily reduce their liquidity buffers below 100% of their needs.

Level 3 policy measures: Relief measures on customer identification (e.g. simplified cdd even in case of non-face-to-face relationships)
Details of the measure: To encourage financial inclusion and the granting of new credits, the following measure will be carried out: the regulation that allows the opening of accounts and contracting of credits without the need for the client to go to the branch is extended to legal entities.
Extension of the securities eligible for the Ordinary Additional Liquidity Facility, foreign exchange hedging program operations, and USD credit operations.
Extension of counterparts eligible for the Ordinary Additional Liquidity Facility (FLAO).
Open a facility to repurchase government securities at longer terms than those of regular open market operations.

Level 3 policy measures: Ensure minimal functionality in the primary and secondary markets
Details of the measure: Implement a debt securities temporary swap facility to provide liquidity for trading instruments.

Level 3 policy measures: Ensure minimal functionality in the primary and secondary markets
Details of the measure: Implement a corporate securities repurchase facility through credit institutions in order to provide liquidity to short-term corporate securities and long-term corporate debt
Open a financing facility for commercial and development banks to allow them to channel resources to SMEs and individuals.
Collateralized financing facility for commercial banks with corporate loans, to finance micro, small- and medium-size enterprises.
Swaps of government securities.

Level 3 policy measures: Ensure minimal functionality in the primary and secondary markets
Details of the measure: Foreign exchange hedges settled by differences in US dollars with counterparts not domiciled in the country, to be traded during hours when Mexican markets are closed.
Lower amount of specific reserves when a restructuring is agreed with the client.

Details of the measure: Recognition of the specific reserves that are released by the restructuring of a loan as additional reserves. Banks will be able to recognize higher regulatory capital by considering additional reserves as part of complementary capital.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in capital requirement (definition of capital, car, risk weights)
Details of the measure: Prudently reduce capital requirements for credit risk in restructured loans.

Phase 2 of the temporary facilitative measures to tackle the outbreak of COVID-19

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: Bulgaria's Fund of Funds (FoF) provided micro loans to local start-ups at more relaxed terms as another step to support businesses during the coronavirus pandemic. The funds earmarked for micro-lending with shared risk amount to 23.9 million levs ($14.5 million/12.2 million euro) undert the EU's Operational ProgrammeÔøΩÔøΩHuman Resource Development 2014-2020.The loans are granted for the acquisition of tangible and non-tangible assets intended for developing and expanding business operations andÔøΩÔøΩcan also be used to cover other costs relating to the core business.The loan size can be up to some 48,900 levs, while the repayment period is up to ten years. An optional grace period of up to three years for the loan principal and/or interest payment,ÔøΩÔøΩa possibility to make small loans of up to 5,000 levs,ÔøΩÔøΩand a waiver on the requirementÔøΩÔøΩfor no previous profit distributions are also among the more favourable terms offered to the applicants.
The FCA has now confirmed updated guidance to firms setting out enhanced support that should be available to mortgage borrowers experiencing payment difficulties as a result of coronavirus.

The FCA has confirmed updated guidance to firms setting out enhanced support that should be available to consumer credit customers experiencing payment difficulties as a result of coronavirus (Covid-19).  The guidance covers users of personal loans, credit cards, store cards, catalogue credit, rent to own, buy now pay later, pawnbroking, motor finance and high-cost short-term credit.  The FCA provided more detail about who is able to apply for payment deferrals under today's finalised guidance.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: The Kazakhstan central bank allocated additional 200 billion tenge ($470 million) for lending to large businesses and entrepreneurs in the agricultural sector, affected by the (COVID-19 pandemic-related) state of emergency, within the concessional lending program for business entities. The bank extended the program's term until December 31, 2021, and the term for the allocation's disbursement - up to March 31, 2021.

Level 3 policy measures: Caps on interest rates or fees
Details of the measure: Introduced maximum interest rates on mortgage backed housing loans obtained by salaried employees from licensed banks. Accordingly, licensed banks will be made to charge only 7 per cent per annum for such loans, at least for the first five years of the loan tenure.

Central Bank has directed all licensed commercial banks and National Savings Bank to suspend the purchase of Sri Lanka International Sovereign Bonds (ISBs) for six months unless such purchase is funded by new foreign currency inflows sourced from abroad.
(BCRD) announced that it will inject US $ 200 million into the foreign exchange market, in addition to its regular participation through its Electronic Foreign Currency Trading Platform.

The BCRA raised the overnight reverse repo rate to 31% from 30%, and the seven-day reverse repo rate to 34.5% from 33%, and left the benchmark Leliq interest rate unchanged at 36%, but did so without releasing an official statement.

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: All Commercial Banks and All Cooperative Banks shall not make any dividend payment on equity shares from the profits pertaining to the financial year ended March 31, 2020.

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: The PRA also expects banks not to pay any cash bonuses to senior staff, including all material risk takers, and is confident that bank boards are already considering and will take any appropriate further actions with regard to the accrual, payment and vesting of variable remuneration over coming months.

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: At the end of March 2020, the Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) welcomed the decisions of the boards of the large UK banks to suspend dividends and buybacks on ordinary shares until the end of 2020. At the PRA's request they also cancelled payments of any outstanding 2019 dividends and restricted cash bonus payments to senior staff.  The PRA judges that an extension of the exceptional and precautionary action taken in March is not necessary and that there is scope for banks to recommence some distributions should their boards choose to do so, within an appropriately prudent framework.

Throughout  the  duration  of up to  90  days  of  the  moratorium,  the  Creditor  Banks shall be committed to applying the following rules: - they  do  not  exert  any  unilateral  pressure  on  the  debtor  for  the  repayment  of obligations; - they do not make any efforts for improving their position relative to the rest of Creditor Banks, - take no additional guarantees (collateral) from the assets of the borrower - they do not continue any legal proceedings initiated before the signature of the agreement between banks and the distressed borrower, except for those which are necessary to avoid the loss of legal rights;  - they do not undertake any new unilateral legal actions or proceedings.

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: In light of the ongoing economic uncertainty and to preserve the strength of the banking sector, the Board is extending the current restrictions on distributions, with modifications. For the first quarter of 2021, both dividends and share repurchases will be limited to an amount based on income over the past year. If a firm does not earn income, it will not be able to pay a dividend or make repurchases.

The deadline for postponing the payment of loan installments is 3 months, from March 16 to June 16, 2020, for borrowers who have encountered financial difficulties as a result of declining personal or business income due to Covid 19.
CBK in June allowed applications for up to 1-year loan extensions and restructuring on a case by case basis.
The lending institutions will not apply punitive interest in relation to lending subject to credit repayment moratorium.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)
Details of the measure: The lending institutions will not apply a change of credit classification to borrowers and the CBK will not require additional provisions from these institutions for deferred loans.

BSP lowered the interest rate by 25 bps to a new low of 2.0%. It also cut the rates on the overnight deposit and lending facilities to 1.5% and 2.5%, respectively. This s the fifth reduction this year.
The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) announced today (Thursday) the extension of the temporary US Dollar Liquidity Facility to 30 September 2021.

The Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council on behalf of its members (collectively referred to as FFIEC members) is issuing this joint statement to provide prudent risk management and consumer protection principles for financial institutions to consider while working with borrowers as loans near the end of initial loan accommodation periods applicable during the Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID event).

The Federal Reserve Board on Thursday extended to March 31, 2021, temporary actions aimed at increasing the availability of intraday credit extended by Federal Reserve Banks on both a collateralized and uncollateralized basis. These temporary actions: (1) suspend uncollateralized intraday credit limits (net debit caps) and waive overdraft fees for institutions that are eligible for the primary credit program; (2) permit a streamlined procedure for secondary credit institutions to request collateralized intraday credit (max caps); and (3) suspend two collections of information that are used to calculate net debit caps.
Extension of the Commercial Paper Funding Facility through March 31.
Extension of the Money Market Mutual Fund Liquidity Facility through March 31st 2021.
Extension of the Primary Dealer Credit Facility through March 31st, 2021.
Extension of the Paycheck Protection Program Liquidity Facility through March 31st, 2021.

The Federal Reserve announced the extensions of its temporary U.S. dollar liquidity swap lines and the temporary repurchase agreement facility for foreign and international monetary authorities (FIMA repo facility) through March 31, 2021.

As part of Covid-19-related measures, the European Central Bank and the NBG agreed to launch a ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ100 million euro repo line to support liquidity. This line was introduced under the framework of the Eurosystem repo facility  for  central banks (EUREP). The purpose of the instrument is to supply euro liquidity to the Georgia's financial system in case of need. The mechanism will be in force until June 30, 2021, and its operational support will be provided by the German Bundesbank.

Measures are enacted to speed up access to and processing of insolvency processes in order to a) facilitate protection of debtors facing difficulties or the liquidation of assets of debtors who lack the capacity to continue to carry out their corporate purpose, b) implement other mechanisms to facilitate the reduction in timing of the procedures and increasing the installed capacity of justice assistants to attend to them.
For start-ups and venture companies, 2.2 trillion won (US$1.8 billion) will be given also through loan guarantees.
Loans must be restructured to allow businesses to recover and have interest rates lowered to 20 percent.

the NBS prescribes an obligation for banks and lessors to approve debt repayment facilities to debtors (natural persons, farmers, entrepreneurs and companies) who due to the conditions caused by the COVID-19 pandemic have or may have difficulties in the repayment of liabilities, at their request.
cut its key repo rate from 1.25% to 1.0% to support the economy during the coronavirus crisis

Details of the measure: In September 2020, in collaboration with the African Development Bank, the authorities created a credit line for banks to provide lending to small and medium enterprises (SME) affected by the pandemic. To access the credit lines, investment by SMEs must have received the favorable technical opinion of the National Investment Agency.

The Reserve Bank announced:  - a reduction in the cash rate target to 0.1 per cent - a reduction in the target for the yield on the 3-year Australian Government bond to around 0.1 per cent - a reduction in the interest rate on new drawings under the Term Funding Facility to 0.1 per cent - a reduction in the interest rate on Exchange Settlement balances to zero
The Reserve Bank announced the purchase of $100 billion of government bonds of maturities of around 5 to 10 years over the next six months.

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: The Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA) has provided updated capital management guidance to authorised deposit-taking institutions (ADIs) and insurers, replacing its recommendation in July this year for banks to retain at least half of their earnings. From the start of 2021, APRA will no longer hold banks to a minimum level of earnings retention.

The Australian Securities and Investment Commission issued  a high-level practical guidance to support board oversight and the exercise of discretion on the variable pay outcomes of large listed companies' most senior executives (cash and/or equity).

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority, after discussions with the Banking Sector SME Lending Coordination Mechanism, has decided to extend the Pre-approved Principal Payment Holiday Scheme by six months. With such an extension, the principal payments of all loans of eligible corporate borrowers (i.e. borrowers with an annual turnover less than HK$800 million and with no loan payment overdue for more than 30 days as at 1 November 2020) falling due between 1 November 2020 and 30 April 2021 should be deferred by six months except for repayments of trade loans, which should be deferred by 90 days.

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: The Bank of Italy, at least until 30 September 2021, the Least Significant Institutions, to 1. refrain from deciding on or paying out dividends/cash pay-out reducing the quantity or quality of CET 1 capital or limit the amount to no more than 15% of the accumulated profit for the financial years 2019 and 2020, or no more than 20bp in terms of the CET 1 ratio, whichever is lower; - refrain from deciding on or paying out provisional dividends/cash pay-out in relation to profit for 2021; - exercise extreme prudence in calculating variable remuneration.

Bank of Japan  extend the duration of the Special Program to Support Financing in Response to the Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) by 6 months and make adjustments to the program, with a view to continuing to support financing, mainly of firms.

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: Banks are restricted from paying bonuses or dividends if their cost-to-income ratios are above 55% or the non-performing loans ratio is above 5%
The Office of the Superintendent of Financial Institutions lowered the Domestic Stability Buffer by 1.25% to 1%.

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: The Office of the Superintendent of Financial Institutions set the expectation for all federally regulated financial institutions that dividend increases and share buybacks should be halted for the time being.

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: The Superintendent confirmed the expectation that institutions will not increase regular dividends, undertake common share buybacks or raise executive compensation.

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: The FSC announced its decision to recommend banks to temporarily limit dividends within twenty percent of their net profits until the end of June this year as it is deemed necessary to maintain banks' loss absorbing capacity in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.
The central bank postponed (to March 31, 2021) the deadline of the ban on financial institutions charging fees or commissions on transactions through ATMs.

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: Extension through 30/06/2021 on the ban on the distribution of profits.

Details of the measure: The central bank relaxed the classification of banks' debtors by extending of 60 days the "days into arrears" parameter for each category

Level 3 policy measures: Caps on interest rates or fees
Details of the measure: Cap on interest rates applied on loans to microenterprises.

Level 3 policy measures: Relaxation in npe treatment (definition, classification, provisioning)

The CB postponed until 1-1-22 the application of IFRS 9 on financial asset impairment for small banks.
The CB postponed until 1-1-21 the application of IFRS 9 on financial asset impairment for small banks.

Grants  to Companies, businesses, self-employed persons, associations and institutions affected by the temporary closings . Grants per week of closings amounting to 75 percent of the average weekly turnover in November 2019 up to an upper limit of 1 million euros, provided that the company's existing scope under state aid law allows this (EU small aid regulation).

Between February 7 and 26, a total of KRW379.6 billion in new loans and guarantees were provided by policy banks and KRW607.4 billion in loan and guarantee extensions to the SMEs, small merchants and self-employed business owners whose businesses have been hit by the spread of COVID-19.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: For Small merchants, financing options such as low-rate loans will be available through the Industrial Bank of Korea: the funds available for super low or prime rate loans at the IBK have been increased from KRW1.7 trillion to KRW4.2 trillion

SMEs experiencing temporary liquidity problems are eligible to receive financial support through primary collateralized bond obligations (P-CBO) and other government-backed financing programs aimed at supporting SMEs' facility investments.

SMEs and small merchants having problems with financing their businesses due to the spread of COVID-19 will be eligible to receive maturity extensions of existing loans for at least six months and up until the situation subsides. Savings banks, insurance and credit card companies are also offering support through maturity extensions.
The FSC announced the availability of loan maturity extensions and deferment of interest payments for SMEs and small merchants until March 31, 2021.
The Monetary Policy Board decided to increase the ceiling on the Bank Intermediated Support Facility from 25 trillion to 30 trillion won, to extend financial assistance to business owners and to SMEs

The FSC and other relevant institutions decided to make available the deferment of principal payment programs for vulnerable debtors for six more months until the end of June 2021 due to concerns about a protracted pandemic situation.

The government, the Bank of Korea and the Korea Development Bank decided to extend the operating period of the special purpose vehicle set up to purchase low-rated corporate bonds and CP for six months until July 13, 2021.

The central bank eliminated limits for withdrawals at ATMs. It also established that financial entities may not charge fees or commissions for operations (deposits, withdrawals, inquiries, etc.) made through all ATMs authorized and operated by them in the country. This is an extension until September 30, 2020 inclusive.
BCRA has extended the term during which institutions cannot charge fees on ATM transactions up to December 31, 2020.

Level 3 policy measures: Restrictions on use of profits and resources (e.g. dividends)
Details of the measure: Ban on dividends by banks

The government unveiled additional financial support for small merchants who have been hit by the recent heightening of social gathering restrictions at the 24th Meeting of the Central Economic Response Headquarters held on December 29. The newly announced support will be made available as soon as the system becomes ready at the lending institutions in mid-January 2021. A special lending support program will be newly launched to provide targeted support for small merchants who have been negatively affected by the recent heightening of social gathering restrictions. The new lending support for small merchants will be available for up to KRW10 million regardless of whether the borrower is a recipient of the government-sponsored second phase financial support program. There will be no guarantee fee for the first year with 0.6 percent fee rate applied from the second year.

Level 3 policy measures: State subsidies, direct loans and tax incentives to facilitate repayments
Details of the measure: The government announced a new coronavirus package worth 9.3 trillion won. The government has drawn up a package to support small businesses and workers affected by surging cases.  Small businesses:  - 4.1 trillion won worth of cash relief for a total of 2.8 million small businesses, reliefs varying from 1 million won to 3 million won per business according to the degree of losses; - Low interest rate loans and credit guarantee schemes for small businesses affected; - Extend tax incentives for rent cuts given to commercial property owners. - Expand the payment deferral for utilities bills and social security contributions Workers: - 500 billion won worth of cash relief for independent workers, including platform workers and freelancers:  378.2 billion won for 700,000 independent workers (1 million won per worker), 46 billion won for 90,000 visiting nurses (500,000 won per nurse) and 40 billion won for 80,000 taxi drivers (500,000 won per driver)
